name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare resumed the session adjourned on Thursday, 24 November 2016.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Jens Geier and Indrek Tarand, on behalf of the European Parliament delegation to the Conciliation Committee on Budgetary Questions, on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 (common text) (11900/ 201614635/2016 - C8-0373/2016 - 2016/2047 (BUD)) (A8-0353/2016).

name: Jean Arthuis
text: President of the Committee on Budgets. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as Europe and the world are going through a period of instability, it is heartening that the European institutions can set aside their differences and give the Union a budget within the time allotted by the Treaties. Contrary to the legend that one in two years conciliation fails, I am delighted that in 2016, for the 2017 budget, as in 2015, for the 2016 budget, we reached an agreement. I am glad that this year, surely overtaken by the many hours of negotiations, Parliament and the Council have taken one step towards the other in sending two clear messages. The first message is that the priority remains, more than ever, to tackle the problem of migration by strengthening the control of our external borders, while allowing the dignified reception of newcomers and the humanly sustainable return of migrants who cannot claim refugee status. Let us not be illusioned, much remains to be done in this area and our budget is extremely constrained in this area, but the progress made by the budgetary authority for 2017 is undoubtedly going in the right direction. The second message is that Europe is investing in its youth: an additional €500 million will be made available to the Youth Employment Initiative. In fact, $1 billion, if we add the additional allocations from the European Social Fund. In addition, 200 million additional appropriations have been allocated for future programmes, such as support for SMEs, the interconnection of infrastructure in Europe, Erasmus+ for students and apprentices — an emblematic programme on which the Commission had already focused in its draft budget — and research, with the Horizon programme 2020. Despite all the reproaches we can make to our budget, and there are many, 2017 edition sends a message of trust. Trust in the capacity of our institutions to work together and trust in our youth, which remains our most promising investment of the future. I thank our rapporteurs, Jens Geier and Indrek Tarand, who have informed our debates and our final arbitrations. Finally, I will express only one regret. Vice President Georgieva's last budget, which will have imprinted her brand, expertise, energy, training force and charisma. Madam Vice-President, accept our gratitude and allow me, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, to express my warm wishes for the success of your work at the head of the World Bank. We'll need you, ma'am.

name: Jens Geier
text: rapporteur. — Mr President. I have been told by the services that, although I only have three minutes of speaking time, I think I have six minutes. I would be grateful if you would briefly confirm that colleagues do not react completely irritated if I simply continue to speak after three minutes. Mr President, I do not know exactly whether you have listened to me now. The request is for you to confirm briefly that I have six minutes of speaking time. Thank you. Good. Thank you for being able to take the floor here as European Parliament rapporteur for the Commission budget. In the beginning, it is important to say thanks to all those who helped to succeed. I would like to thank the Slovak Presidency. I have always found their negotiation to be fair, open and accessible. That wasn't always the case. I would like to thank you very much for being a fair interlocutor and a good mediator for the European Parliament. My thanks also go to Kristalina Georgieva. I fully endorse what our committee chairman has said. It is your last appearance today in the plenary of the European Parliament, and I think that is important then that we, as the parliamentary part of the householder family, once again express thanks for an extraordinarily prominent work for the European budget. You have made a lot of progress, you have launched budget for results, a discussion about what we really want to achieve with the money. They have helped budgetary control. The budgets that you proposed under your aegis have often been guided by Parliament's priorities. We have always made a lot of progress in the budget negotiations with you. You were a fair partner and the Commission services under your leadership were an honest broker. For this whole many thanks and good luck with the World Bank. We will miss you, but we wish you all the best for the way forward. (Applause) The final thanks go to my shadow rapporteurs. I have always found the cooperation with them to be open and collegial. In the stressful moments that we all know — such as when you are standing on important issues in conciliation at 3 o'clock in the morning — it is good that, despite all the things that divide us, there is solidarity among the budgets across the political groups, and you even break a lance for things here and there, which was not necessarily voted for in the parliamentary debate. I think this is a very special form of cooperation that we have here, which I also find very pleasant. We want to vote on the 2017 budget package tomorrow. As rapporteur, I would urge you to adopt it, because the priorities of the European Parliament, as we have agreed here in this Chamber, are, as best they can, be reflected in this budget. We have received EUR 500 million in new money to combat unemployment, especially among young people, in the countries of southern Europe, and this will allow us to continue this very successful programme at the end of the day and continue to work to significantly reduce youth unemployment in many EU countries. We have achieved EUR 200 million more for growth and jobs, for small and medium-sized enterprises, transport infrastructure, research programmes and for promoting the mobility of people in the Erasmus+ programme. These are the most important headlines. Behind this, there are many important successes that recede a little before these two headings, but I want to highlight two especially because they are close to my heart. One is additional Money for UNRWA, for the UN Relief Agency for Palestinian Refugees. This agency is largely dependent on the money provided by the European Union. A Palestinian refugee must be worth as much to us as a Syrian refugee. We must ensure that the people in the camps have a social perspective, a training perspective for their young people, and what we have achieved is a guarantee of this. We have also been able to strengthen important social policy programmes such as Progress. That is particularly pleased — let me say that — a Social Democrat. We also did not achieve many things. I did not understand — and this task will come to us in the coming years — why it is not possible to include the heads of EU missions in the administrative category, where they also have their hat in the world as special representatives of the European Union! That sounds very technical. In the end, however, it is a question of whether we have more money for development policy and foreign policy and a clean system in the budget. There is apparently no legal basis here, and the Commission has to do something, and I myself find it unfortunate and have often been pointed out by the social networks that we have not succeeded in increasing humanitarian aid as we wanted. However, we have been able to strengthen important instruments in development policy. It is also particularly important to me, as a parliamentarian, that we have reminded the Commission and the Council a little of the dress code when it comes to spending money, which is to create the legal basis first and then put the money in the budget. That is why we will now wait patiently for the European Fund for Sustainable Development to come up with the legal basis. We're gonna have to talk again about how we can do this — then in the end very hectic — Improve procedures with the joint conclusions. This is a task for the future. I look forward to the discussion with you and hopefully a successful decision tomorrow.

name: Indrek Tarand
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to inform the plenary that before the vote tomorrow I have to make a technical adjustment. I am sorry about this but it is my duty. I would now like to congratulate and offer my gratitude to everyone who helped me to finish this adventurous and creepy road of budgetary process. We achieved as much as we could, and the only complaint from my side would be that we did not meet the 20% of climate—related budgeting, which only recently came out from the Court of Auditors document. But let us try to do better next year. The conciliation meeting ended in a friendly atmosphere but in a bit of a rush. That is why, on the initiative of the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, Mr Arthuis, we had to make some technical clarifications. I must say that almost two thirds of them were very successful. Unfortunately, the Commission failed to put in the necessary point about the reserves, which Parliament adopted with a large majority. The reserves were meant to improve the Code of Conduct for Commissioners, particularly for a cooling-down period for former Commissioners. I promise to this plenary, to the Commission and to everybody else that we will come back to this issue, because it seems that President Juncker has sent Mr Schulz a proposal about how to improve the Code of Conduct, although for me for the time being it does not look like a step in the right direction, but rather the opposite. It proposes a cooling—down period for former Commissioners and to allow them to be lobbyists at the same time and employed as advisers to Commissioners. It is too long a period. We can cool nuclear reactors much more quickly than former Commissioners, and sometimes these former Commissioners have not given as much energy as a nuclear power plant. So we will come back to this issue. Secondly, the External Action Services need to pay more attention to their strategic communication activities. We agreed on that and I am very grateful to the Council and the Commission for adopting it. The most important thing is, of course, our own business. Political groups asked for 76 additional posts, and I, as a negotiator, made the utmost effort to get something. Finally we compromised in a budgetary-neutral way, and now the problem is with this House. I understand that the Secretary-General has been flexible enough to resolve it. I apologise to all the Parliament officials who feel that their share was reduced in order to increase the share of political workers, but that is the political decision. I would like to thank Commissioner Georgieva, who was very helpful in these efforts to achieve the agreement, and also the shadows and everybody from Parliament’s delegation, as well as Minister Lesay from the Slovak Presidency. I heard on the Bulgarian news that the Bulgarian Government is intending to appoint a replacement, Mr Ivailo Kalfin, who has a lot of experience in Parliament. His appointment as a Commissioner would relieve us from sophisticated debates over hearings, semi—hearings and mini hearings and allow Mr Oettinger to continue, under the experienced and firm supervision of Vice—President Ansip, on the digital area and perhaps also take some commercial flights. To sum up, I am extremely grateful and indebted to the secretariat of the Committee on Budgets and many other people in different institutions who literally saved my skin on numerous occasions when I was lost in this budgetary jungle. The only thing I can promise next year, under the Estonian Presidency, is that we can try to do better.

name: Ivan Lesay
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, today it is my pleasure to attend the European Parliament’s debate on the general budget of the EU for the financial year 2017. On behalf of the Council, I would like to welcome the positive outcome reached by the Conciliation Committee in the early hours of 17 November after long and sometimes difficult discussions between, but also within, our respective institutions. We have been able to establish a realistic budget providing, on the one hand, the necessary appropriations to cover the needs expected in 2017 but leaving, on the other hand, sufficient margins to cope with unforeseen situations in the course of next year. I would like to underline the constructive atmosphere during our budgetary negotiations. The agreement on the 2017 budget could only be reached due to the readiness for compromise on both sides of the table, with tremendous help from the Commission. Thanks to the excellent teamwork, professional attitudes, mutual trust and Europeanism, we have managed to avoid another crisis, which our citizens would certainly not have understood – and rightly so. Parliament and the Council share the same two main priorities for the financial year 2017: to respond to the ongoing migration, refugee and security crisis, and to boost innovation, growth and employment in Europe. In the Union budget for 2017 we have been able to translate these priorities into concrete figures. Almost EUR 6 billion will be available for tackling migration issues within the Union, for dealing with its root causes and improving living conditions in our neighbourhood, and for reinforcing security in Europe and at its external borders. This amount corresponds to an increase of more than 11% compared to the budget of the previous year. Furthermore, more than EUR 21 billion was agreed for programmes and projects supporting competitiveness for growth and jobs, which translates into an increase of approximately 12% if compared to 2016. Successful programmes such as Erasmus+ are even increased by 19%, and the European Fund for Strategic Investments will see an increase of 25%. These figures are proof of our joint objective. Both Parliament and the Council want to make Europe a better and safer place to live, and to create training and job opportunities, notably for our young people. At the same time, the Union budget agreed for 2017 is a responsible compromise in these times of economic and financial crisis, which have led inter alia to major constraints on national budgets. Let me underline the importance of our joint agreement on reducing the number of staff in all the institutions, bodies and agencies by 5% by 2017. This signal is of the utmost importance for European citizens, especially in times when anti-establishment political parties are gaining stronger support across Europe. The package agreed by the Conciliation Committee includes a number of joint statements, and the Council strongly supports these statements and is fully committed to honouring them. After the successful outcome reached by the Conciliation Committee on 17 November, the Council formally approved the joint text on 28 November, and I am glad to inform you that no Member State voted against the compromise reached between our institutions. Parliament’s approval of the joint text tomorrow would allow the adoption of the general budget for the financial year 2017 within the deadline foreseen by the Treaty. For the first time, as was already mentioned by Mr Arthuis, for the first time since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, two consecutive annual budgetary procedures will have then been completed successfully in conciliation without having recourse to a new draft budget to be submitted by the Commission and a second round of negotiations. This outcome is also remarkable, as we had an additional challenge this year linked to the mid-term review or revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework. Due to the political momentum, the MFF revision has been a high priority, both for this Parliament as well as for the Council. Just in the following item on today’s agenda, and State Secretary Ivan Korčok will be clear here on the next steps which are necessary to finalise the MFF revision. Concerning the EU budget 2017, I would like to thank the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, Jean Arthuis, and the two rapporteurs, Jens Geier and Indrek Tarand – especially for your constructive approach, Jean, Jens and Indrek – during the whole annual budgetary procedure, for your openness to compromise and for the positive atmosphere. I would like to thank all the other colleagues from Parliament who during the long and stressful hours on the Council’s premises showed patience and a strong spirit of compromise. Finally, I would like to thank Vice-President Kristalina Georgieva for facilitating our negotiations. Without your support, it would have been far more difficult, if not even impossible, to reach a balanced and timely agreement. I wish you all the best in your future position, and I can say that you will be very much missed here.

name: Presidente. –
text: Before giving the floor to the Commission, Mrs Georgieva, I too wanted to join the thanks given to her: I had the pleasure of working with her when we were both commissioners, I had the pleasure of working with you as Vice-President of Parliament responsible for security and Commissioner and Vice-President Georgieva responsible for the Commission's security. Thank you, thank you for the fruitful work done together, in the mouth in wolf and good luck for the new, fantastic, adventure.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I join Mr Arthuis, rapporteurs Geier and Tarand, and Minister Lesay, in recognising that we have had difficult negotiations but very constructive negotiations, and through those hours, 18 hours during the very final stretch, we were all led by one objective: how to make best use of the scarce resources of the European Union. And of course we argued, because the needs are bigger than the resources that are available, and we had to make every effort to prioritise on the basis of what would do most for our people.  We have concluded that there are two overwhelming priorities: to manage migration flows and address the security threats, and to support the fragile recovery of our economy, especially with regard to what it means to be jobless for our young people.  I want to recognise each and every one of you who have worked towards finding the difficult, but finally successful room for compromise. This budget has already been described as remarkable because it injects additional funds for very valuable programmes that support the competitiveness of our economy such as Horizon 2020, Erasmus+, the Connecting Europe Facility and COSME. It has been emphasised that we have precious resources – a total of EUR one billion – for support for the Youth Employment initiative, and it has also been emphasised that we have not forgotten people who are depending on our kindness and generosity simply to survive, like the Palestinian refugees that Mr Geier talked about.  What I would add is that in this budget we have also been very careful to support innovation, new ideas, such as piloting a free access to rail for young people so that they can experience Europe, or supporting a European solidarity corps that would allow our young people to work together for Europe.  We have also not forgotten our farmers. In our budget we have EUR 528 million for the dairy sector and an additional EUR 100 million for the extension of the measures put in place to mitigate the impact of the Russian ban. To those of you who have been speaking up on behalf of those who are affected by the Russian ban, I just want to give you the reassurance that, indeed, their needs and the impact felt in the milk-sector are in our budget.  And finally, we have been very careful to allow the flexibility that has served us so well to be present in this budget, including by retaining a margin of EUR 1.1 billion, so that if a shock hits us we have the funds to respond.  Let me in these last hours standing in front of you finish with a word of gratitude to each and every one of you, for keeping me on my toes, for demanding of me and my colleagues to do our utmost, our best, so that our budget goes furthest for the people who rely so much on it. From the bottom of my heart, thank you. (Applause)

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we have a budget for the European Union for next year. This in itself is good news. Herewith we are proving to the Council, Commission and Parliament that we are ready to act and to deliver a budget to the European Union in these difficult circumstances and, not only that we have a budget, but that we have a good budget for the Union for next year. It responds to what we established at the beginning of the 7-year Multiannual Financial Framework as our main priorities: growth and jobs. In order to allow for more growth in the European economy to generate more jobs, we are investing the money which we have in innovation and infrastructure. It is those areas which will make the European economy stronger. We are also giving support to students, with EUR 50 million more for the Erasmus programme, and to SMEs and young entrepreneurs through investing EUR 50 million more into the COSME programme. As the Commissioner also said, we have not forgotten about farmers, and I want to see that, in addition to these additional priorities that we have had, we also respond to current and new challenges, making Europe safer again. We are strengthening Europol and Eurojust and we want to stop illegal migration to Europe and manage the refugee crisis which we have been tackling. The negotiations were difficult. We managed to agree, but to my colleagues in Council I also want to say that, if Europe is expected to deliver in the coming years, especially in 2018, Member States have to understand that, if there are new priorities and new demands vis—à-vis the budget of the Union, then of course fresh new resources are clearly also needed. What we are delivering this year is a good budget under difficult circumstances but, if we are expected to deliver more next year, then of course more resources are needed. To conclude, I would like to thank the main rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs, with whom we have worked in a good spirit. I would like to thank the Commissioner for the wisdom and the political sensitivity which she put into the negotiations – and sometimes passion too – to make this budget possible. I would also like to thank the Council for having been a good partner to us.

name: Derek Vaughan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, can I also thank the Commissioner and, as was said, she will be sorely missed. I would also like to thank the Slovak Presidency for the way they have conducted the negotiations, and of course our two rapporteurs, who I think have done a fantastic job. Indeed, I would say this is probably one of the best budget agreements we have had for a number of years, and of course the headlines will be the extra EUR 200 million for Heading 1A, research and development money, which is vital if we are to encourage jobs and growth in the European Union, and secondly, the EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment initiative. I think the Youth Employment Initiative has got off to a slow start in many states, but I also believe that youth unemployment is still one of the great scandals of our time. Therefore it is absolutely vital we continue to put money into the Youth Employment Initiative to try and tackle the scourge of youth unemployment. Hopefully colleagues will welcome that. Can I say on the 500 million and the written declaration from the Council, I think it is absolutely vital that they do allow the Commission to come forward with an amending budget next year. Too often in the past we have had written declarations, but when the time comes for the amended budget, the Council has backtracked and blocked it, so for the credibility of the European Union it is absolutely vital that the Council allows that to go ahead. Finally, can I say something on the various flexibility instruments – the flexibility instrument itself, the global margin and the contingency margin. Used in the right way, these flexibility instruments allow us to adapt to changing priorities and problems in the European Union and the EU’s budget, and hopefully we can learn lessons from that in the review of the MFF, and in the next MFF we must build in flexibility into a budget to tackle those new issues as they arise.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ECR Group. First of all, I too should like to thank the two rapporteurs, Mr Geier and Mr Tarand, for their work, for the report that has been presented. Unfortunately, as in previous years, this budget report is also going in the wrong direction. We have a 1.7% increase in commitment appropriations to EUR 158 billion. Once again, the priorities are wrong, as the EU intends to spend 72% of its expenditure on agriculture and cohesion policy in 2017. This is quite exactly the same as previous years. This means that we do not see any policy change here, we do not see any fundamental reorientation of our budgetary policy. The EU must not, however, be concerned with spending as much money as possible on certain projects, but must be concerned with spending this money in areas where the EU can create added value, where it can act better than the Member States on its own. This is the only reason why we should make money. And this is not true in many areas of the agricultural sector, at least not when it is a net contributor country. These net contributor countries could also distribute their subsidies without going through Brussels. That would be a real contribution to de-bureaucratization. In addition, we have a gap in this budget between commitment appropriations and payment appropriations of EUR 23 billion. I am, unfortunately, quite sure that we will again have problems with unpaid bills here in the future, because we promise more than we can afford. I would also like to point out that we have put forward EUR 500 million for cuts from the ECR, all of which were rejected by the Committee on Budgets. In particular, we had also proposed that we transfer funds for Turkey's accession to the EU to the EU, which was Unfortunately, God also refused. At the same time, we know that last week our Parliament called on the Commission by a large majority to suspend accession negotiations with Turkey. This shows that our proposal was correct.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, it is with conviction that the ALDE Group will vote for the agreement reached with the Council on the 2017 budget. No budget, however good as it may be, fully satisfies our aspirations, and it even contains provisions that are difficult to swallow. I am referring to the 76 additional positions for political groups. I also make it very clear that we can meet in this budget, at least partially, our priorities. We support the priority given to youth by increasing credits for student and apprentice mobility, as well as the $500 million to combat youth unemployment. We support the strengthening of credit for SMEs by allocating an additional 50 million to the COSME programme. We support strengthening the capacity for research and development through the additional funds allocated to Horizon 2020. We support the additional appropriations allocated to “Connecting Europe Facility”. We support the additional means provided to assist farmers affected by the Russian embargo, in particular milk producers. And we support the unprecedented effort to address the migration crisis and strengthen security within the European Union. I could go on explaining the reasons for our satisfaction at length, but I prefer at this point to thank the craftsmen of this agreement that — I must admit — at some point I did not think it was possible. First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Georgieva, whose departure we all regret, for the quality of her draft budget and for the intelligence of Letter of Amendment No 1, which is, in fact, the real basis for this agreement. Thanks to the delegation of the European Parliament and in particular to the two rapporteurs, Mr Geier and Mr Tarand, who, in symbiosis with President Arthuis, showed a rare tenacity and of high efficiency. And finally thanks to the Slovak Presidency, which, after a start-up which I found laborious and even provoked my anger, managed to rise to the level required to finalize this agreement. I thank her, and I congratulate her for that. In short, I welcome the effectiveness of all those who stayed around the table and finally succeeded in achieving the result that I support today with my entire group.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – Go raibh maith agat, a Chathaoirligh. Ba mhaith liom mo bhuíochas a ghabháil leis an dá rapóirtéir, an tUasal Tarand agus an tUasal Geier, as an obair fhónta atá déanta acu.  Tá an-díomá orm, caithfidh mé a rá, faoin gcomhaontú maidir le comhréitigh Bhuiséad an Aontais Eorpaigh 2017. Tá rialtais Bhallstáit an Aontais Eorpaigh tar éis faillí a dhéanamh ar na daoine – iad siúd atá i gcruachás, an ghéarchéim dhaonnúil agus caighdeáin shóisialta níos lú ná riamh. Agus is í an teachtaireacht atá ag teacht ón gComhairle ná Buiséad 2017 a chur chun tosaigh, cé gurb é sin an buiséad is ísle i dtaobh an tsealbhaithe íocaíochtaí le blianta fada.  Bhí réiteach eile le haimsiú. Bhí bealach eile atá féaráilte le haimsiú. Ach is easpa tola atá léirithe arís agus arís eile.  Cuirim i gcuimhne don gComhairle agus don gCoimisiún an fhreagracht a dúirt siad a bhí ar intinn acu chun an easpa comhionannais idir na tíortha agus Ballstáit a ísliú. Níl go leor infheistíochta san Eoraip; tá seirbhísí pobail ag fulaingt agus is iad an pobal a bhíonn i gcruachás dá bharr. Cá bhfuil an tiomantas agus an gealltanas a léirigh an Chomhairle i dtaobh fostaíocht a chruthú? Cá bhfuil an gealltanas i dtaobh ár ndaoine óga? Cá bhfuil an gealltanas i dtaobh tacú lenár SMEs? Tá an oiread sin dúshláin mar phráinn ag bagairt orainn agus tá an t-am tar éis sleamhnú chun déileáil leis seo go réadúil. Táimse ag rá leat go mbeidh praghas i bhfad níos mó le híoc againn sa todhchaí, de bharr an easpa físe agus an easpa tola agus gan treoir éifeachtach agus treoir pholaitiúil a bheith ann ar son na ndaoine. Tá ár bhfeirmeoirí, ár n-iascairí, ár n-aeráid, ár dtodhchaí ag brath ar an infheistíocht seo. Agus táim ag glaoch oraibhse anois seasamh le chéile agus seasamh dlúthpháirtíochta a thógaint ar son mhuintir na hEorpa uile.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, Mrs Georgieva, of course, thank you very much and all my congratulations, also to the rapporteurs and the entire team of the Committee. Of course it is an elaborate budget, worked hard, with sweat — we say — and with an indisputable result. But let me say right away that the two-year rule to which Mr Arthuis was referring, that it was not necessary this year to reach an agreement, we have broken it at a price, at the price of accepting a result of the initial approach of this Parliament and far, above all, of the desirability or necessity of the European Union in its set. It can be said that politics is the art of achieving what is possible. Okay. And surely here we have as much as possible, in the sense that the limit of this' possible 'is set by the Council, and it is clearly and forcefully marked — 'resources available', as Mrs Georgieva said. Do not ask us as Parliament to accept this logic, because if this Parliament accepts this logic, it is simply accepting to be a resonant chamber of decisions that are already taken in advance. The problem is not for this Parliament or for my group; it is for the European Union, for the commitments we have made as the European Union on climate change, the Europe 2020 strategy, the sustainable development goals. All these commitments are not being respected by this budget. The 200 million that appeared at the last minute mean what they mean for the respective games — for Horizon 2020, for COSME, for the Connecting Europe Mechanism, for Erasmus. You speak, as I did this morning, with Mr Bourguignon, of the European Research Council, and you will see what it means in real result, in real budgetary value. The same is true of the 500 million Youth Employment Initiative that will appear — we say — throughout the year, far away from the minimum continuity that would mark us 6 billion for the four years or 1,500 for each of them. And if we add to that the question of the Code of Conduct, which Mr Tarand reminded us, the conclusion is clear: we are also losing the battle of credibility, the battle of image and respect. When we protect controversial actions by former members of the Commission, we are equally damaging our own institutional credibility. Last but not least, we have budget, but we don't have MFPs. Let's discuss it in a few minutes. Our Group has shared the effort and has accompanied them here. We will certainly not be able to accompany them in the final vote.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, when we come to this point in the year, I sometimes wonder why we don’t just replay a recording of last year’s budget debates rather than repeat the entire performance. Because it is the same thing that happens over and over again. As it’s Christmas, let’s compare this to an annual pantomime. The Committee on Budgets, the Commission, the Parliament – well we all vote, don’t we, for more EU, more spending, more taxpayers’ money being thrown at this project? Then along comes UKIP and our colleagues in the EFDD – the Five Star Movement and others – and we suggest saving the taxpayer billions of euros. We show how it can be done, we show costs that can be cut and we show victimless cuts, saving money for ordinary people. Well, that makes us the pantomime villain. So you lot all boo. Oh yes you do. And Labour and Conservatives vote against whatever we come up with, and that sometimes shows how much they seem to care about saving money for ordinary people. And then the Council comes and proposes a smaller budget increase, and we have the ‘will they, won’t they?’ moment where the audience wonders if a compromise can be reached. So we go into the early hours of the morning almost every year, wondering whether they can find a new trick to find more taxpayers’ money without actually breaching the budget ceilings. And, after nail—biting tension, the audience on the edge of their seats, a compromise is always reached, the day is saved and everybody lives happily ever after – everybody, of course, except the general public, who have to pay for all of it despite, in the UK’s case, having voted for Brexit. Never mind a 3.3% backdated pay increase for EU Commission officials that went through the Committee on Budgets last time, never mind draft amending budget No 5, which means that the UK will have to fire off another EUR 700 million cheque off to Brussels, and never mind the repeated Court of Auditors reports. You know what? I sometimes don’t know whether this is a pantomime or a Kafkaesque farce. Well, the British people voted for Brexit and we’re going to write the last chapter, we’re going to play the final act and we’re going to lower the curtain on this tragedy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Arnott, as you mentioned, the United Kingdom is going to leave the European Union. Why do you care so much about the European Union budget? Leave us, the countries that remain, to take care of the European Union budget.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well that is exactly what we want to do. Of course we want to leave the European Union, but right at this moment we’re still here, and we’re still paying into that budget. Everything that we vote for, for 2017, is money that the United Kingdom, as things stand at the moment, will have to pay into that budget, so of course I care about the British taxpayer having to pay into this place.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, today the OECD proudly announced that taxes have never been so high, and Brussels is taking part in this. The budget is therefore a long list of costly failed dreams, billions for so-called refugees, billions for a beaten to death and billions for EU propaganda. Unlike the Social Democrats over there, I think it is a great shame that the Palestinian budget is also going up 10%. These are the same Palestinians who try to kill Jews in every way possible. We're going to give over 300 million a year to the terrorists who fire missiles, commit bombings and burn forests today. Brussels continues to insist that these are all the starting point for peace negotiations. Brussels, morally bankrupt, what else can you make of it? Mr President, it is clear that my party will vote against this budget. (The speaker answered a blue card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure. — Thank you, Mr President. Colleague, among other things, you have said that taxes are too high and Brussels is to blame. I want to ask you: do you know who has duties in the field of taxation, the establishment of taxes and taxes in the Member States?

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: “blue card” -answer. — Thank you very much for the question. The point that has been made here is, of course, that this European Parliament itself has a Committee on Budgets, and in that Committee on Budgets, it has been decided, after I have tabled amendments, that there is no expenditure that can even be a little downward. Everything this Parliament does and everything that Europe spends is well spent. In no European country, in any country in the world, there is ever a budget that is perfectly perfect, but this Committee on Budgets believes it is. And that is the source of all budget overruns.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President! Returning to the previous speaker, of course, the Council and the Heads of State or Government have decided to cut this seven-year framework by 4% compared to the last framework, and we are saving 1% of posts per year. I would like to know which Member State is as efficient as the European Union. With 40 000 employees, we have the lowest budget of all political levels, and I dare say that we have the most efficient budget. On top of this, we have adopted this 2017 budget in a very democratic, grassroots way. I would like to thank the Slovak Presidency in particular. Mr Lesay has conducted these negotiations very carefully. Finally, I believe that, in fact, the essential points that are important in the European Union have been optimally implemented. I believe that our Commissioner, Kristalina Georgieva, too — I would like to thank her very warmly — brought the negotiations itself to a positive end at four o'clock in the morning, with full commitment and with all her charisma. We also see that the social attitude here was full, for example at the Special Olympics, where we really helped the poorest of the poor in the European Union to prepare for the Games here with six million. Our MEP, Mr Becker, was very pleased that this initiative has been implemented. We have implemented initiatives for the labour market. And my dear friends from UKIP: We have enough unemployed in many countries. The European Union, in particular, is called upon here if Member States fail to eradicate unemployment, to take new initiatives here, and with EURES, with Progress, we have managed to make a great deal of progress here. With COSME, we support the self-employed and small and medium-sized enterprises with over An additional 50 billion, the European Research Council — the flagship project worldwide — has received more money to support young active scientists. We have also implemented the Connecting Europe Facility, which enables this internal market. Thank you, thank you, thank you — I am proud of this Europe!

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: — First of all, I want to congratulate the rapporteurs for their work in obtaining this budget, which comes to change, at least in part, the logic of austerity. We need to work together to solve many of the problems of European citizens and to fund our actions at the level of the ambitions and expectations of those we represent. For example, supporting young people and combating unemployment. After long negotiations and many of our calls as MEPs, we have obtained EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative. Similarly, this budget brings back EUR 200 million for important European Union programmes, Erasmus +, COSME, Horizon 2020 or Connecting Europe Facility. I would like this kind of topics, referring here, in particular, to support young people, to no longer become a polemic between us and between the institutions. We need concrete solutions that can be financed at European level, as we face the challenges we face. The most important in budget construction is not to forget its purpose. We in the European Social Democrat family, and especially in the Social Democratic Party, think that the most important thing is to invest in people, which is also visible in our programme of government. Last but not least, I am glad that this budget confirms the approval of two initiatives that I have proposed, totalling EUR 3 million, that will support the industry and the digital sector at European level and, especially, in my country, Romania. Together we can do a lot, but for this we need to get out of technocratic rhetoric, correlating the budget with the real needs of the citizens. And in this regard, I want to thank for the approval of this budget.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this budget responds to the migration, security and agricultural crises in a manner that is both timely and appropriate, and that is welcome, but I wish to express one reservation. Whilst I share my colleagues’ concerns about youth unemployment, I am not convinced of the value of the Youth Employment Initiative. In common with the views of the European Court of Auditors, I too have seen plenty of similar schemes which actually deliver very little by way of value for money. Surely the two things that young people need most is, firstly, a quality education and training system, and, secondly, a strong, growing economy that creates job opportunities for all. Finally, may I finish with a word to Vice-President Georgieva. Commissioner, you have achieved a huge amount. Through your formidable skills you have transformed the budget, and you leave behind you a legacy which is huge and valuable. For that, we offer you our thanks, and we wish you well in your new job at the World Bank.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to focus on two concepts, two terms central to any budgetary process. The first is the word ‘trust’. When we struggled with the first version of the EFSI Fund, one of the central themes was the willingness on the Commission side to take money out of the parliamentary budget. That was, of course, very hard for us to accept. During that process, Vice—President Georgieva showed that she understood our difficulties, and she did something which is probably unique in the relationship between the Commission and the Parliament: she built a fund of trust. When in this budget we were able to repair some of the ills created by the first round of EFSI, I think we established a trustful cooperation between the Vice—President and Parliament. We are going miss her very much, particularly in the next round. The second question is balance. There is an old saying: ‘No taxation without representation’. That was the golden rule when the monarchies were broken and their power was broken. Now we are going to see the same issues. The more subtle the budget becomes, the bigger the question of ‘No taxation without representation’ will be before us. I am deeply worried about the prospects for future deals in this House.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner and Mr Representative of the Council: 6.4%, that is the cut in payments agreed this year for this budget. One of the most austere budgets known in a long time has been agreed. It is cut in social and territorial cohesion funds; it is cut in health and rights and equality. And what is it reinforced? Well, for example, in Turkey's trust fund, our undemocratic border keeper. Also, the internal security fund almost doubles. Securize; for that there is funding, but for climate change goals, for example, there are not enough. 24% of people living in Europe are at risk of poverty. And what happens to the lords of the People's Party? To distribute Interrail tickets to all young people. Very useful. Young people today travel to look for work. You're breaking up Europe. They are the ones that generate a European Union of corrupt, undemocratic treaties and insufficient responses to people's social problems. Europe needs democratic responses and Europe needs change for people's problems.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union throws out billions of euros for fake refugees for immigrants and abandons Italian, Spanish, Greek and French citizens into unemployment and poverty. In Italy almost one in two young people are unemployed, and one in ten lives in absolute poverty. In Italy there are more than three million unemployed people, over four and a half million poor citizens who cannot even put together lunch with dinner. The dramatic truth is that our businesses are closing: our young people are the new poor, forced to emigrate, to work, to survive! And what does the EU do in its budget? He allocates money to keep 177 000 illegals in Italy, kept in the hotel with free breakfast, lunch and dinner, thanks to the Renzi government. And, not content, he gives 6 billion euros to Islamic Turkey, bending to the blackmail of dictator Erdogan. You understand? You understand then, why do the citizens want to run away from this crazy cage that is the European Soviet Union?

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all allow me to give the Commissioner a word. You did an excellent job again! We must say thank you for your commitment, thank you for your competence, for the quality you have shown. You set the bar so high that whoever comes to take your briefcase will have difficulties. We, however, will be here to help. It is thanks to you and your commitment, your proposals and especially the budget proposal, but then also to letter of amendment No 1, as well as the negotiations, that we have achieved this agreement. I also congratulate the Presidency of the Council on their perseverance and also for its competence and a thank you to rapporteurs Geier and Tarand for the compromise we have reached here. The priority of the budget is clear: it is youth. That is why we strengthen Erasmus+, the youth employment initiative, but young people also need a growing economy and hence the strengthening of the European Union's competitiveness in programmes such as research, such as innovation and also, in addition to strengthening Erasmus+, the strengthening of the COSME for small and medium-sized enterprises companies. Furthermore, this budget, which we regard as positive because it also responds to security in the European Union and solidarity with refugees, is now missing a second part to make it perfect: that the link it has to the revision of the multiannual financial framework is effective. The EUR 500 million that we give to youth in this budget must have consequences for the revision of the multiannual financial framework. The payments that are needed in the budget must have consequences in terms of that review and we need flexibility. I therefore call on the Council for a genuine revision of the multiannual financial framework so that we can help the Council itself to make commitments and to implement them, commitments it has made with the citizens of the European Union.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: — Mr President, as shadow rapporteur for the other sections, on behalf of my Group of Socialists and Democrats, I am pleased that we have achieved results that are in line with the current realities, particularly on the question of supporting the European Parliament's resources to ensure that it remains a place of democracy, on the the question of security-related adjustments and the question of measures to reduce the environmental footprint of our parliamentary activity. I welcome that. But as a member of the Committee on Budget, I would also like to make a few comments on the 2017 budget as a whole. I am pleased to see real support for the COSME programme, as has been said by several speakers, in favour of SMEs, for the Horizon 2020 programme, which is the sanctuary of European fundamental research, the Youth Employment Initiative, of course. I am also pleased to see that, for the first time, almost all of the flexibility instruments have been used. But I am also concerned about the overall inadequacy of the European budget which cannot meet the enormous needs facing the European Union, particularly in terms of investment. Moreover, the European Union would have gone well from the €1.8 billion less linked to the exchange rate after Brexit. I clearly call for a budgetary reorganisation, in which the European Parliament would finally have the power to vote on revenue, not just expenditure, and half with the Council. Politics remain the last refuge for adventurers, Wolinski repeated. It is now more than time for Member States to be these adventurers. The European Parliament will support them.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! In taking the floor in this debate, I want to emphasise the importance of the compromise concluded by Parliament and the Council, resulting in the amount of liabilities amounting to almost 158 billion and the amount of payments close to 135 billion. The attempt to rebuild funds for Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe programmes — previously reduced in connection with the funding of the so-called Juncker Plan — the transfer of additional funds to Erasmus+ and COSME programmes or additional resources to young people's employment programmes, and also additional measures for intervention in agricultural markets. The enlargement of the measures in Chapters Three and Four, which gives the opportunity to strengthen the Union's actions beyond its borders in order to eliminate the causes of migration in countries of origin and transit. However, the low level of cohesion policy payment appropriations — just €37 billion, because 2017 will be the fourth year of the financial framework for 2014-2020, and this in practice will mean more than the run-off of bills to be paid.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: Mr President! Commissioner! First of all, I would like to congratulate and thank our rapporteurs, but also the Slovak Presidency, which showed great openness, and Madam Commissioner, thanks to which, very clearly, we did not leave the room during the negotiations. Because I think it's only your determination that we decided to stay. I think this is evidence of a deep belief that indeed today the budget is needed. This budget makes it possible to demonstrate that we have avoided something that has happened in previous years — namely very high tensions, an atmosphere of conflict. We have essentially come to an agreement and in this room you can see that generally the parties are satisfied. It seems to me that this is a very important signal, in particular today in Europe, that we are showing that we are willing to compromise. Secondly, this budget introduces some elements of flexibility that we are discussing at a multi-year perspective. And it is extremely important that this budget allows for the launch of certain mechanisms in 2017 and opens up some possibilities in the following years. It is extremely important that we, working on budget 2017, have been working on the rest of the financial perspective until 2020. I wanted to thank you very much for this.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the first thanks goes to Commissioner Georgieva, thanks for these three years of accompanying work on the budget. The second thanks goes to Commissioner Georgieva, but also to the rapporteurs Mr Gahler and Mr Tarand, for their good work on the budget this year. A budget that satisfies us of course, but that I, as has been said, for the things you are said, that I want to consider as a beginning, a beginning of a path and probably — why not? — maybe, of a turn. We need a budget and a multiannual financial framework, as has been said, more modern, adapted to the times we live, the difficulties and challenges we are experiencing. A multiannual financial framework, a budget that is more flexible and which are more substantial, also, of course, that they have more substance within them. We often say that we need to make policies to combat the popusms that grow and are born in Europe. I don't care about that. I think that Europe has a high duty: it has a duty to make policies to respond to the citizens, to the demands that citizens make to Europe about work, especially young people, the environment, with regard to issues of immigration, which concerns both migrants, but also concerns countries and cities and communities that welcome migrants who are in great difficulty. And then on the environment, work on business, we need to focus on this and to get these results, to work on these matters, we need to go back to investing, we need to have a Europe that goes back to investing. That is why I also support the appeal made by Mr Fernandes to the Council in relation to the multiannual financial framework. We need and it's the last thing I say President, apologizing for stolen time, we need to try again to respond to a dream, that citizens have: that a Europe that comes back to thinking about the citizens and not just austerity anymore.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: Mr President! Madam Vice-President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. You can only congratulate on the result. You have to say postmodern: the way is the goal. So you managed to go together, and that's a huge success, because we all know how hard this has become today. That is why my express appreciation to all parties involved — they did great! Maybe you can learn from this. On the one hand, I think it is right that we did not tie it to the MFF, because that would have meant that we would not be here today. That's why, in my opinion, you need to think carefully about whether you want to have the egg in the refrigerator or the omelette on the plate. For us, of course, it means that all the more so now at the MFF, where we have to achieve results, we are all the more dependent on flexibility that the well-meaning also give in. There are many good arguments to stick together with the MFF and move back together, which is why my appeal. I would also like to appeal to the fact that solidarity is not a one-way street. In the countries which claim solidarity for themselves, we need more understanding of the fact that solidarity also applies to refugees. We cannot live with some caring for the refugees and the others not. This will drive a large wedge into the European Union. That is why I can only say that the recipient countries have to move much more than they do so far, otherwise we will no longer hold this European Union together. Another appeal to colleagues in the Committee on Budgets, on the part of budgetary control: if we work together, and even better than we are doing today, then we can achieve great things together. That is why I believe that today is a good day for the European Union, not the last good one, but one of many good ones. I believe that we are going to the anti-Europeans, the Antis, have shown. And we do not need the anti-Europeans to move forward together. We will show that together we are stronger than each person alone. Thank you. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr Tajani! Thank you very much. I have a question for Ingeborg Gräßle. Solidarity is something that needs to be lived every day. The European Union has put forward many proposals here in the refugee crisis. We now have the problem that the Member States cannot agree on solidarity here. What else do you think the European Union could do to reach an agreement between the Member States?

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the procedure of “blue card”. — The magic word, of course, is “money”. We need to reward those who do more, and we need to take money from those who do less. I myself have tabled three amendments to the budget, which have yet been rejected, namely that those who do not follow European law — and it is European law — should also feel it when it comes to how much money they receive. I think this is the way to the future. And not getting money is a language that is understood even without an interpreter.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, Madam Vice President, let's be honest and open to us and to our constituents! Along with the common values that we share, along with the faith that holds us together — what holds this Union together yet is the budget and the common currency. That is why this is not just another budget, but this is the future of Europe, spelled out in figures. And in these turbulent and storm times, we have achieved a lot: we have half a billion more for new jobs for young people, we have 200 million more for student mobility, for supporting small and medium businesses and for key infrastructure projects. Along with all the positives, we have to say, however, that we also have problems. VAT fraud cannot occupy such colossal proportions. And a step towards solving this problem are genuine own revenues and a single VAT system. We also need a single investment platform — why not in the field of tourism. Last but not least - I am sure, Mrs Georgieva, that you are leaving a good legacy to the next Commissioner. I congratulate you on your work!

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: — Thank you to both rapporteurs, all those involved in the conciliation process, for having an ambitious European Union budget for 2017. Thanks to the European Parliament, it offers more funding for strategic items, employment, small and medium-sized enterprises, transport infrastructure, research, innovation, Erasmus and for our security. Today's package also includes €50 million to provide appropriations for advances in the event of accidents from the Solidarity Fund. The European Union Solidarity Fund is more than just financial support, it is also a political message of solidarity and offers the necessary assistance to the affected citizens. Responding quickly, including through advance payments, will help the Union to achieve these objectives. Ladies Commissioner Georgieva, I wish a successful continuation of her career. It was an honour to work with her.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Mr President, the budget has never been and will not be such that it satisfies all wishes, all needs, but we must monitor priorities. If Europe faces such fundamental challenges as security and cohesion, then we must monitor the priority of strengthening internal and external security and I am very pleased that the budget for the year 2017 increases the capacity of both personnel and technical to the security agencies. When it comes to building cohesion within the European Union, then we need to think about youth, their education, their employment and their application. It is therefore important that Erasmus plus, Creative Europe, Europe for Citizens, European Volunteer Service, Erasmus Plus, Creative Europe, Europe for Citizens. These are the programmes that build and strengthen European identity. I also want to thank the Commissioner for her work and wish her every success. And to ask that the European Union does not forget our budget.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in this budget, we finally see timid stimulations to promote growth, to cope with the migration crisis and to strengthen youth policies. Compared to 2016, it is important to emphasize the increase in commitments to immigration, security, by 11.3%, to around 5.9 billion euros. I particularly appreciate that the agreement has transposed the European Parliament's demands on the additional funding of 700 million, the Erasmus programmes, Horizon 2020 and the young initiative. There are therefore improvements in the distribution of expenditure, which are going in the right direction, but which are not yet sufficient. I regret, in particular the reduction of commitments to the Mediterranean countries and the postponement, due to the lack of legal basis, the financing of the European Fund for Sustainable Development of 250 millions to address the root causes of immigration. Finally, I welcome the anticipation of emergency measures to support European farmers forced to deal with very difficult market situations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mrs Georgieva on her appointment to the World Bank and wish her every success in her work. Mr President, we are in the same work once again, with a budget that is an austerity budget, and in this way neither the economic crisis nor the refugee crisis can be tackled. EUR 41 million is allocated for employment, EUR 115 million for asylum and immigration. Of course, we must point out that EUR 530 million is also available in the area of security and citizenship, but these are crumbs, especially the sums allocated to tackling unemployment, since Europe is plagued by armies of the unemployed, especially the unemployed belonging to the new generation. The sums allocated to the refugee crisis are also insufficient. Greece has so far spent 2.5 billion euros addressing the refugee crisis. So much more sums are needed to deal with the major problems that Europe has today.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL). — (EL) Mr President, I think that a large part of the debate has rightly been devoted to youth unemployment, but I would like to add the following: there are countries where youth unemployment starts at 20% and often hits 40%. This is essentially a bomb in the foundations of democracy, because if young people do not have a job, they also distance themselves from the construction of the European Union, they also distance themselves from what democracy is, because nothing worse than feeling that they are not part of society. I would like to end with this: there must be radical action to tackle youth unemployment, who have tons of knowledge, much more than adding the knowledge of all of us in this Chamber, and knocking on our door to find work and we are ashamed to say that we have difficulty dealing with this problem. It must be a comprehensive, radical attempt by the European Union to address this issue, because tomorrow we will face their anger, bitterness and perhaps their reaction.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D).
text: — Mr State Secretary Lesaj, I am really proud of the Slovak Presidency and of the efficiency, integrity and fairness of the negotiations. I agree with you that reducing the number of employees by 1% in a row for 5 years is very important. However, it will be very necessary to examine how this cut has achieved the objective, because some institutions that have dismissed interpreters are thus employing them externally because they really need them. I have participated in the final negotiations on the European Union budget for ten years, so I can compare and evaluate. Commissioner, we will really miss your expertise, the move on the gate, your empathy and the tremendous interest in doing everything in your power for the people of the European Union. I keep my fingers crossed and thank you again.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr. President. We all know that the budget is always difficult to negotiate and it is difficult to accept when your proposal is not accepted. But let's not forget, resources are limited and high demands. Personally, I want to thank you, Madam Vice-President, Commissioner, who negotiated excellently and obviously also the rapporteurs, for the final form of budget, which I personally will support. Of course, I am a supporter of SMEs, I am a supporter of youth. Obviously I would have wanted here more. But I understand that it can't be done. I believe that it is now the role of the Council and the Member States to see how they spend this money that we have allocated on very important chapters. And I also think that it is still important to see the collection, said a colleague of mine. I would also like to add that for the next budget we need to think much more about how we can stimulate investment in poor areas, increase social cohesion, dedicate investment to tourism, because for Europe it is indeed an opportunity to increase jobs in the turn of youth and, obviously, do not forget about innovation and education. Thank you personally and wish you good luck in your new job and remember, maybe you can help us from there.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the fact that the European Parliament managed to restore the Commission’s initial proposal on all lines cut by the Council. Furthermore, the European Parliament delegation managed to ensure a big amount of fresh reinforcements for the key programmes, such as growth and jobs and the Youth Employment Initiative. I also find fundamental the allocation of additional EUR 500 million to tackle the crisis in the agricultural sector, to support dairy and livestock farmers, and the additional 5.91 billion to tackle the migration and refugee crisis and reinforce security. Finally, I support the decision taken in order to accommodate a big part of these reinforcements to mobilise the special instruments available under the current Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 Regulation.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this has been a very engaged session and I am very grateful for the comments that have been made. Let me respond to some of the points that honourable Members have raised. First, there are indeed grounds for concern about the level of payments in the budget for 2017 and, more specifically, about the level of payments for cohesion policy. It is unfortunate but true that the new programmes – the programmes under the current Multiannual Financial Framework – have taken some time to start, with the result that in many of them we are registering delays in implementation. We have been working very hard with Member States to encourage the availability of authorising bodies that can then certify expenditures so we can speed up implementation. That would, of course, have a positive impact on payments. So it is definitely not because we do not have the capacity to provide these funds. It is objectively because of the slower pace of the implementation of the programmes. We are working with the Council – as Minister Lesay would confirm – to find ways to speed up that process. Secondly, a number of speakers made comments about the new ways in which we tried to fund new priorities, more specifically the Turkey Facility trust funds. One of the comments very clearly stated ‘No taxation without representation’. There has to be a role for Parliament. On the Commission side we agree, and we are thinking of ways in which we can make sure that, if there is a need to mobilise extra budgetary resources, it is done in a fair way so that Parliament can have a say without creating processes that may slow down implementation. That is a fair point, and the three institutions will have to reflect on it and address it. Third, I am fully mindful of the fact that there are demands for money that we have not been able to meet within the parameters of this budget. It is therefore up to us in the Commission to follow up implementation very carefully. Should there be a reason for any programme to be slower than anticipated, we would do what we have done in previous years: relocate funds to a higher priority. In other words, what we have done with the budget up to now in this financial framework, gearing up for more agility and more flexibility, we will continue in 2017. Finally, I would like to express my deepest gratitude to the Slovak Presidency for – indeed as many of you have recognised – being fair, engaged and determined, and to the budget negotiators, the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, the two rapporteurs and each and every one of you who stayed in the room until four o’clock in the morning so we could have a budget that, as you recognised, is a sound budget. It is a good budget and now we have to implement it. Well, thank you. (Applause)

name: Ivan Lesay
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this very useful exchange of views. It has shown that we are united in our commitment to making progress for the benefit of Europe and its citizens. This debate closes long and sometimes difficult discussions between the European Parliament and the Council over several months. However, they have shown that our respective institutions share many objectives and that our positions are not that far apart. This has been my impression all the time, and that is why we have been confident that we would be able to reach a deal. It proved not to be too easy but we were happy to do it in the first round, and here we are with the compromise. As I said, the negotiations on the 2017 budget took place under complex circumstances. In spite of this, we worked together in a constructive manner and we were able to reconcile our positions on how to finance the different priorities and actions of the Union. I am convinced that the agreement reached on the 2017 budget is a good and balanced result, allowing the Union to act and react to the various needs. I thank everybody once again. Thank you very much for your attention, and I wish you success during tomorrow’s vote.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: PRESIDENT OF THE BUDG COMMITTEE. — (FR) (FR) Mr President, Madam Vice-President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the debate we have just shown that if our 2017 budget is a step in the right direction, there is still a small step where Europe needs big strides, especially for investment, for growth, for economic growth and for the employment, and for the control of migratory flows as well. For, let us not be mistaken, other crises are in sight, other emergencies will justify torturing the budget to try to make it do what, in many cases, it is not able to accomplish. Look at how many budgetary protuberances have multiplied, how many satellites are densifying the European budget galaxy. Juncker Fund for Strategic Investments, Budget Facility for Turkey, Trust Funds here, Trusts Funds there, and tomorrow Juncker Fund for Africa or European Defence Fund. So many peripheral entities that are outside parliamentary control. The creativity of the European Commission cannot hide for a long time the destitution of the European budget and these budgetary practices are, for the Union, a danger. They put the European Union at risk, first of all, because the proliferation of budgetary satellites makes reading a European budget that is already too distant from the citizens. Let us not forget, ladies and gentlemen, that society has the right to ask any public official in its administration to account; this is a fundamental democratic requirement. Without budgetary readability, we risk disconnection. Europe becomes weakened when it proves to be unable to speak directly to European citizens. Finally, such a budgetary contortion tends to accredit illusions and, unfortunately, disappointments. A Union without a budget, committed on all fronts, risks giving a show its helplessness. The urgency is to agree on the competences that Member States are ready to transfer to the Union, because they no longer have the ability to assume them in a globalised world. The budget will then have to be endowed accordingly, to show our ambition to make Europe a world power. Beyond the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework, which is the subject of the forthcoming debate, it is already time to plan ourselves into the post-2020 period. Before concluding, I would like to thank the Slovak Presidency, Ecofin, but also the Presidency of the General Affairs Council for their brilliant and caring effectiveness.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support the agreement on the budget for next year. It is particularly gratifying that, at Parliament's insistence, the funding for the Youth Employment Initiative will be increased by EUR 500 million. In doing so, we are tackling a major current problem in the EU, the appalling level of youth unemployment. With the Employment Initiative, we are helping young unemployed people to find a job in a very concrete way. Now we must continue to call on the Member States to ensure that this money arrives where it is needed without major bureaucratic requirements. I find it equally important that the programmes applicable to SMEs have also been increased.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is essential that the EU budget be able to keep pace with the implementation by Member States of regional development programmes accelerating in 2017 and making cohesion funds available on an appropriate scale. The EU budget has the resources to allow the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated in implementing Member States' projects. We have also managed to ensure that the funds mobilised to tackle the migration crisis are not diverted to the detriment of other EU programmes that are already in place. Cohesion and agricultural money cannot be reduced when defining resources for tackling the migration crisis. Finally, the 2017 EU budget does not contain provisions on penalties for Member States rejecting compulsory reception quotas. The socialists and liberals have proposed a budgetary mechanism that would penalise Member States which, despite the mandatory resettlement quota system, do not accept illegal immigrants into their countries. This attack was averted during the adoption of the 2017 budget.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. — According to the agreement reached with the Council, the appropriations to cover commitments in 2017 should be EUR 157,86 billion and the payment appropriations EUR 134,49 billion. I am pleased that we have managed to fight an additional EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI), supporting them to search for work and experience, and another EUR 200 million for jobs and growth focused projects such as COSME, competitiveness small and medium-sized enterprises, the Connecting Europe Facility, designed to fund infrastructure projects, the Horizon 2020 programme, which supports research projects, and the Erasmus+ programme. In addition, the EUR 725 million package will be allocated to support migration funds, including EUR 28 million will be allocated to UNRWA helping Palestinian refugees and EUR 3 million to support peace processes. This is a good result of long and uneasy negotiations with the Council.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. — The three institutions, the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission, agreed on the 2017 budget of €157.8 billion for hiring expenditure and €134.5 billion for actual payments. Additional resources have been provided for job creation for young people, financing small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as student exchanges. However, I believe that there are still programmes approved at European level that are still underfunded. For example, funding for immigrants is insufficient both in Europe to integrate immigrants and to reduce the flow of immigrants through action outside Europe. It is important that the European Union does not adopt the practice of some Member States approving programmes, without funding from the public budgets required by the implementation of these programmes being ensured.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am very glad that we have finally a budget for next year. In fact, it is very important that the EU will increase its commitments in the field of ‘competiveness for growth and jobs’. In particular, I welcome the additional EUR 50 million on Erasmus+ as this programme enables youth to arrange friendships with Europeans from other countries, especially as very often such relationships can last for whole lives. Furthermore, within this programme there will be some amount of money allocated to support of handing out free InterRail tickets to all young Europeans when they turn 18. Such strengthening of Erasmus+ means that participants will have now even more opportunities to get their first international experience and visit many beautiful places in Europe. In addition, EUR 500 million more for the Youth Employment Initiative means simply better tackling unemployment in the poorest EU regions. Consequently, it is crucial that in light of the wave of euroscepticism spreading across the continent, the EU increases expenditure on activities leading to creation of jobs and the development of a common European identity in a young generation.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. — The adoption of the common text of the EU budget under the 2017 procedure will undoubtedly send a positive signal on the skills of the EU institutions to develop a common position on this key issue. Rudently creating jobs and stimulating economic growth remain one of the fundamental priorities for us. This is intended, inter alia, to increase funds for Erasmus+, research, infrastructure and support for SMEs. No doubt we are moving in this case in the right direction. However, I would also like to remind you of other programmes such as Creative Europe or Europe for Citizens, which also represent strategic investments in human capital. I stress that their adequate funding is a prerequisite for effective implementation and delivery of tangible results. I also draw your attention to the fact that the macroeconomic environment in the EU affects the ability of Member States to meet their funding commitments to EU institutions and bodies and thus, as we know perfectly well, the EU's ability to continue to implement EU policies. Thus, I point out that our expectations must be realistic and take into account the current macroeconomic situation, but we cannot set in efforts to raise awareness of policymakers and citizens about the role of investment in culture and education in stimulating economic growth and creating places work.

name: El Presidente. –
