text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the basis of Council and Commission statements on the review of the MFF.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you very much for this opportunity to lead you through the process where the Slovak Presidency was engaged in the Council to explore possibilities on amendment to the Multiannual Financial Framework. I would like to lead you through, but we agreed with Vice-President Kristalina Georgieva that she will explain more in detail the components of the package that the Council is proposing. Instead, I will share with you a few political remarks, but I would like to start by saying that the Slovak Presidency has a clear guidance for the process of review/revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework, and that was given by the MMF Regulation agreed in 2013. I would like to quote what was written there, namely that the review shall, as appropriate, be accompanied by a legislative proposal for the revision of the MMF Regulation. So that was a clear guidance for us. I would like to say that we started in the Council the work on MMF review/revision with a political debate, so this was not for us, Mr President, a technical exercise. On the contrary, we knew that we needed to have a frank and open political debate where we should ensure consensus, or an opinion, on whether the financial perspective, as agreed back in 2013, corresponds to new challenges both outside of the EU and inside the EU, and whether we have sufficient flexibility to react to unforeseen circumstances or events. So these two objectives were at the forefront of our effort. Number one: whether we need more in terms of financial resources, and to ensure more flexibility. I can say that the outcome of this political debate that we have had under our leadership in the Council was, yes, the Council recognised that the events outside of the Union and internal challenges in fact require additional resources, and that we need more flexibility to react swiftly to the challenges that I have referred to. So on that basis the Commission has proposed, in mid-September this year, a review and revision of the financial perspective that we have agreed in 2013. The second point that I wanted to make is about the process. This was important. Of course the substance matters, but the process this time was extremely important. We all know, both Parliament and the Council and the Commission, that we have been working in a framework given by special legislative procedure. Nevertheless, we in the Council knew that Parliament has well-defined expectations when it comes to the need to revise the financial perspective; we were aware of the resolution that you have adopted, and that is why, in spite of this special legislative procedure, we, together with the Commission, have engaged in a very open dialogue with you, with Parliament. I want to thank your representatives, representatives of this House, led by Chair Arthuis and the two rapporteurs Madam Thomas and Mr Olbrycht. I have to say they were very tough negotiators. There were moments when really it was not easy for us to accommodate everything for which you, Mr Chair, Madam rapporteur, rapporteur Olbrycht, have been fighting for. It was very difficult with you. But, when I look back, I dare say that it was thanks to your perseverance that in fact we were able together to come up with a package, which I think duly reflects both the need for additional resources and for more flexibility, so I think it is to your credit and your merit that it is included in this package. Thirdly, as I said, I will not go into details. I would like to kindly ask Kristalina to lead you through, but I would like to say that this package, when it comes to resources, is giving a chance to mobilise more than EUR 6 billion to be allocated for the most outstanding priorities until the end of this financial perspective. Two, I would like to say that 85% of these additional resources represent fresh money. Redeployment is part of it, but it was needed, because you know that the resources of the Member States are limited – they are scarce – so redeployment is a legitimate part of it. But 85% of additional resources represent fresh money, and this fresh money will be used in the most pressing challenges, starting with migration, with security, with youth unemployment. And when I speak about youth unemployment, I think that is not an issue of everyday practice that the Council has in fact agreed more than the Commission has proposed, so the Council is proposing for Youth Employment initiative 20% more than the original proposal of the Commission matched with additional resources. I think we will have a good deal to fight what are the concerns of our citizens, that is, youth unemployment. Secondly, when it comes to flexibility, very quickly, we know we are living in difficult times, and we need to react swiftly to the events outside of the Union and inside the EU, and therefore I would just remind you that what the Council has agreed on is increasing the emergency aid reserve, the flexibility instrument – additional funds allocated by reshuffling of special instruments – and we increased the ceilings for global margin for payments and extended the scope for global margin for commitments to cover also the areas of migration and security. So this is just a fraction of what the flexibility and the changes to flexibility can bring if we agree on this revision. In conclusion, I dare say that this is the moment where we have to bear in mind that it is possible to agree on a package (or it was not possible to agree on the package) where everyone’s demands, requests and expectations can be met up to 100%. In politics this is rarely the case where everyone can be happy up to 100%. At the same time, I dare say, on behalf of the Presidency, when I look at the moment where we started in mid-September, and compare to where we are today, where the landing zone possibly could be, I am quite proud, because I would like to remind you that we started at the moment when the appetite to go beyond mere review in the Council and engage in a real revision which could be a result of our common effort, was very low. So I think we, all the three engaged institutions – the Commission, Parliament and the Council – can proudly present this package where the Council has found a broad agreement on its element on 15 November. And two, it is important for me to recall in this House that if you look at the package as it stands right now, I think the elements that are in there represent the maximum possible of what the European Parliament’s demands were. And this is why I hope this House at the end of the day will look at it politically – look at it as a chance for our citizens – and in fact Parliament will be able to give consent for this Multiannual Financial Framework mid-term review. I thank you for your attention and I am looking forward to your interventions.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it is indeed very satisfying that this time, when I talk about the mid-term process, I will no longer use the word ‘review’. I will talk about mid—term revision, because the proposal we have in front of us is a proposal for revision. Indeed a lot has been done – also in informal consultations with Parliament – to move us towards a place where the job of providing resources to our citizens for the remaining period is well done. I do, of course, fully recognise that there are aspects of this where Parliament does not feel completely satisfied. I realise that there will be opportunities today to debate, and perhaps to continue after today. But let me outline the key elements in this broad agreement that the Council has proposed. First, a very important element is what we would call top-ups – in other words, additional financial resources towards our top priorities. The total of these additional resources is significant – EUR 5.1 billion – of which EUR 3.9 billion is for migration and security and EUR 1.2 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative. I do recognise that, while it is below what Parliament recommended, the proposal is above the original Commission proposal, which was for EUR 1 billion. We also have to put on record that for Heading 1A the Council’s broad agreement falls behind the Commission proposal and even further behind Parliament’s proposal. The Council has requested that these top-ups be financed from redeployments within Heading 1A. We think that there should be more flexibility regarding redeployments. We accept the fact that we have to squeeze the budget for priorities, but there has to be more flexibility, and they anyway need to be decided in the course of the annual budget procedures. I think that there is some room here for a pragmatic compromise solution that fully respects the prerogatives of the budgetary authority. It is not for the Commission but for the Council, the budgetary authorities and the Parliament to decide, but there may be some space here to reach a pragmatic outcome. The second – and actually the most difficult and therefore the most valuable – part of this package is on flexibility. Why? Because any amendment of the MFF regulation requires unanimity. It requires all Members of the Council to agree. In that sense I genuinely congratulate the Slovak Presidency for guiding the Council towards that broad agreement on flexibility. What are we talking about? We are talking about sizeable increases in flexibility in terms both of commitments and payments. In very simple terms, if there is no agreement on this proposal – if it falls apart – we will have no funds available under the flexibility instrument in 2017, and that is the EUR 740 million that otherwise would be available. Secondly, over the years 2017—2020 we would have additional availabilities for special instruments amounting to a bare minimum of EUR 1.3 billion. It would definitely be more than EUR 1.3 billion. Why? Because we are calculating only one year of what is left over from the European Globalisation Fund and European Union Solidarity Fund. It is very unlikely that in the other years there would be nothing left over based on historical evidence, but we have taken a very conservative approach to count only what we are certain would be available. This is critical for us in terms of building flexibilities as, without an agreement, the possibility to use the margins left under the ceilings in the previous financial year for financing additional measures via the global margin for commitments would end next year. If we want to continue, we will have to have unanimously agreed revision. Last but not least, the Council has agreed to raise the global margin for payments available in 2019 and 2020 when we know that demand for payments will be highest by a total of EUR 6 billion at current prices. The Council has also agreed to settle in a very pragmatic and positive way the issue of the disputed EUR 350 million in payment appropriations which arose in 2014 in relation to the mobilisation of EUR 2.8 billion from the contingency margin to reduce the backlog of payments. So, from that perspective, what we see is a chance to expand flexibility that is pretty much exhausted as a result of the crises that have been pressuring us. In conclusion, we have a very valuable opportunity to revise the MFF and give us more space. It is a matter of accepting our responsibilities – all of us – to make sure that we have that space to do what is necessary. From the Commission side, we would be happy to facilitate further discussions. We believe that we have all been putting our best foot forward in terms of bringing what we believe is right and to end this calendar year knowing that in the future we have more money and more space to do what is necessary.

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! Mr. Minister! There is a fundamental difference between the previous debate and this debate. In the previous debate, we clearly emphasised that we had come to the end of a certain action together, that is, we have achieved a certain goal. During this debate, we are still in the process of investigating the target, we are still before the end, and therefore the tone of our debate is somewhat different. I would like to stress that the European Parliament, in preparing this perspective, has made clear that it will be necessary to check in the middle of the period whether it has actually been well constructed. A review needs to be done, a review, and if it becomes necessary, a review will need to be carried out. We are very pleased that despite the first negative responses to our proposals for revision, both the Commission prepared its proposal for revision, as well as the Council, the Slovak Presidency, took up this topic and agreed that the perennial perspective needs to be revised. What does it mean need to be revised? It requires change. Since it needs change, it is a matter of approach to what needs to be changed. Some essential elements have already been introduced in the 2017 budget. They have opened some action, and now we need to take a step further and actually improve or change the financial outlook for the next years in line with what we agreed in the 2017 budget. The European Parliament, we as rapporteur, we very much appreciate the efforts of the Slovak Presidency to develop a unified position in the Council on the perennial perspective and revision. We also very much appreciate the European Commission's contribution to making this proposal important, interesting and indeed acceptable. At the same time, however, I would like to say that the European Parliament is very remarkable to follow the dynamics of what is happening in the Council. We see what's happening with Italy's protest. We have information from the Italian government that the Italian government expects from the Presidency of such talks so that the revision would be more ambitious, so that the revision would actually indicate more flexibility, to greater flexibility in the following years. If that is the case, we understand that the Council's proposal is not yet ready and that work is ongoing. Today we are not yet at the stage of agreeing — or not — because we understand that the situation in the Council is still dynamic. We accept that and we enter, therefore, into this process. The European Parliament is therefore looking forward to further talks, which also coincide with talks with the Italian government. We would also like to point out that the European Parliament will definitely indicate the need to strengthen the flexibility elements, in particular to increase the flexibility of the EU budget, the flexibility instrument, the emergency aid provision, the global margin commitments and recycling of unused cancellations of obligations. On this, it looks like we agree, in part, with the expectations of the Italian government. We expect openness from the Slovak Presidency and talks that will seek to reach agreement so that we in Parliament, in accordance with the consent procedure, can finally approve or confirm our position. We expect openness of the Slovak Presidency and further talks.

name: Isabelle Thomas
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, Mr Representative of the Council, allow me to begin by joining the tribute paid by my colleagues to Vice-President Georgieva, to whom I wish well, although I am sure, I hope, that she is not quite a party. To talk about the revision, I have to go back to the 2017 budget for a moment, as my co-rapporteur colleague did. These negotiations have been rough, which always leaves me perplexed since we share most of the priorities: jobs, growth and especially youth. We have stood on course and, despite daylight saving time, we reached an acceptable agreement, notably thanks to the €500 million for youth employment and the additional EUR 200 million for growth and employment. As you have said, Mr Representative of the Council, this is for once new money and not redeployment, that is, without cutting into existing programmes but by mobilizing unused budgetary margins that are essential to meet current challenges. Parliament therefore obtained the relaunch of the European programme to combat youth unemployment, which no longer had commitment appropriations in 2016. But if we are to fight youth unemployment, we will not be content with an extension for the 2017 programme, but we must be able to make sure that this programme will be effective in the years to come. The same applies to our economic stimulus instruments. In short, the financial framework of the European Union 2014-2020, adopted in 2013, needs an ambitious revision and I welcome both the Commission and the Slovak Presidency's efforts to recognise it, and I thank you, Mr Council Representative, for agreeing to open the discussion with a view to a compromise in which no one will be 100% satisfied, nor the Parliament or the Council. The arrival of refugees, COP 21 commitments, agricultural crises, underinvestment, internal security, defence, in short, all these upheavals require it. However, we must be aware that everything we achieved in the 2017 budget is likely to be lost if we accept the Council proposal on the revision of the European Union's financial framework as it is today. I know that the Council does not yet have a unanimous position, as Mr Olbrycht said, that discussions continue, but I must insist. At the moment, the account is not there, but I am sure our discussions will be fruitful. Parliament could not accept, I do not know which annex would reduce the multiannual financial framework and further constrain the annual budgets, while we see all the additional challenges that have arisen since 2013. On the contrary, this revision must be an opportunity to increase flexibilities — as you said, I think we all share it here — so that the European budget can adapt to a changing world. To strengthen existing instruments such as the Flexibility Instrument, we are proposing €750 million a year. For the emergency aid reserve, we ask for EUR 400 million a year — you see that we are even lower than the Commission's proposal. Similarly, the European Commission had proposed that unused commitment appropriations be reinstated into the Union budget. We propose that discommitments from at least two headings be reincorporated into the budget: Heading 3 on security of citizenship and heading 4 'Europe in the world' to feed into the overall margin of commitments. On payments, serious measures must be taken against a payment crisis at the end of budget programming. The maximum ceilings for the overall margin of payments need to be increased. Accounting outside of Payment ceilings for special instruments remains debated on the table and will be a major issue at the end of the period, let us bear in mind that the current financial framework is both lower than the previous one and yet more demanded. It must therefore be fully utilized. Because, if we are talking today about the revision of the current financial framework 2014-2020, tomorrow will open debates on the forthcoming financial perspectives and I would like to recall a reality that causes many difficulties that we face: 90% of the budget the Union is based on direct contributions from the Member States. This system is inherently perverse, as it encourages each State to reduce its contribution to the Union budget as much as possible in order to keep the maximum for its national budget. The general European interest is therefore swept away in favour of national selfishness by the system itself. Worse, the overall result is a reduced budget, ultimately contrary to the interests of the Member States. This situation is not a fatality, solutions exist. These are own resources. As has been the case in the past, own resources must take a prominent place in the European budget. We are waiting for a strong proposal from the high-level group, of course, and we would be glad, if not delighted, if the Council would also issue a signal to that effect. Thank you and good discussion in the coming days!

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ECR Group. First of all, we would like to thank all those who have been involved in the development of these lines of reasoning so far. However, these arguments for revising the MFF do not shed enough light on the real requirements for the EU. The EU needs to become leaner. And anyone who works here must not conform to anyone that state programmes can permanently create jobs. Ultimately, these are all market distortions. Because we have to make a distinction: where aid is needed in the short term, of course, it can and should be provided, but the aid provided by the EU is usually started once and then continued on a permanent basis. We can't and shouldn't afford that. Nor should we take this opportunity to hide the fact that many euros are fixing problems that we would not have without the euro. That is why we should also focus on the problem of “Euro” here. Finally, I would like to thank you most sincerely, Vice-President Georgieva, for the fantastic cooperation with you. It has always been a great pleasure to see you on our Committee on Budgets. Your arguments, as well as your straightforwardness, are exemplary. Thank you very much!

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) (FR) Mr President, in this case of the multiannual financial framework, we were dealing with three key issues. First question: is there a need for a review? The European Parliament has always said yes, and it needed a firm determination to ask for it, and this was done when our House approved the good report by Mr Olbrycht and Mrs Thomas. Then we needed a good legislative proposal from the Commission and, Mrs Georgieva, you met our expectations: there was a legislative proposal from the Commission and I said, as soon as we became aware of it, that it was a good basis for discussion to reach an agreement. Then there was a need for a positive will on the part of the Council, and I must say to the Slovak Presidency that it happily surprised me. We did not expect such a positive attitude on the part of the Council to the Commission's request. Second question: do we need additional resources? Yes! The current corset is too narrow, the financial framework does not allow us to meet the urgent needs we are facing. Are there any additional means? Yes! Are they well affected? Yes! They are in line with the right priorities, both youth employment and the management of migratory pressure and security. Is that enough? I think not, and I think in particular, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, that the corset you are making for heading 1a is not wise. This is an area in which practice only through redeployment seems to me a mistake in relation to the requirements. Third question: Is there a need to improve flexibility? Yes! Is there one proposed? Yes! Is that enough? I think we can do a little better and that, in particular, the requests we made in the Olbrycht and Thomas report seemed to me more sensible than those you have withholding. I wish you good luck and good work to reach an agreement because I hope that we will do it.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – Go raibh maith agat, a Chathaoirligh. Ba mhaith liom buíochas a ghlacadh leis na rapóirtéirí as an obair atá déanta acu chuige seo.  A Choimisinéir Korčok, táthar ag moladh i mBuiséad Leasaitheach Uimh. 4 de 2016 go mbeidh ísliú de EUR 7.4 billiún ar ranníocaíochtaí ó na Ballstáit. Cuir leis seo Buiséad Leasaitheach Uimh. 5 ina mbeidh ísliú ar ranníocaíochtaí ó Ballstáit do 2017. Táthar anois tar éis airgead fíor, a raibh níos mó de ann ná an t-airgead úr seo atáthar ag tagairt dó – tá tú tar éis é sin a ghearradh. Is droch-chinneadh, drochphlean agus drochthoradh é, cosúil le Plean Junker a bhí ann chun an AE a tharrtháil – rud nár dhein caithfidh mé a rá.  Ar phointe eile, ba mhaith liom tagairt a dhéanamh d’Éirinn atá neodrach. Táimid tiomanta, agus má fhéachann tú siar ar ár stair – go háirithe ar an bpróiseas síochána – ní féidir linn tacaíocht a thabhairt don struchtúr cosanta Eorpach ar chostas coinníollacha maireachtála ár ndaoine. Is maith an rud é go bhfuil solúbthacht ann, ach gan dabht braitheann solúbthacht ar thosaíochtaí.  Caithfear leanúint ar aghaidh leis an bplé seo agus caithfear freagracht a ghlacadh agus toradh dearfach a aimsiú.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Mr Korčok, Mrs Georgieva, I think that this debate has a small defect of origin, say. We still do not have in our hands, as perhaps it would have been appropriate, the formal proposal, the proposal which should already be submitted to formal consideration and therefore to an immediate next vote. That's not yet the situation. We have your explanation, and what Mrs Georgieva has just given us, but as it was already seen coming — a little — we confirm that the mantra, that the new mantra, the new word that fixes everything, that resolves everything is 'flexibility'. “Flexibility” fits everything: new objectives; new and not so new problems; emergencies; immigration; economy; security, etc. And it is obvious that we are abusing the concept of flexibility. I sincerely believe that the Member States are once again saying 'no' to Europe. That's the evidence, at least until this moment. Of course, with the UK's abstention and still doubting what Italy's final position will be, pending more from its own referendum than from this very European debate — or which, in any case, has called for time in that regard. I sincerely believe that the Council has imposed an undue separation between the revision of the financial framework and that of the annual budgets that develop and implement it. Mrs Georgieva told us the other day, at the hottest point of conciliation: 'We must concentrate on the effort to exercise budgetary authority every year'. And it's true, I agree with that. But let us also accept that the appropriate logic would be for this exercise of budgetary authority to take place within an effectively known, agreed, shared, multi-annual forecast framework as the financial framework should be. In the proposal we know so far there is no growth in real spending ceilings. There is limited flexibility and generous use of available margins. That's it. That is why, when we now hear President Juncker, on the other hand, talk about growth, fiscal policy, the turn to start abandoning austerity, we cannot understand what seems incoherent: the counterproductive rigidity in the role of the European Union budget, which the Council's proposal still looks like, and apparently, also of the Commission. The decision should now be how we grow it from its initial dimension — now it is Horizon 2020, COSME, CEM — and not how to recover the EFSI cuts, at what rate and if we recover them all — that we do not recover them. We should be discussing how we make it grow. We should be discussing how we assume our rightful responsibility in the refugee crisis — and therefore how we add resources there. We should be discussing how we have sufficient resources for internal and external security issues. Ultimately, the contribution of the European budget as an added value to the development of the new stage of growth that Europe needs and our citizens expect. We don't have that perspective right now.

name: Marco Zanni
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the political situation that has come to be created on the revision of the multiannual financial framework represents the failure of this European Union. I have heard so many colleagues and also the Commissioner ask for new resources to combat unemployment, for growth, for small and medium-sized enterprises, to finance innovation: it is all beautiful, but for doing this serves money and today the money is not there. Member States are reluctant to give money to the European Union, for two reasons: today they are experiencing an endless economic crisis and austerity that has compressed Member States' incomes and resources and today They do not believe — as Mr Maragall said — in the European Union, that the European Union can spend this money well. It is pointless to talk about the flexibility of the multiannual financial framework and ask for more resources, when at the first opportunity the hawk, as the president of the Eurogroup did yesterday, invites exclusively to strict adherence to the rules. If we want more resources, we need to get Member States and Europe back to growth, and we know that today, the main bloc on growth, has a name and there is a responsible one. That responsible is the euro, the single currency that forces squeeze and austerity. Without the release from this constraint we are not going anywhere. We can discuss flexibility all we want, but we won't come to any results, it will be pointless. As useless as the controversy of Prime Minister Renzi, who wants to veto the multi-year financial framework. I believe that after the referendum on 4 December, if he is still the Italian prime minister, he will return to his steps and give in immediately to pressure from Juncker, Merkel and his associates. Why Renzi does not tell Italian citizens that, having voted yes to amending budget number 5, forced Italian taxpayers to pay a billion euros additional to the European budget. This situation is not sustainable and this flexibility will not help us. Long-term goals must be achieved with much more resources. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Ask about the procedure of the “blue card”. — Dear Mr Zanni! Michael Theurer is my name. You have just mentioned that the crisis is causing budgets to be overburdened. This is not clear, however, because our budgetary system is linked to gross domestic product, that is to say, to economic strength. This means that if the economic power is lower, the Member States will also pay less. Your reasoning is inconclusive! The system makes sense: everyone pays one percent, and if a country is bad, you pay less, and the better countries pay more. Are you ready to accept that this system is fair?

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: answer to a question “blue card”. — For the reason that there is a block to growth, which is represented by the rigidities of the single currency, we cannot ask for more resources or more flexibility in reviewing the multiannual financial framework. If we, as Europe, are able to return to growth policies, then the EU budget will also be able to have more resources and can invest more to solve the problems of unemployment, for make more investments, to have more resources to devote to research. But, without growth and with the rigidities of the Maastricht rules and the Stability and Growth Pact, we will not go anywhere, there will not be the resources needed to carry out these policies.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). — (EL) Mr President, the multiannual financial framework in its present form is a failed model of allocating the Union's resources over time; it is purely technocratic, rigid financially, limited flexibility and without development, mathematically leads to recession. A typical example is the mobilisation of margins for unforeseen needs of this year and next year to be voted on to address the Union's wrong policies on illegal immigration and, in view of the constraints set by the Multiannual Financial Framework, frozen funds of 2018 and 2019 from now. Does that mean prediction? Does it mean growth? Does it mean flexibility? At the same time, Erdogan blackmailed the Union with hordes of illegal immigrants and directly threatens Greece and Cyprus with invasion of their territories. Is Europe in a position to cope economically with existing tools with such a possible development? The Multiannual Financial Framework should be abolished. Its position to receive a three-year operational plan with general quotas on the important aspects of the Union's economic policy, great room for flexibility, with an emphasis on real growth, work, not just the employment of citizens and the treatment of finances imbalances between Member States. As you have understood, the structure called the European Union in the form that has mutated today is collapsing. If you want to save it, make brave decisions. Create a Europe of Nations. It is the only way out, because you will soon get an answer from Italy, France, Austria, the Netherlands.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: — Mr President, the institutions of the European Union must be credible. To be credible, they must comply with and comply with citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises, young people, researchers, regions and local authorities. We want to comply with and help the Council to comply, but to comply we cannot make reallocations. What is a reallocation? It's a cut from an assumed priority. And we, for new priorities, for new policies, must have exceptional resources. It is clear that the revision of the multiannual financial framework is an imperative that requires the institutions to unite so as not to lose credibility. The Council makes many proclamations, but it must then be consistent with the financial resources to follow up these proclamations. We can't accept that you don't go from speeches after to deeds. One thing that strikes me, and I am addressing the Council, is that I sometimes do not understand the masochistic attitude of the Council. 80% of the budget of the European Union goes to the Member States. We have an amending budget of EUR 7 300 million, in which this amount is returned. This shows poor implementation of Community funds. But then we will have to replenish that money, the Member States have to replenish those amounts. What does that mean? That we're gonna need flexibility. Flexibility in the Council's own interests, flexibility in the interests of the regions. We want something very simple: that the amounts in the budget are used and that no euro in the budget is wasted. I think this is something easy to understand. I believe that this should be shared by everyone, and so we are on the right track, the proposal on the table can be improved, and it must be improved in the interests of the institutions, in the interests of the Council itself, first of all. (The speaker agrees to answer a question “blue card” ( Article 162)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue-card question. — Mr President! Honourable Member, You were talking about flexibility. To some extent, I can agree on that. What could you do about the situation where a government in a Member State organises a systematic diversion of EU funds from common goals and gives it to its own circle of friends, such as is the case in Hungary. Moreover, European Union money is used to pay for anti-European Union propaganda.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: Answer under the blue card procedure. — European Union regulations must be complied with. The acquis communautaire must be respected. To this end, we have the European Commission which obliges, or must oblige, and other institutions, to comply with the Treaties. Then there is the principle of subsidiarity and the Member States must respect all this acquis, they must respect Community regulations and then also have the freedom to comply with their programmes, the partnership agreements, whatever the Member State.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D).
text: Mr President, Brexit, Trump, the rise of populism, Eurosceptics, Europhobes, economic crisis, refugee crisis, terrorist threat... What else has to happen for ministers sitting in the Council to raise their heads and see that the world around us has changed and that our responses are no longer valid and we need to improve them? I would like to recall a letter signed by President Juncker, President Tusk and Prime Minister Bettel in which they said: 'Making our actions correspond to our commitments is the greatest test we face and it is proof that we cannot afford to fail. ' I think we are failing at the moment, but I also think that the revision of the financial framework is an opportunity to start rectifying, to show that the Union has an ambitious present and future project, with a look at those who need our intervention and our support most; a project that can look at young people who are unemployed in the face, be an example of care and integration of refugees, be the envy of the scientific community, who leads the fight against climate change, consider culture and creators as a strategic sector and is a reference in development cooperation; a project that can return to conquer our continent. And that can only be done from politics and from budgets. Vice-President Georgieva, I would like to thank you very sincerely for your work and your commitment over the past few years, and I would like to ask you for a final contribution in your days at the head of the budget portfolio: help us to get with the Council this review that we are going to need so much.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! Having taken the floor in the debate on the review of the multiannual financial framework, I would like to welcome the compromise on this matter to the Council and express my hope that Italy will also join it after the referendal settlement next Sunday. Particular emphasis is the arrangements for the increase in expenditure in Chapters Three and Four, which gives the opportunity to strengthen the Union's actions beyond its borders in order to eliminate the causes of emigration in the countries of origin and transit, and to protect external borders more effectively than up to now Union. The Union should renege on the curiosal immigrant quotation programme, which was made in only 3% within a year, and oblige Member States to support their national budgets with EU policies to help immigrants in countries origin and transit. However, significant delays in the implementation of EU programmes are concerned, reflecting even the amending budget number four for 2016, which could lead to a new payment crisis, just as it was in the end of the previous financial outlook.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, this revision of the multiannual financial framework is unfortunately a missed opportunity. We came from a financial framework that was very unflexible, and very insufficient, above all; a framework that was not adapted to the needs of the present moment of urgency that we are experiencing and which requires new investment. In this regard, it has been decided not to do anything; nothing to provide us with more budget to deal with the social crisis. On the other hand, it had been decided to increase the outsourcing of borders in violation of international refugee asylum law, as is done with Turkey. We live in a period of urgency and exceptionality, but we have stingy accountants, unfortunately. If the challenge is to have a sufficient budgetary framework for the European Union to respond to people's needs, you are going the opposite direction. Both for the 2017 budget, which we discussed earlier, and for this financial framework, we need a 180 degree shift in budgetary policy that will enable, on the one hand, to address humanitarian and social emergencies and, on the other, a change in the productive model to address climate change.

name: Helga Trüpel (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to remind you that the Greens did not agree to the current MFF, because we said it was too unecological, it is not flexible enough, and above all because the budget has been cut for the first time in the history of the European Union; in a situation where it was clear to everyone that the European Union was actually aware that the European Union was more than must do. That's why it was clear that we definitely want a real midterm revision. Now the representative of the Slovak presidency has said: yes, there is fresh money. That's exactly what I doubt. 'Cause there's not really fresh money. Fresh money would mean being politically ready to go beyond the ceilings agreed by a majority. That's not happening right now. It is mobilized within the limits agreed by redistribution and by exploiting money up to the ceilings. But talking about really fresh money is, in my view, a misrepresentation, because that would mean having the political courage to really make a difference. I believe that we need an EU budget that is genuinely capable of tackling the causes of flight that responds to the Paris Climate Agreement — which is not the case now either — and where there is more investment in environmental transformation and also in the EU 2020 strategy. All this, however, will not be achieved with the proposals that are being discussed now. Looking at the Erasmus programme, Parliament would have liked to see that we have 200 million more by 2020, and now there are supposed to be 100 million, 50 of them next year. This means, however, that it will then be stipulated for the three years later that Parliament will not be able to negotiate anything additional each year. I think that is a wrong restriction on Parliament, and that is why I oppose this discussion stand, as we have it now. One final comment: it was clear from the outset that if we need a new model, we really need new own resources, such as the financial transaction tax, environmental taxes, carbon tax or diesel tax. So far, there is no signal from the Council that we are genuinely capable and prepared to undertake such a reform. Only then, I think, can we speak of a real revision when there is a real political movement in all these fields. I'm sorry, I don't see that right now.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: — Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, I am very sorry that you are leaving, thank you very much for what you have done so far, and I hope that by the end of the year you will do something more. Thank you for this proposal for rectification, not revision, it is very important. President of the Council, thank you for your effort, the first step taken so far, but I think you still need to work to reach an even better solution. Member States committed three years ago to spend a figure, an amount of more than 900 billion. This money must be spent in full. For this we need flexibility and we need a few things proposed by the Commissioner, but which are not yet accepted by the Council. We need the decommissioned money to remain in the budget because it is employed by the Member States, so it must remain in the budget and be used for urgent matters. We need flexibility, again, it is extremely important. We need the money to remain in the budget so that we do not get back to the situation we were in two years ago, having no money to pay for European policies. It is inadmissible, two weeks ago we approved the budget for Member States to receive more than EUR 8 billion this year and, at the same time, negotiate for 50 million. So, Commissioner, please continue to work so that your proposal for rectification is fully accepted by the Council. Thank you very much.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D).
text: — We live in a period with historically the greatest need for resources. If there is no economic growth, if people are not employed, they are not going to shop, there will be no inflation, and debts will rise. The Council and the European Parliament adopted a binding strategy. This leads to high-value-added investments that will bring about growth and employment. However, the resources for implementing this strategy are limited. We therefore need to create a smart budget that will provide the European Union with its own resources to achieve its objectives, but also reduce the contribution of states to the budget of the European Union. Monti's high-level group is working on the proposal. Until this happens, the key elements of the revision of the multiannual financial framework must be maximum flexibility, additional resources, resource efficiency and timely payments. Any surplus resulting from underimplementation of the European Union budget or penalties should remain in the budget of the European Union — without adjusting the contributions of countries.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: — Mr. President, Commissioners Georgiev congratulate you on the quality work in the European Commission and wish good luck in the future work. In terms of the IMF review, what I have to emphasize in particular is that it is not simple to predict all the circumstances that are going to happen and that's why we need to have flexibility. With this review, we show that we have flexibility for what is happening to us — from migration, through youth unemployment, the agriculture crisis, to lack of investment, investment in research and development, into startups — that's all we have to respond to. However, we must take care of the nature of individual policies. The fact is that cohesion policy contracts much more in the early years, and only later a lot more is paid and we should not jeopardize the future payments needed for cohesion policy. That is why we must always place the multiannual framework in the context of the nature of a particular policy funded by the EU budget.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report adopted by this Parliament last July in relation to the annual review of the Multiannual Financial Framework required higher appropriations for respond adequately to the challenges ahead of Europe. Despite the failure to meet this request, the proposal for a revision of the multiannual financial framework is still going in the right direction. The forecast of additional resources from budget reserves for investments to support growth and employment and to deal with the migration crisis, is certainly a novelty to be assessed positively. However, a solution must be found to the problem of payments: the backlog of unpaid invoices during the previous multiannual financial framework has risen from €5 billion in 2010 to the end of 23 billion euros 2013. This backlog has already extended to the current multiannual financial framework as well. We must do everything possible to avoid further accumulation, with reference to the current programming.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, the financial framework is essentially a narrow corset of violent fiscal adjustment that serves mercelic austerity. What we as the European Union urgently need is policy change: boosting growth, creating jobs, investing in education, training and new technologies. It is only in this way that we can tackle the enormous unemployment among young people and, of course, provide funds for the refugee crisis. That is what I referred to in my previous speech. The second thing that is required is for this policy to be put at the service of the Europe of the peoples, the Europe of the nations and the Europe of the homelands. The third is to put it at the service of social Europe and the fair distribution of the wealth produced, and finally the multiannual financial framework must be a flexible tool and, in fact, transformed and replaced, I would say, with a strategic production plan. reconstruction of the European Union.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, during this debate our rapporteurs, Mrs Thomas and Mr Olbrycht, have said the essentials and all our colleagues who have spoken. I would like to make a specific appeal for young people and youth employment. I note that young people who have benefited from Erasmus scholarships, that these students protect themselves better against the risk of unemployment than others. I also note that young people who have been trained in apprenticeship in Germany, Austria and the Netherlands do not experience unemployment. That is why I would like us to be able to develop mobility for apprentices, but this assumes that we have more substantial credits for Erasmus. I therefore allow myself on Christmas Eve to launch a specific call for the Erasmus envelope to be re-evaluated again. It is increasing by 20% in the 2017 budget, which we will vote tomorrow, but I believe that we must go beyond, Madam Vice-President, Minister.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: — The rectification of the multiannual financial framework must be carried out in line with the expectations of European citizens, who really want a Europe more involved in improving the quality and living conditions throughout the Member States. This means maintaining the funds earmarked for cohesion policy, supporting young people's policies with additional funds and increasing the budget for contingencies arising from the crisis. And, in order to respond to a British Eurosceptic MEP who spoke earlier, I am also referring to the decrease in the rate of the pound sterling, which has produced serious effects for British citizens and the European Union. To this end, we need to integrate into the mechanisms of the multiannual financial framework a number of general principles, such as support for underdeveloped areas, financing policies for disadvantaged groups and categories, budgeting as expected by European actions and programmes in areas such as education or health. The multiannual financial framework must put the citizen at the forefront. Thank you.

name: El Presidente. –
text: It is now the turn of Mrs Georgieva, but she will allow me, Mrs Georgieva, to join the words of appreciation and appreciation for her brilliant work. I do not know whether or not this is very correct — to do it right now, from this place — but I think that, above the protocols, there is precisely respect for a work and an extraordinary person like yourself. Thank you for everything. (End of interventions under the “catch the eye” procedure)

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I am deeply touched. We do have a critical task to complete. I heard many voices expressing the wish that it is completed before the end of this year. This is very wise, because we do need to be able to predict how we are going to approach the remaining time of this multi—year financial perspective, and we do need to have the certainty for funds that are going to be absolutely essential for our work to be done. Just to give you one example: we have agreed that it is critical for the European Union to better protect its external borders. For that reason we have proposed the creation of a new agency, the Border and Coast Guard Agency. When we look into the future of implementation, we of course count on having the space to fund it, not only in 2017 – for which we do now have the money – but also in 2018, 2019 and 2020. Or when we think about how critical it is to address the needs of young people to have jobs and to be able to benefit from education, it is not good enough to know that we have boosted these funds for 2017. We do need predictability for 2018, 2019 and 2020. So, in that sense, reaching an agreement that allows us to provide these funds in the future so that the money will be there for multi—year programmes of that significance, I believe in my heart of hearts means that we have to find a space for an agreement that allows us to have this predictability. Secondly, I agree with those who said that we cannot resolve everything with flexibility. That is very true but, if we have more flexibility in the budget, we can respond when unexpected events occur. I would remind us all that we have generated three times more money to deal with migration and refugees inside Europe and in their countries of origin because of the flexibility that Parliament demanded as part of the agreement for the MFF. But we are now coming close to exhausting the reserves we have had in terms of flexibility. Therefore we ought to build more and expand it further. Third, is this really fresh money? Yes it is, because we are taking money from the margins and we are allocating it predictably. You might say that the margins are part of the MFF. Yes and no because, if we do not make a commitment and if we do not expand the global margin for commitment and make it available in future years, there will be no commitments to demand further payments from the budget. In fact EUR 5.1 billion extra is EUR 5.1 billion extra. It would have not been there without that revision. Is it true that we are facing more demands than we have resources? Yes; since 2012, every year we have been struggling to cope with the demands on the EU budget. However, we also need to be honest with ourselves. Unanimity is required to go above the ceilings, and this unanimity is not being met. It is quite simply not there. Should we continue – and I look at the Parliament – to advocate for the needs of European programmes? Yes. Maybe that moment will come when this unanimity to go above and beyond the ceilings is there, but it is not there today. If we do not tell ourselves the truth, we will not be able to do what we are here for, namely to serve our people. It is as simple as that: to make sure that everything is done to get the resources to them in a predictable and secure manner. Do I have regrets? Yes. I thought we had come up with a very good proposal to create a crisis reserve using the commitments. We put it forward, we lobbied for it and we argued for it, but neither net payers nor net recipients liked it. They didn’t like it. They didn’t accept it – and, yes, I am looking at Mrs Thomas, who wants to have a second bite of this particular apple, bon appétit, hein? But I think, if I am to respond to what people have been saying, that we should continue to work – of course we will continue to work. The work is done only when it is done. I think, with goodwill and determination, the work will be done. We will play our part as sincerely as we have been doing up to now.

name: El Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mrs. Georgieva. We wish him the best.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first I would like to thank you sincerely for the words of recognition for our work – the work of the Slovak Presidency – and reciprocate by repeating my thanks for the excellent cooperation we have had with you during our meetings on this very important file. I shall try to once again reiterate what I said at the beginning, and I feel confirmed, after having listened to you, that the package that the Council has agreed on is a good package, and the question, I dare say, now is not whether the Council is ready to accept 100% of what Parliament would like to see there, but the question is whether with this package we are better off than we would be without it. And I dare say if you look at the elements that are already in there, with additional money mobilised and with increased flexibility, I dare say the EU and its citizens will be better off. I know too, distinguished Members of the House, that you would like to see more, but this does not mean that the Council is less concerned about the challenges and the circumstances that are challenging us every day. It is not the case that the Council is less concerned. The question is whether we can land at a compromise which would be acceptable to all of us. I have to say as well, however, that it is very difficult for me to hear that additional resources and flexibilities are hot air. This is not hot air: this is exactly the opposite. This is something that we can have in addition to what was agreed back in 2013. I have to say, too, that I totally agree with Vice-President Georgieva when she explained why this is fresh money. Frau Trüpel, ich glaube, man kann nicht sagen, dass es sich nicht um frisches Geld handelt. Die Begründung, die wir von Frau Georgieva gehört haben, ist eine ganz exakte Begründung. Und zusätzlich möchte ich noch sagen: Wissen Sie, warum das frisches Geld ist? Es muss zusätzlich zu dem transferiert werden, was wir 2013 verabschiedet haben. Es muss von den Steuerzahlern aus den Mitgliedstaaten zusätzlich transferiert werden. Deshalb denke ich, kann man nicht sagen, dass es sich hier trotz der Tatsache, dass es sich innerhalb der Obergrenze bewegt, um nicht frisches Geld handelt. Denn wir könnten auch kein Geld haben. Deswegen ist es wichtig, dass wir das ganz realistisch sehen.  And finally, I have been listening very carefully to this debate, and I have to recognise that there is an expectation and there is a demand here to continue our exchange. However, I have to say, fairly, that I see very limited space, if any, for further amendments or changes to what the Council has agreed on the 16th. But after having four meetings with you, Mr President, with Madam Thomas and Mr Olbrycht, I see no obstacle to having another one on a political level before the Council sends a formal request for consent to this House. I think this will only confirm that both the Presidency and the Council are ready to listen, so I say: why don’t we meet again in the days to come? But I would like to invite you to remain realistic when it comes to the possibilities of further improving the deal, because I would like to say that what we are offering is a good deal for our citizens. So Mr President, Madam Vice-President, I am not saying goodbye just yet to you Kristalina, we will have further opportunities, but I would like once again to thank you all for your cooperation so far – and let’s work on getting a good deal.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. — The economic crisis, the rise of populism, refugee crisis, terrorist threat, Brexit,... The world around us has changed and the Union needs to respond to these challenges. The review of the financial framework is an opportunity to show that the Union has an ambitious present and future project, with a focus on those who need it most. And that can only be done from politics and from budgets. The European Union financial framework 2014-2020, approved in 2013, needs ambitious revision. It is time to put “fresh money” on the table instead of redistribution, that is, not to cut existing programs. This review should provide an opportunity to increase flexibility so that the Union's budget can adapt to a changing world.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The economic crisis, the rise of populism, refugee crisis, terrorist threat, Brexit... The world around us has changed and the Union needs to respond to these challenges. The review of the financial framework is an opportunity to show that the Union has an ambitious present and future project, with a focus on those who need it most. And that can only be done from politics and from budgets. The European Union financial framework 2014-2020, approved in 2013, needs ambitious revision. It's time to put “fresh money” on the table instead of cutting and redistributing existing programs. This review should provide an opportunity to increase flexibility so that the Union's budget can adapt to a changing world.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. — The paradox is that at present in the European Union, the most developed continent, more than one in four children live in poverty, and in many countries children are at greater risk of poverty than adults. I am therefore convinced that we need new concrete measures, as proposed by our Social Democratic Group. We urge the Commission and the Member States to create a Child Guarantee that allows every child to receive free health and childcare, education, decent accommodation and proper nutrition services. In order to be able to reduce child poverty, we need to create a special EU budget for this, because without money we will not be able to do anything. We now have different measures to reduce child poverty, but they are not harmonised, and most often money from funds is allocated to other areas, and there is simply no money left for investment in children. Therefore, once again, I call on the Commission to allocate a special fund to finance the Child Guarantee when reviewing the Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020). Unfortunately, without the financial resources (the budget), we will not be able to do anything: we will not be able to contribute to reducing child poverty. In addition, the fight against child poverty should be foreseen as a priority in national budgets.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The presentation of the multiannual financial framework has undoubtedly shown that there is a new mantra: that of flexibility. A flexibility that has been justified by the need to react promptly to events or to have “the space necessary to do what we need to do.” But what will be done in the three-year period 2017-2020 to meet the needs of European citizens? What will be done for employment, for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, for welfare, for a sustainable future? Or do we rather ask how much waste will still be there, starting from the three seats of the European Parliament, for example? In the courtroom we also heard once again justify flexibility, as well as increasing resources, as necessary steps to intervene on emergencies such as immigration and security. So, since Erdogan has been in power, Europe has already transferred or promised to allocate 36.6 billion euros to Turkey. Other than emergencies: here, under the excuse of the refugee crisis, a dictatorship is being funded! Finally, we should not forget a contradiction in the terms, since the Council and the Commission speak of flexibility, when the Member States are imposed the chains of austerity and the rigour of Stability and growth pact.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. — Economic crisis, the rise of populism, refugee crisis, terrorist threat, Brexit... The world around us has changed and the Union needs to respond to these challenges. The review of the financial framework is an opportunity to show that the Union has an ambitious present and future project, with a focus on those who need it most. And that can only be done from politics and from budgets. The European Union financial framework 2014-2020, approved in 2013, needs ambitious revision. It is time to put “fresh money” on the table instead of redistribution, that is, not to cut existing programs. This review should provide an opportunity to increase flexibility so that the Union's budget can adapt to a changing world.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. — The occasion of the review of the multiannual financial framework, which to so many may seem like bureaucratic technicality as we see many in Brussels, is actually a key moment. It is a question of deciding where to invest the essential resources we have in this phase of economic and social crisis. Unfortunately, the Council chose not to introduce new funds, but to transfer resources with an operation that masks no longer sustainable budget cuts. The proposal presented by the institutions does not satisfy us either as Italian MEPs or even as members of the Social Democratic Group. We cannot accept the immobilism and rigidity which are leading to the collapse of the project of European cohesion and solidarity. Together we call for more investment where there is more need, in areas where Europe's role can do much better to put growth, jobs and flexibility at the heart of our work. immigration, security and support for young people at a critical time for the labour market. name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Recommendation by the Committee on International Trade on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement between Ghana, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part (12396/2016 - C8-0406/2016 - 2008/0137 (NLE)) (Rapporteur: Christofer Fjellner) (A8-0328/2016).

name: Christofer Fjellner
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, this trade deal with Ghana is very important. It is especially important for Ghana. In 2015, Ghanaian exports to the European Union accounted for EUR 2.4 billion. 46% of Ghana’s exports was to the European Union. The consequences of voting ‘no’ to this agreement, of not ratifying this agreement, would be dramatic for Ghana. They would face a wall of EU tariffs. Even though the average tariff for Ghana would be around 8.13% – it might not sound much but it is a prohibitive tariff level; for many products in areas where Ghana has a lot of exports, the tariffs are even higher. For bananas, for example, they would have most favoured nation duties of 19.7%, and for prepared tuna 20.7%. The consequences of saying ‘no’ to this would be dramatic for Ghana. And why would they face this wall of tariffs? The answer is simple: because the current trade regime the EU has with Ghana – the Market Access Regulation – is running out in 2016. That is the reason why we have to take this decision now. And then one might ask: why does the current regime run out in 2016? The answer to that is actually pretty simple: it is because we in this House decided so. With a broad majority. I remember negotiating with my good friend and colleague David Martin, on specifically that date, to say that this existing trade regime should run out in 2016. But the thing with this trade agreement is that it is actually a pretty good agreement. It is a good agreement that we present instead of the current regime. Ghana will get duty-free access to the European Union from day one. 75% of Ghanaian tariff lines will be liberalised, yes, but they will be liberalised over 15 years. People talk about the fact that we need to have asymmetrical agreements, taking into account that they do not have the same level of development in many areas and competitiveness. I would say if this is not asymmetrical, taking that into account, I cannot imagine what would be. They get free access: from day one, 75% of their lines will be liberalised, but over 15 years. It is worth repeating. And the tariffs removed in Ghana are mainly things like industrial machines, pumps, generators, turbines, certain vehicles, boats, aircraft, cars, certain chemicals – all of those are used as input to Ghanaian industries and not produced locally. Eliminating import duties on these products will reduce the cost of imports for local businesses and increase their competitiveness. What we didn’t liberalise is mainly agriculture, the sensitive stuff, things like chicken and other meat, tomatoes, onions, sugar, tobacco, beer, clothes, wheat, frozen fish, some industrial things like industrial plastics. We did take their needs into account. And there are safeguards in this agreement to protect the Ghanaian side. But not only that. The reason I speak about Ghana now and what this means to Ghana is no serious actors have questioned that this will have any serious implications on the European Union and our trade policy. Those who are criticising say it is bad for Ghana, but we should let Ghana decide what is good or bad for Ghana, and Ghana is a democracy. The government and parliament have with broad majority supported this, and why should we then reject it? Let me therefore finish by quoting the Minister of Foreign Affairs from Ghana, Hanna Tetteh, in her letter to the Committee on International Trade, where she says: ‘We believe, when it comes to determine the matter of what is in our best national interest, we, as elected representatives of the people of Ghana, the Parliament of the Republic of Ghana, have both the legitimacy and the mandate to make that determination, and not to any other third party, irrespective of however well intended such third party decisions might be’. Don’t act as new imperialists here. Listen and respect the people of Ghana, and let them decide if it is good for them.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the work they have been doing. This is actually the third time this year that I have had the opportunity to discuss with you in plenary the agenda of our Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) with Africa. I came in February, we had a debate on an oral question on the sustainable development provisions of the EU—West Africa EPA and we had a good debate in December on the SADC EPA, following which you gave your assent, so that has now entered into force and I thank you for that. We are now working with our friends in SADC countries with great enthusiasm to put that into practice and to make it to function as intended.  Throughout Africa we are moving to the implementation phase as more and more African parliaments are giving their ratification to the EPAs. The Trade for All communication recognised that fulfilling the promise of these agreements will be a major deliverable for the next few years. It is now for us and our partners to fully use trade as a tool for growth, sustainable development and employment.  In West Africa a large majority of countries have signed the regional EPA which, as you know, ultimately intends to foster and strengthen the regional integration process in that part of Africa. We are committed to the conclusion of that EPA together with the regional organisation. But, while that process is ongoing, Ghana and Côte d’Ivoire decided to keep up their economic development by preserving their access to the EU market.  They did so by reviving the best option available at the moment, an interim bilateral EPA. The interim EPA with Ghana remains compatible with our objective of achieving a regional EPA which will, of course, ultimately replace this one. We are continuing to work hard to get a West Africa EPA in place for the near future but today let us focus on the one we have on the table with Ghana. It is a self—standing, WTO—compatible trade agreement of unlimited duration. It immediately guarantees Ghana’s exporters duty—free, quota—free access to the EU market. The agreement protects local development through safeguard clauses and a limited and gradual liberalisation focusing on equipment and inputs. Many provisions deal with support for Ghanaian producers to meet EU standards, which is, of course, good for farmers and for the transformation of agricultural products. The EPA also contains cooperation provisions to accompany Ghana during the implementation of the agreement. I would also like to highlight that the EPA is anchored in the provisions of the Cotonou Agreement. This includes the essential elements and sustainable development objectives, its provisions on labour, environment, democratic principles and human rights. This is very important to remember.  When I came here in February – I think it was in Strasbourg actually – I committed to having sustainable development as a strong element of the implementation of all our EPAs. It is true that this bilateral EPA with Ghana has been negotiated with 2018 in view and it does not contain a sustainable development chapter on top of what we have in the Cotonou Agreement. But it is linked to the Cotonou Agreement and this does not mean that we are not active in this area.  We are committed to engaging in a dialogue on sustainable development in the EPA Joint Committee that will be created by this Agreement. The same goes for involving civil society. There are provisions in the EPA that give us a hook for putting this into place. For example it is foreseen that civil society organisations can participate as observers in the EPA Joint Committee, and I can guarantee you that Ghana is very committed to doing this. Ghana is one of the thriving democracies in the region. They have a well—developed civil society in place. That is not always the case in the region, but in Ghana it is. The Foreign Affairs Minister, Hanna Tetteh, made it clear when she came to the Committee on International Trade and she said to you – and I spoke to her as well – that they have already started to engage civil society and they are committed to sustainable development at the highest level. This is about companies and about people. A substantial part of Ghana’s trade is done with the EU. Ghana’s exports to the EU amounted to EUR 2.6 billion last year. On cocoa and bananas they are heavily dependent on us, and non-traditional exports, such as processed tuna, depend on the EU market even more. Those exports contribute to building local value chains which involve SMEs and create jobs, directly and indirectly. So this provides a solid environment for local and foreign investors, which should not be underestimated because when European investors settle in Ghana, they increase the share of formal employment, which ensures more protection for Ghanaian workers as well.  Finally, I believe that the successful implementation of the EPAs with Ghana, Côte d’Ivoire and other African countries will be the best proof that our trade responds to the many challenges faced with our partners. It is also the best way to convince remaining partners to opt for the regional EPA, demonstrating on the ground the benefits of deepening trade relationships with us. I hope there will be strong support for this when you vote on it tomorrow in the plenary.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his great work and I would like to support his recommendation to give consent to this agreement, which opens up the door to its provisional application. West Africa is our largest trade partner in sub-Saharan Africa. At the same time, the European Union contributes to economic growth and development in the region and is the main export market for West African agriculture and fisheries products.  The deal on the Stepping Stone Economic Partnership Agreement with Ghana and Ivory Coast ensures a contractual safety net warranting a duty-free quota, free access to the EU market, and asymmetric gradual opening of Ghana’s market to EU goods until the regional agreement comes into force. Moreover, the interim agreement includes provisions on development cooperation, trade defence and trade facilitation measures including sanitary and phytosanitary measures.  Furthermore I wish to call for swift implementation of this economic partnership agreement. If it comes into place without excessive delay, any discrepancies in tariff liberalisation schedules and tariff lines would be solved without any need for additional adaptation to the regional processes, which is highly advisable.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, in the words of our rapporteur Christofer Fjellner’s draft report, this agreement with Ghana is incomplete and outdated. We are only compelled to consider it because the Commission has failed to deliver a sustainable strategy for West Africa. To build a real economic partnership with Ghana and the rest of West Africa, we need far more than traditional trade liberalisation and old-fashioned power politics. The content of this agreement is poor, the methods employed to conclude it are far worse.  We have a duty to be coherent with our global sustainable development goals, and this agreement is not about value-based trade. On the contrary, it undermines our values by not even mentioning them in the core of the agreement. Finally, there are alternatives available to ensure market access for Ghanaian exporters, and no reason for us to rush through an interim solution, which could become very quickly a permanent bad deal for the EU and Ghana. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Christofer Fjellner
text: rapporteur, blue-card question. –   Ms Kirton-Darling, if you are to quote me and my report would you be so kind as to quote me correctly the next time, and not only say that I think this agreement is insufficient, but that it is insufficient compared to the final general regional Economic Partnership Agreement. Because if you cut me like that, you actually lie.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I quoted directly from the draft report which was tabled in the Committee on International Trade (INTA). We are talking about the EU-Ghana Interim Economic Partnership Agreement and not about the Regional Economic Partnership Agreement, and those were your words in relation to the Interim Economic Partnership Agreement.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Commissioner, you know that I recognise many positive aspects of your revised trade strategy, particularly as regards the higher priority of fair trade and the enforceability of binding sustainability chapters. However, the text of this old EPA, an interim EPA with Ghana, is an ancient ghost. We prohibit the country on export taxes on unprocessed raw materials. Why? West Africa agreed on joint external duties on 1 January 2015. However, this old EPA has different values. Where is our respect for regional integration? After Brexit, EU imports from Ghana would be down 32%. How do we compensate for this? Ghana was forced to sign an agreement that no longer corresponds to European and African modern interests. We need to make proposals for answers to perspective issues of the third and fourth decade of our century today — in the interests of the people of Ghana, Africa and the EU. My group will therefore reject this old non-regional EPA tomorrow.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (DE) Madam President. The development of Ghana is certainly to be welcomed, and the opening of Ghana's market to 83 percent with the forthcoming trade agreement also sounds positive at first. However, this will lead to the flooding of Ghana with European products and thus to a stronger dependence on the European market. For example, despite low wage levels in Ghana, after eight weeks of breeding on a farm, a chicken costs 3.60 euros, which means that a Ghanaian chicken is about 100 percent more expensive than a low-cost chicken from the Union. What will that mean? It will be impossible for Ghana's breeders and farmers to compete with these import prices. They'll destroy the livelihood. And what will continue to happen? People will make their way to Central Europe, where with a minimum income, with a minimum guarantee of 800 euros, the chickens will no longer be bought on the market in Accra, but in the supermarket in Berlin or in Vienna.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: —The Economic Partnership Agreement, which we are talking about today, but in broader terms also trade agreements, free trade, services, investment, these are examples of how well-developed countries — rich countries such as the Member States of the European Union — can cooperate with other poorer countries, not only economically, economically, not only to forge these kinds of agreements to increase trade, but also to support the development of their partners. Ghana, like many other countries, is a country particularly deserving of the support of the European Union. It is one of the best functioning countries in Africa, not only economically but socially, respectful — when it comes to the African context — civil society, caring for the principles of democracy. I hope we will see this soon too, during the elections in this state.
