The agreement we are talking about is certainly not an ideal, because it is a definite solution, moreover, but if we take it and implement it, it will certainly be a good part of cooperation between the European Union and Ghana, and in the future West Africa.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, while I of course acknowledge that the interim EPA does not fully meet my Group’s requirements for a free trade agreement – especially given the absence of a trade and sustainable development chapter – as we have just heard, we should remind ourselves that we are talking about Ghana: a vibrant, constitutional democracy, committed to implementing the UN Sustainable Development Goals, sadly almost an exception in Africa. Plus, this is only an interim EPA which will be applied until the regional one, ECOWAS, comes into force. This is an agreement that the Ghanaian Government and Parliament strongly want, as they believe it is good for their people. In fact, it was ratified unanimously by the 275 Ghanaian MPs, so who are we to say this is not good for them?  The current preferential trade regime MAR is not WTO-compatible and will cease to apply sooner or later. Ghana needs a more stable framework to attract and maintain foreign investment. Ghana does not want to keep the uncertain MAR preferences, does not want to apply for the less-favourable GSP+; they want this agreement, and we should respect their choice. I want to stand by the Ghanaian people, and therefore I will vote for this agreement.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I share the European Union's trade strategy to help countries in economic difficulty. The Free Trade Agreement with Ghana will allow the African state to have access to the European market and the stability needed for new investment and job creation. However, the substantial inadequacy of the activation of an agreement concluded in 2007, should be noted, compared to the changed current conditions. The absence of a regional dimension and rules on origin, as well as an incomplete institutional framework, make this agreement a fallback solution, waiting to define the partnership with the whole West African region. And precisely in view of this partnership, I would like to emphasise the importance of introducing safeguard measures, which will allow the reinstatment of duties if an increase in imports threatens to disrupt the economy of a sector, such as fruit and vegetables, too often sacrificed by agreements concluded with African countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: (ECR). — (EL) Madam President, another trade liberalisation agreement with an African country, which means dismantling the farmers of the European South and, of course, strengthening the industries in the North of Europe, which will export products. The report also states that Ghana exports mainly fruit and fish. Secondly, there is child labour in Ghana, particularly in the areas of agriculture. But what does Ghana import? Ships, vehicles, therefore products which concern the countries of the North which export. From then on, 35% of European exports to Ghana have already been liberalised. This is the real situation. What if European farmers want to export to Ghana? Then, as the report says, Ghana can exclude certain sensitive agricultural products. Finally, there should also be arrangements for immigration in such conventions and for these countries to commit themselves to immigration, because thousands of their nationals come to Europe.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: — Madam President, the Ghana agreement before us today was concluded in 2007 and it was signed only nine years later. Why this time is so long? Because negotiations, which are regional negotiations, have taken place. These regional negotiations include a major country, Nigeria, which is the largest economic power. Today, while we should put all our energy to move towards this regional agreement, you choose to give preference to interim bilateral agreements such as the one with Ghana. These interim agreements, Jude Kirton-Darling, said, are outdated agreements. So, rather than putting our energy into outdated agreements, as presented to us today, I plead that we do not vote for this interim agreement and work to ensure that the regional agreement can succeed. Let us put our energy into this regional agreement, rather than kill it by an interim agreement.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Honourable Members for this debate. I believe that this interim agreement has the potential to provide growth, stability and development for Ghana. Let us be honest, this is not something that will be of major importance to make the European economy grow. We are not doing this for the European economy. It will have marginal effects on the European economy. We are doing this to support the development, the diversification of the industry and the stability of a country like Ghana, a rare democracy in a region where that is not always the case. Ghana’s commitment to the regional EPA is very strong. They want to integrate and to develop in a transparent manner. As the Foreign Minister, who we have been quoting here today, said in the letter to you, she is very committed to making this happen, and she has already started to work with the civil society organisations and will continue to jointly work with them.  There are indeed alternative options to the EPA that have been voiced, but they are not realistic. They do not provide the same advantages to Ghana as the EPA does. Some of them are not even WTO-compatible. But this agreement is something that Ghana wants. They have chosen it and they have decided on it in a parliamentary vote by their democratically elected Parliament. I am sure you have also read the letter where the Foreign Minister, Ms Tetteh, explains this very clearly.  It is true that we are working on a regional agreement but, as you know, there are some countries blocking this. Why should Ghana be blocked while we are waiting for this to happen? It will happen someday. We are working very hard on it, but we should not punish a country which wants to cooperate with us, which wants to be a close ally and which has chosen this path. The regional EPA is a way to overcome the challenges regionally. We are working on this. It is of course up to West Africa to decide about the future, but for the moment that agreement is not available. So let us work together for a successful interim bilateral EPA with an important country which wants to engage with us and, at the same time, continue our advocacy, together with the West African regional organisation, for a regional EPA. Thank you very much for your commitment here and, by the way, Mr Obermayr, chickens are not liberalised in this agreement. Thank you very much for your engagement in this.

name: Christofer Fjellner
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I entered the plenary of the European Parliament, but listening to some colleagues from the S&D on my left, it sounds as if they wish to be members of the Ghanaian parliament instead, as they want to vote against it because they think it’s bad for Ghana. Didn’t you hear the democratically elected Foreign Minister of Ghana saying they think it is good and they want it? Don’t you think that they’re legitimate when taking that decision, or don’t you think they really understand it? Because it has to be one of those two. And if you win, if you manage to kill this trade agreement, forcing them to meet the tariff wall of the European Union, how can you explain to the poor farmers of Ghana that you thought you were in a better position than their elected representatives to actually choose the destiny of their future? Will you be able to look at yourselves in the mirror after doing that?

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 1 December 2016.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Jan Philipp Albrecht, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information relating to the prevention, investigation, detection, and prosecution of criminal offenses (08523/2016 – C8—0329/2016 – 2016/0126(NLE)) (A8—0354/2016).

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, this is a historical breakthrough. For the first time in history, the United States of America are entering into a binding international agreement on data protection standards. This House has asked for such an agreement between the EU and the United States for years and, finally, we will have it.  So what is the agreement about? First, it establishes a comprehensive framework of data protection principles, safeguards and rights when personal data is transferred for criminal law enforcement purposes between the EU and the USA. Those protection standards do not only apply when law enforcement authorities exchange information, but also when private entities transfer data to law enforcement authorities, for example European airlines to the US Department of Homeland Security under the PNR Agreement. Second, this framework does not only cover EU-US agreements, but also bilateral data transfer agreements between the EU Member States and the United States. This is a huge success, which has not been clear from the beginning because Member States resisted the inclusion of bilateral deals. It was finally included because the European Parliament consistently asked for it as one of the conditions for giving consent to such an agreement. The agreement establishes a right to judicial redress for EU citizens before US courts should they think their rights under this agreement have not been respected. It was again the heavy pressure from the European Parliament which in the end made it clear that the US needs to open up their judicial redress avenues to EU citizens in order to restore mutual trust. Earlier this year, the US Congress amended the Privacy Act in order to do this. I am not sure how often it has happened in history that the US Congress, which had a hard time agreeing on anything in recent years, has changed US law because we have asked them to do so.  It is also important to clarify what the agreement is not about. The Umbrella Agreement is not a data transfer agreement. Article 1 clearly specifies that the agreement cannot be a legal base for any transfer of personal data, and that a separate legal base shall always be required. The Umbrella Agreement does not limit any individual rights. On the contrary, it increases the level of data protection where data are being transferred already today. We have now made it crystal clear that if the US side restricts rights under this agreement, the EU authorities can consider that the USA is not delivering sufficient safeguards for data protection enshrined in the agreement and suspend data transfers. This is all clarified now in the Commission’s declaration to the agreement, which I share and which will be published together with the agreement, so it will guide any legal interpretation. The uncertainty of the incoming Trump administration is just one more reason to conclude the agreement while President Obama still in office. If we conclude this agreement, the United States will be bound by international law, which gives unconditional data protection rights.  There are motions on the table to refer the agreement to the Court of Justice, and even though I am convinced – after intense discussions with our Legal Service, the Commission, data protection authorities, and other experts – that the agreement is good enough and fully complies with EU law, I have no problem voting in favour of this request if doubts remain with some of the Groups. But let me be clear: this agreement is a huge step forward for fundamental rights and, in particular, for the right to data protection in times when data exchange is key for effective law enforcement cooperation between the EU, its Member States, and other partners in the world. With the Umbrella Agreement, we will restore trust in the effective protection of personal data as a precondition for better law enforcement information exchange. Thank you very much.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Umbrella Agreement on which you are asked to cast your vote tomorrow is of great importance for the protection of all Europeans whenever their personal data are transferred to the United States for law enforcement purposes. It is with this in mind that I ask you for your consent to the Agreement so as to allow its conclusion under the current US administration. Let me briefly recall what the Umbrella Agreement is about and what type of immediate benefits it will bring to Europeans. First – and this is unprecedented, not only in the trans-Atlantic context, but also more generally at international level – for the first time we will have a genuine data protection agreement in the field of law enforcement cooperation. By that, I mean not an agreement that authorises transfers, but instead an agreement that focuses exclusively on data protection safeguards and the rights of individuals, an agreement that contains the same type of catalogue of principles, safeguards and rights that we have in our data protection legislation. These include purpose limitation, restrictions on onward transfers, the right to access and rectification, administrative and judicial redress, and independent oversight. In assessing the value of the Umbrella Agreement, let us also recall the current situation and what the status quo would mean. As we speak, data is being shared between EU Member States and US law enforcement authorities. These exchanges are taking place on the basis of legal instruments, in particular bilateral agreements that very often lack basic privacy safeguards or contain only limited protections. As we know, these transfers will continue to take place and are likely to intensify, notably in response to terrorism threats. The Umbrella Agreement addresses this serious deficit of protection. With its entry into force, all these transfers will benefit from the additional safeguards and rights provided by the Umbrella. In other words, this is an agreement that will bring immediate and very substantial improvements to the situation of the EU data subjects. In doing so, the Umbrella Agreement will also remedy the current imbalance of protections between both sides of the Atlantic. Today Americans already enjoy these protections when their data is transferred to the EU, while this is not the case for Europeans when their data is transferred to the United States. This is why you asked us, in your resolution of 12 March 2014, to put rights for EU citizens on an equal footing with rights for US citizens. The consequence of all this is clear. It is first and foremost the protection of the fundamental rights of our citizens which will benefit from the agreement. I see no benefit in delaying its conclusion. This will only be to our detriment.  I would like to warmly thank the rapporteur, Mr Albrecht, for his support on this important agreement. The help from the Parliament has also been essential to ensure the adoption by the US Congress of the US Judicial Redress Act, which extends important rights to our citizens that were previously reserved only for Americans. I would like to thank all of you for your continuous support on that.  I know that certain aspects of the Umbrella Agreement have raised questions among some Members of this House. The Commission has taken these concerns very seriously, and on various occasions provided explanations and clarifications to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Most recently we have transmitted to Parliament a statement that contains these clarifications. The Commission will issue this statement at the time of the conclusion of the Agreement by the EU and it will be published in the Official Journal. While I understand that some of you still have reservations, I hope that our central message has been heard. This is a big leap in terms of data protection, and a major improvement compared to the status quo. This includes the adoption of the Judicial Redress Act, something which would not have been possible without the pressure stemming from the Umbrella Agreement negotiations. Making the Judicial Redress Act operational still requires that the US Attorney General designates the EU as being covered by the Act. This is a necessary step for full implementation, and we have agreed with the United States that the official notifications triggering the entry into force will only be exchanged once this designation has been made.  So time matters here. We understand that this can still happen in the coming weeks under the current administration.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. — Madam President, Commissioner Jourova, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I supported the position of the rapporteur of the committee lead, my colleague Albrecht. Parliament has given its approval to conclude this agreement. It is important and will lead to visible results. The aim of the agreement is, above all, to create a wide range of safeguards and safeguards that will be offered for the transfer of personal data for criminal enforcement purposes between the United States of America, the European Union and its member states. As a condition of legal certainty, the protection of personal data is a definite priority and it is guaranteed in this agreement. I believe that this agreement provides at a high level the protection of these data, contributes to legal certainty and will also improve law enforcement cooperation with the United States of America. It is important to note that the exchange of the data of the national security services remains outside the scope of the agreement, as they are not within the competence of the Union.

name: Axel Voss
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Let us vote for this agreement together tomorrow! We need this agreement, and this has been emphasised several times. First, it regulates the protection of personal data when transferring data to the United States for the purposes of preventing, investigating, detecting and prosecuting criminal offences. Secondly, it complements existing criminal cooperation agreements with the US with additional data protection. Thirdly, the umbrella agreement is also necessary because many of these agreements are not yet adapted to technological developments and therefore offer additional data protection here. Fourthly, the agreement is also a great success for the citizens of Europe. In the future, they will always have the opportunity — as has already been mentioned — to obtain appropriate legal protection before the US courts. This will therefore strengthen the fundamental rights of our citizens here too. We can be satisfied with the outcome of the agreement and we support it. After all, we worked for this for many years. Many thanks to the Commission and the Commissioner for their work, but also to the rapporteur, Jan Philipp Albrecht, for his dedication and commitment. He has really tried to respond to the wishes and demands of sceptics and critics in the European Parliament's negotiating team. The resolutions now tabled, on the other hand, are once again an expression of political helplessness. This would delay the adoption of such an agreement by years and would again delay the increase in data protection accordingly. That is why I would like to call on everyone again: the majority of us should agree to this umbrella agreement tomorrow.

name: Marju Lauristin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I also want to stress what was said by Commissioner Jourová that this is really the first international agreement between the EU and a third country – especially now the USA – which is implementing principles enshrined by us in our ‘police’ directive on data protection. That is a major step forward. The Umbrella Agreement improves the current regime of data protection in the existing bilateral agreements between the USA and EU Member States. We must know that the existing bilateral agreements are really weak and they do not provide our citizens with data protection safeguards. For example the treaties on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between the USA and Germany, the USA and Spain, the USA and Finland, the USA and my own country Estonia, and many other countries, do not comprise important rights of the data subject such as the right to access, the right to rectification, the right to be informed about the process, onward transfer restrictions, enhanced protection of sensitive data, rectification in case of data breaches, the fight for judicial redress, and so on.  All of these rights will be provided to our citizens by the Umbrella Agreement. This means that delaying adoption of the Umbrella Agreement will, first of all, be at the expense of our citizens, and we have to understand that we have a very big political responsibility in this situation. I feel that we could have something ideal in an ideal world, but in the real world, with the incoming Trump administration, I think that delaying this decision means that we will be really naive to hope that we will have a better solution under this new administration compared to what we have. At the same time, the Umbrella Agreement also foresees law enforcement cooperation. In situations of terrorism and all kinds of other international crimes, specifically cyber-crime for example, we need cooperation with America, even under the Trump administration. But in this situation we also need better and concrete safeguards, so I think that in order to have better safeguards for our citizens and better police cooperation we have to support this agreement and to try to implement it as fast as possible. Time really matters.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Madam President, the overall agreement is a major step forward. Never before have we negotiated such a high level of protection between the EU and the US in the exchange of personal data for the fight against terrorism and organised crime. We're still a target of terrorism. That is why cooperation and exchange of information are indeed crucial for protecting our society, but we must and can organise this exchange properly, respecting our European values, including the protection of privacy. I would stress that data protection and the fight against terrorism do not stand in the way of each other, and a common data protection framework will, on the contrary, lead to better cooperation. The critics are now trying to torpedote the umbrella agreement by submitting it to the European Court of Justice. This sounds noble, but it's nothing more than a retardant. Postponement will make the current situation stand, and it is much worse. In addition, there is a guarantee that the agreement will be constantly monitored and regularly evaluated. Similarly, the agreement will only enter into force when it is fully implemented by the US. I therefore call on everyone not to support the reference to the Court of Justice. The rapporteur enjoys my full support.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, my group, the ALDE Group, was one of the first groups about 10 years ago to ask for this kind of umbrella agreement, and on the surface it looks really good and contains very good safeguards. But it is a bit like with Swiss cheese – the cheese is fantastic but it is the holes that are the problem, as in this case. I would say to my colleague, Mr Voss, who is accusing me of political opportunism, or something like that, that there is a negative opinion by the Legal Service of this House, by Working Party 29, by the EDPS, by various legal experts, and also some pertinent and negative remarks by the Advocate—General of the European Court of Justice, so this is not politics. There are very legitimate legal concerns.  This may not have the effect of an adequacy finding, but it does have the effect of being a kind of green light, because it provides appropriate safeguards, as we say, so we have to look very closely at what we do. Now one thing, Madam Commissioner, is that the Commission has conceded that in order for the umbrella agreement to be fully implemented, it is necessary, it is a precondition, that the exemptions from the Privacy Act for PNR, TFTP and comparable programmes be repealed, because only then can the umbrella agreement be considered to be implemented. So what do you think the chances are that will ever happen? I think they are zero. They are zero under the Obama administration and they certainly are zero under the Trump administration, so what are you going to do if the United States will not repeal? What will the European Commission do? Will we be in the same situation as with Safe Harbour, which had to be repealed but it took the ECJ ruling to actually annul this.  Then the rapporteur said we have unconditional data protection rights. Well that is misguiding, Mr Rapporteur, because there is a condition – namely for judicial redress, namely allowing for data transfer for commercial purposes. That smells a little bit of ‘buying’ our rights; that is not unconditional.  Finally, we all know that the rights do not extend to all EU citizens and they do not cover people living in the European Union without EU citizenship. Therefore, I do think that an ECJ opinion is not a stalling tactic, but will address very legitimate legal concerns which have been expressed not only by my group, but also by the legal experts that I have mentioned before. I find it remarkable that the rapporteur, the Green rapporteur, who is known as a privacy activist, now seems to rely on the word of Mr Trump for the safeguards of European citizens. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question asked by raising a blue card. — Dear Mrs. Sophie in't Veld, I'm not Dutch, but until today I thought that the holes in the emental actually belong and that it was part of it. But that's not what I was going to ask. I just found your comparison a little grinning, but I'm sorry about this joke. I'd rather like to know your opinion. What do you think is missing in this agreement for your faction to support it? What is the main reason for disagreeing, because I haven't understood until now?

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – But I suppose the problem is I come from a country where they make Gouda cheese, which doesn’t have any holes, therefore we have a bit of trouble with that. But I think I’ve been very clear in the last 10 years that we’ve been discussing this; you can also read the details in my blog, if you’d like to. But one of the key elements is what I’ve just mentioned: the Commission itself has, in writing – including in the declaration that will be attached to this, conceded that the umbrella agreement can only be considered implemented if the exemptions to the US Privacy Act are repealed. This is a bit complex and technical, but the Commission has stated that, and that will happen when pigs fly; that’s my problem.

name: President. –
text: I am very sorry but you have had 30 seconds, and your reminding us of cheese might make us all hungry, so let’s stick to the work in hand.

name: Malin Björk
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I am here on behalf of our shadow, Cornelia Ernst, who could not be here tonight but who has, as you know, been working on this with colleagues for several years. Like the former speaker, I want to highlight that, although there are improvements and good things in this Agreement, we are not satisfied. In our view, the Agreement does not meet the requirement of the Charter under EU law and fails to provide the required levels of protection. The wording is not strong enough when it comes to purpose limitation and onward transfer and, as the former speaker said, not all individuals are allowed to have effective judicial redress. It differentiates between EU citizens and non-citizens. Legal actors have criticised the Agreement. It is an international agreement, which would mean it is very difficult – near impossible – to challenge its legality in court. It will, as such, override the EU’s data protection legislation, endangering what we have fought very hard to have, our good data protection rights. For all of these reasons, we think that the Agreement has to go to the European Court of Justice so we can have clear legal guidance on the manner in which these international agreements in the field of law enforcement and data protection interlink and whether they comply sufficiently with EU law. I must also add that I do not think that we should use Mr Trump as an excuse for bad European Union law-making. We have full responsibly here ourselves and we should refer this to the European Court of Justice. Otherwise our Group will have to vote against this Agreement.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (NL) Madam President, the new rules governing the use of data from us, European citizens, by police forces in the United States is, in my view, a major step forward. And I hear Mrs. in't Veld say it's not, but we can only win. Either they use this agreement on their side and then we have won something, because so far our data has not been protected there and we cannot go to court there, or they do nothing with it, then this is a worthless agreement and we have lost nothing else. And these appointments don't come a moment too soon with Donald Trump in power. I fear for the security of European citizens, of course, of Americans too, just when Mr Trump further tightens security. Luckily, Trump doesn't have the judges in his pocket yet, and we can go to court there. What is very unfortunate is that this protection only applies to people with a European passport and not to everyone living in Europe. We are setting a good example. If you want to get your right here, it doesn't matter what passport you have. Good example does follow well, says the saying. But maybe that's too much to ask for President Elect Donald J. Trump.

name: Raymond Finch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Establishing tough data protection safeguards is something I’m sure we can all get behind. It’s only fair that, when data is shared between nations for the purpose of prevention, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, these safeguards must be in place. They help to ensure that there is a fair data retention period, that there are fair rules on the use of sensitive information, and that there is accountability when data is lost or stolen. The latter, perhaps, is the most important, given the increased global security threat. Attached to this vote are two resolutions from the ALDE and GUE groups, who seek to postpone the signing of this agreement until the ECJ is given its opinion.  It probably goes without saying that UKIP reject the very existence of the ECJ, and that is putting it quite mildly. This is a real problem, that this agreement does not appear, at the moment, to be signed by the UK Government; we shall be watching it closely to see whether Prime Minister May actually does bring us into this, against all of things she said about getting us cleared of the ECJ, and we will absolutely be monitoring how all the UKIP UK MEPs vote on these amendments regarding sending disagreements to the ECJ.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I just wonder if Mr Finch would confirm that he feels this whole topic would be far better dealt with by an independent Britain post—Brexit, and that we shouldn’t have to worry ourselves with the activities of the ECJ.

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, indeed, but the fact is that it will be in two to two and a half years’ time that the UK should enforce its own data protection deals. The ECJ is not fit for purpose, and I will be extremely distressed if our present Prime Minister actually signs us into these. We do have an opt-out at present, and we will be watching extremely closely.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: — (The speaker speaks without a microphone.)... World must pay attention to this and must agree that the protection of personal data is something important and is also supported. I too support this agreement from a fundamental point of view. But one must not confuse cause and effect here. On the one hand, they bring a variety of measures to the policy pipeline for the documentation and exchange of personal data. It was data retention, the SWIFT agreement, the passenger directives and so on and so forth. And wherever data is documented, wherever data is exchanged, there is misuse of this data. I do not understand why the documentation and exchange of data is generally extended to all members of the European Union, rather than focusing on risk communities. It is not the French and German grandmothers whose data needs to be monitored, they are political and religious extremists. And that is exactly where the emphasis must be placed and must not implement surveillance measures with regard to all citizens of the European Union. You're going the wrong way.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). — Madam President, the Council has drawn up a draft decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the United States on the protection of personal information, so that it can be traced, investigated and prosecuted criminal offences such as that of terrorism. If we look technocratic at the text of the agreement, it goes in the right direction, because it is based on a sound legal basis, guarantees to a large extent the protection of the right to the security of personal data and, in agreement with the United States Congress, allows us to European citizens are prosecuted by United States agencies which violate the confidentiality of the personal data of individuals who have made it available to them. As I said before, all this sounds good. However, the bad experience we have gained from the behaviour of the United States during the TTIP negotiations ought to make us very careful, because what happens in the event of mass processing and leakage of personal data? How will the American authorities behave in this case? Will they apply the terms of the agreement or will they try to exclude from the application of US law those services which have violated confidentiality? So we need to look at the agreement not technocratic but essentially and agree only on the condition that rules are established that either limit the possibility of information leakage or, if that happens, prosecute... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: — Madam President, the adoption of the umbrella agreement is an extremely important step forward in improving security in Europe while, at the same time, not compromising on human rights and, more precisely, the protection of the personal data of European citizens. Here, in this Parliament, we have repeatedly demanded increased cooperation, both between law enforcement services in the European Union and with our international partners, with the aim of the timely exchange of quality information about suspected terrorists, traffickers and other criminals. This is necessary in order to prevent future terrorist attacks and European citizens from feeling safer in their daily lives. However, this cooperation cannot and must not be at the expense of the fundamental rights and freedoms we have conquered in Europe. European citizens have the right to know that their data is not being used unlawfully, that the state does not monitor them, but, on the contrary, is doing everything possible to protect them and their data. In the particular case of the umbrella agreement with the United States, the European Union does not unconditionally transmit the personal data of Europeans. The aim of the agreement is to ensure that the high standards of data protection that we have here in Europe will also apply to data sharing with our American partners. The agreement is by no means constituting a head of Europe before the United States, but on the contrary, it warns protection for European citizens before the US law enforcement authorities and courts, which has not existed before. Therefore, for the sake of international cooperation and the protection of the personal data of European citizens, we must all vote in favour of this agreement tomorrow.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: — Thank you. In principle, of course, it is helpful if there are transatlantic rules to protect law enforcement data that do not then have to be renegotiated again and again. But questions remain. For example, there are reasonable doubts as to whether the complaint body on the US side, for example, is truly independent and has sufficient competence. We want this so-called umbrella to also apply to measures already adopted, such as DNR and TFTP. However, there is no clarity as to whether the US administration will undertake the necessary legislative reforms to ensure that passenger and bank data actually falls within the scope of the agreement. Last week, a referral from CETA to the ECJ was refused on the grounds that we should trust our legal service. I do. Our legal service believes that this agreement can act as an adequacy decision, and this could mean that the US will be a safe haven for our law enforcement data in the long term, without it being clear how our side can prevent data flows in the event of violations of fundamental rights. And the US can deny EU citizens access to an effective remedy if their home country no longer pushes commercial data across the Atlantic. I find this mixture of civil rights and commercial interests questionable. Clearly clear, these issues are all the more important as we are voting on an agreement with unlimited duration. Of course, such an agreement can also be suspended, but our experience with safe harbour makes me unoptimistic. Thank you.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: “I am a strong supporter of this agreement and I am convinced by the arguments of Commissioner Jourova, which indicate that in the existing bilateral agreements the level of protection is lower than in this agreement, which we will adopt on behalf of the European Union. This is a new balance of efficiency with the protection of personal data. Whenever we debate the protection of personal information we have on the part of the far left and ALDE showing off radicalism, but the world is so built that radicalism is usually the enemy of the good. You interpret your fundamental values so broadly, privacy, that it would prevent any effective protection of the security of Europeans. And finally: I'm not a Trump sympathizer, but insulting the president of the United States is a pop of lack of diplomacy. I don't think anyone would want Americans to talk about the President of the European Parliament or the Prime Minister of the Netherlands, so he calls for more diplomacy.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: Madam President! So today we are debating an agreement between the United States and the European Union on how to deal with personal data, how personal data is to be protected in criminal investigations. The left is opposed to the agreement for the very reason that it is an agreement with the United States. It's an anti-American reflex. This may not be the good guide to politics, that should be reason. The agreement does not concern the exchange of commercial data, but personal data, and since there is no agreement at the moment on how to protect this data in the exchange, this agreement is of course an improvement. It's not good, but it's an improvement in the current situation. Data retention and something like that remain wrong, but are not meant here. There must be further improvements and, above all, we need to regulate — in other contracts — whether or not the exchange of personal data should take place at all. We have to set very, very tight limits.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF).
text: - Madam President! Dear ladies! We must be aware, above all, of the fact that the construction of large citizens' databases is objectively a part of a system of totalitarian control over citizens. This is a recipe of an oppressive nature. These types of oppressive regulations should function in such a way that the proceders in this type are as little as possible, not as much as possible. Each country should be able to restrict these types of proceders to cases necessary in a country. One should not create universal standards, so as not to extend these procedures to other countries that do not wish for such totalitarian control. This law is not so bad at all, although the rapporteur has shown a great deal of errors and disparities of this law, after which he has incomprehensibly recommended adoption. They need to be rejected and better solutions are proposed. They're easy to edit.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: — Madam President, this agreement on data protection in the fight against crime and terrorism aims to restore confidence in the transatlantic recovery affected by what Snowden revealed about the CIA and NSA's mass surveillance programme in 2013. The agreement ensures European standards for the protection and security of data transferred to the United States, although it only applies to nationals of European Union countries and questionably discriminates against non-resident nationals. Nevertheless, with the election of Trump, this acquis of guarantees, which can and must be extended to everyone in the European Union, is more important than ever. The Trump Administration is the burden of complying with or shredding this agreement. It is therefore imperative and urgent that Parliament should give its consent and prepare to accompany it in its implementation, if the United States respects it. I thank Jan Philipp Albrecht for his leadership in this crucial legislation on personal data protection.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: — Mr. President, the agreement between the US and the EU on the protection of personal information regarding the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences should be supported as it complements the agreements so far. First of all, bilateral between Member States and the United States increasing and harmonizing the rights of persons whose data is processed. What this upgrade provides are safeguards for the person whose data is processed and the equal treatment of citizens of the Union and the US in practical application. It's a quality step in the right direction. Overcoming global challenges in the fight against crime cannot be without the rapid and efficient exchange of data among partners. In this fight, we must take care that there is no abuse. In this context, I am particularly satisfied with the provisions of the agreement on the accuracy, relevance, up-to-date and completeness of the data collected and the period of their storage after processing.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement between the United States and the European Union establishes for the first time a complete framework of data protection principles and guarantees for the first time for the transfer of personal information, relating to criminal law enforcement, including in matters of terrorism. A comprehensive and coherent protection instrument applicable to transatlantic, data exchanges in the field of judicial and police cooperation, which is undoubtedly a significant step in forward in relations between the United States and Europe. The agreement will confirm, in the transatlantic context, the general requirements on international data transfers provided for by the European Directive, adopted last April, to protect individuals with concerning the processing of personal data, by the competent authorities for the prevention, investigation, investigation and prosecution of crimes or enforcement of criminal penalties. It will form in relation to future EU-US agreements, a safety net, below which the level of protection cannot fall.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Madam President, the protection of personal information is a fundamental right and any processing of personal data is prohibited. It is allowed only for reasons of public interest but also under strict conditions and also with judicial protection and in accordance with the laws of the European Union. It is obvious that there is a gap between the guarantees of data protection offered by the EU-United States umbrella agreement and the requirements of European Union law. It is surprising that the pressure is being exerted for this agreement to be approved even when the Court of Justice of the European Union has given a ruling on the PNR, in other words the agreement between the European Union and Canada. I therefore believe that the referral of the case to the Court of Justice of the European Union gives additional guarantees. If you read the explanatory memorandum, you see that there are gaps in protection. Under point 8, processing will not only be carried out by the requesting authority but also by other authorities which may request it.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL). — Madam President, we are debating a very serious issue, because nobody wants to be the victim of terrorism. On the other hand, however, nobody, as a citizen, possibly innocent, wants to be the victim of the terrorism imposed by the decision or agreement between the European Union and the United States. There is one expression which may be key to our decision: 'It is better to have some guilty people outside prisons than an innocent man rotting in prison', and this has happened to us after the agreement which may or may not be approved tomorrow. The fact that there is a rush, as has been said by other Members, to close this agreement before Mr Trump arrives, apart from the fact that it is certainly offensive to him, regardless of the views each of us has of the new President of the United States, shows that we're moving at a speed that puts us in danger. Finally, I personally do not accept that this agreement should only concern European citizens and not other people who live here.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for your support, not only in today’s debate but also in many years of negotiations of the Umbrella Agreement. Your consistent engagement also with your counterparts in the US Congress played a vital role in a securing new rights for our citizens under the Judicial Redress Act, and I count on you to continue engaging with the new US Congress to make sure that we maintain and build on what we have achieved. As for myself, I am in contact with the US Attorney General Loretta Lynch to ensure that the United States side makes the necessary designations to ensure that this agreement enters into force as soon as possible. As for the other questions which have been raised, and some doubts concerning some of your questions, we tried to clarify everything in in our clarification which, as I said before, will be published, and I will engage with the successor of Loretta Lynch as Attorney General, once confirmed, to work together on its full implementation. Against this background, I can only encourage the honourable Members of this Parliament to give their consent to this international agreement, which is so important for our people in Europe.

name: President. –
text: I now give the floor to the rapporteur, Mr Olbrycht. I am sorry, I know that Madam in 't Veld is looking for the floor. Could I ask you, Madam in 't Veld, if you would speak to the Commissioner afterwards, or perhaps Commissioner, could I ask whether the questions can be put to you in writing? We have had the debate, the Commissioner has made a statement. I will give you the floor reluctantly because you had your chance during the debate, so perhaps you could very briefly make your case.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE).
text: – I asked a very simple question. The Commission in the declaration that will be attached to tomorrow’s document states very clearly that a precondition for the Umbrella Agreement to be valid, to be implemented, is the repeal of the exemptions to the Privacy Act. What does the Commissioner think are the chances of that happening? It’s a precondition: without that the Umbrella Agreement is not valid.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: rapporteur. — Madam President. Dear Ladies and Gentlemen! We have made historic progress. After years of negotiations, it has finally been possible to agree binding international standards on data protection in the field of police and judicial cooperation with the United States. This is an important step forward for our citizens after many years of agreements and passed laws, notably with the voices of Conservatives, Liberals and Social Democrats who have adopted the legal basis for transferring data to the US — that is, monitoring and have adopted data transfer measures. We are now going to launch an agreement that strengthens the privacy rights of data subjects, which ensures that legal protection exists in the United States and that binding standards exist when this data is transferred. The umbrella agreement, the data protection framework agreement, is not a legal basis for further data transfers, it is not a surveillance measure. No, on the contrary, it is a data protection agreement. It strengthens the fundamental right to data protection, and it is a huge step forward that the US Congress has cast these rights into law. It is also perfectly clear that if the United States does not fully implement the high standards that we agree here and the unequivocally granted legal protection for all EU citizens, then this agreement will not come in this way, and then there will be no increase in confidence or better cooperation with the US. That is our basic requirement, and we finally have something in our hands to force the US to implement such rights. This is better than before and I have no problem asking again whether this agreement is in line with the European Court of Justice. I don't have a problem with this, but I wonder why this then here is so vehemently called for a data protection agreement, while elsewhere, such as trade agreements or surveillance agreements, it is also being rejected by Socialists and Liberals.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 1 December 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - The exchange of crime prevention and law enforcement data with other states is essential to ensure the security of Europe's citizens. However, data exchange can only take place with the proper protection of the personal data of EU citizens. That is why it is of great importance to adopt an agreement with the Government of the United States of America on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, which provides a framework for those standards and requirements that apply to the conditions for handling data exchanged between EU Member States and the United States. The agreement can be said to provide adequate data protection safeguards, thereby aiming at a high level of protection of the rights of data subjects. I think it is important to emphasise that the agreement itself does not constitute a legal basis for the transfer of personal data to the United States. I would also like to point out that thanks to the persistence of the European Parliament, the American side provided European Union citizens with legislative measures with judicial redress in the United States.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The exchange of personal data in the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crime is necessary and useful in a globalised world. However, such data exchange programmes must be subject to the strictest safeguards to protect personal data. I do not see these safeguards in the agreement between the United States of America and the Member States of the European Union. That is why I take a critical position on this agreement. The balance between freedom and security is complicated. However, the freedom of the individual citizen must never be curtailed. I agree with the rapporteur here in accepting that this agreement represents a great step forward in the protection of personal data transmitted between the Member States of the EU and the United States for the purpose of law enforcement. However, it is not the best possible agreement that can be envisable, not even in the current situation. Only new rights and safeguards for cases of transfer within the framework of law enforcement cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and the United States will be added here. However, I am in favour of further tightening of security measures to protect personal data.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: in writing. — I express my support for the Albrecht report and thus agree to conclude the so-called 'umbrella Agreement' between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal information related to crime prevention, conduct of proceedings preparatory, detection and prosecution of prohibited acts. This agreement matters especially because of the counter-terrorism efforts being made. The planned agreement creates a framework for the protection of personal data, which contributes to legal certainty. The Agreement will, if necessary, supplement data protection safeguards in existing and future data transfer agreements or in national legislation authorising such transfers. In addition, the agreement will have a significant impact on the cooperation of the police and law enforcement agencies of the European Union and its Member States and the United States, by establishing a common and comprehensive framework that includes principles and guarantees for data protection. The agreement will allow law enforcement agencies in the EU or its member states, on the one hand, and in the US, on the other hand, to work together more effectively. The establishment of common standards in this area of cooperation can greatly contribute to the restoration of trust in the field of transatlantic data flows. Thanks to the agreement concluded, the EU and the US will intensify cooperation while ensuring a high level of data protection. This is particularly important because of the huge challenges facing the EU and the US.

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: in writing. — The umbrella agreement signed by the US and the EU on 2 June 2016 provides a comprehensive data protection framework for closer transatlantic law enforcement cooperation. It completes existing agreements with the US governing access to passenger data and financial transactions. This agreement will ensure high standards of data protection in the fight against crime and terrorism across the Atlantic. It includes all personal data exchanged between the US and the EU for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of crime, including terrorist activities. Citizens of the European Union will benefit from being given the right to sue US authorities for data breaches. In addition, the storage of the data is only possible for a limited period and the use of data is limited. This agreement will strengthen fundamental rights, such as the fundamental right to privacy. It also helps to deepen law enforcement cooperation and restore confidence in transatlantic data exchange.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Parliament called for an agreement that would provide data protection safeguards for personal information transferred between the EU and US. On 3 December 2010 the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations on such an agreement that would provide the right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data when this information is transferred to the competent authorities. On 8 September 2015 EU and US officials concluded the agreement, guaranteeing a high level of protection for all personal data that will be transferred between the law enforcement authorities of the two parts. The personal data will only be exchanged and processed with the scope of investigating, detecting or prosecuting criminal offences and acts of terrorism in the framework of police cooperation and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Any citizen from the two parts that considers that his data has been misused will have access to several accessible and affordable dispute resolution mechanisms. This is the first time that personal data information is exchanged in a secured way with strong obligations on companies handling the data, clear safeguards and transparency obligations on US Government access and an effective protection of individual rights.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union has strict data protection standards. It is a basic principle that data should never be used for purposes incompatible with the original purpose, and personal data should be collected and processed lawfully under strict conditions and for legitimate purposes. It is important that these principles are shared by EU partners, thus protecting European citizens' data worldwide. This is particularly relevant for close and important partners such as the United States, with which not only does the EU have close trade ties, but we also work closely together in the field of law enforcement. The recently established EU-US Privacy Shield also serves to protect the privacy of Europeans, and we expect the same from the agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal data relating to the prevention, investigation and detection of criminal offences. In addition to ensuring a high level of protection of personal data, we also, of course, consider it necessary that, thanks to the Data Protection Framework Agreement, the exchange of law enforcement information between the United States and the European Union and its Member States, the international law enforcement effectiveness will also increase.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on recent transition of the IANA stewardship to the global internet community in October 2016 and the upcoming Internet Governance Forum in Mexico (6—8 December 2016) (2016/2997(RSP)).

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as you know, Parliament and the Commission have been working side by side on internet governance issues in support of the multi—stakeholder model for many years. Both institutions actively supported the completion of the IANA transitions, as well as the extension of the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) mandate, which was part of the successful outcome of the review of the World Summit on the Information Society one year ago in December 2015.  Recently a historical milestone for internet governance was finally achieved. The IANA contract has expired. As of 1 October 2016, the multi-stakeholder community is responsible for the overview of the IANA functions. In parallel, a series of improvements in economic accountability have come into force. This is a major step in making internet governance truly global and I warmly welcome it. Parliament, our Member States and the Commission have long called for the globalisation of the IANA functions. We have all worked together with the rest of the global multi—stakeholder community for it to happen. Indeed the European input into this process has been substantial. However, the transition is not only the end of a process. It is, much more importantly, the beginning of a new phase. The multi-stakeholder model will now be put to the test. It is now up to all of us to live up to our new responsibilities. My message to you is that it is even more relevant now for Europe to have a strong presence and voice in international discussions. While the United States has stepped back from its previous role, the continued threat from more authoritarian countries means that the EU must remain vigilant and play an even bigger role in the stewardship of the internet and defence of the multi-stakeholder model. Next will be the Internet Governance Forum in Mexico. It is a very good sign of Parliament’s engagement that, as I understand it, 18 MEPs will be participating in this global meeting. Now that the IGF’s mandate has been extended, the challenge is to make it even more relevant and helpful for the whole multi—stakeholder internet community, which will face an ever—changing technological landscape. The internet of today is very different from the internet we will have in 10 years’ time.  Europe can, and should, be a more active and powerful player in internet governance in line with the importance of the internet for the European economy and society. The role of the internet and digital has never been so high on the political agenda. In Europe we are working hard to deliver on the digital single market. A fundamental building block for our success is ensuring that the internet continues to function in a reliable and stable way and its governance is balanced, inclusive and transparent. I look foward to your contributions.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, thank you very much, Commissioner. In fact, 2016 has been an enormously fruitful year in the maturation of internet governance. As of October 1 this year, the management of the Internet Number Assignment Authority (IANA) was linked to the United States Administration. As of 2016, the maturation of internet governance has culminated in its emancipation from ICANN, from the United States Government, through the transfer, on September 30, of its contract for the performance of IANA's duties from the US Administration. This is a really important milestone. There have been many years in which this process has developed. Right now we are facing a situation clearly defined by a multistakeholder approach to internet governance. It must be said, as the Commissioner said, that the European Union has played an important role: the European Commission, representing the interests of all Member States, on the one hand, and also the presence of the European Parliament at all meetings — and they are going to be eleven — which, since its founding, has had the annual Forum for Governance of the European Union. The Internet, which must continue to maintain that open, non-fragmented and global nature of the internet.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Madam President, at the Global Internet Forum in 2015, held in João Pessoa, Brazil, it was possible to extend the Internet Governance Agreement for 10 years, and this will continue to be ensured by the global user community through a multi-partnership platform involving the various stakeholders. In the conclusions of this Forum, emphasis was placed on the commitment of the United States Government to ensure the transfer of IANA functions to ICANN through a transparent process, monitored and verified by the global user community. That happened. In October 2016, the transfer process was consummated. A very important step has been taken to ensure an open and participatory model of Internet governance. It is now up to the 2016 Global Forum, which will take place in Guadalajara, Mexico, from 6 to 8 December, under the sign of inclusion and sustainable growth, to consolidate the proven governance model, founded on democratic values and based on networks of nationwide structured user forums, to regional level and at the global level. It is essential to ensure that, with the new digital revolution and the new technological platforms, the Internet continues to be an open network, free of interference, technologically neutral and capable of reconciling the market approach with the social dimensions of inclusion, universalization of access and the generalization of utilities. The European Union has been a key partner in affirming an open and plural vision in the dissemination of the Internet. This vision, coupled with successful global partnerships, made the difference at key moments of the decision when the heralds of Internet control tried to assert their perspective and failed. This European perspective, which is the winner of the global plan, must now also be prevalent in the realisation of the Digital Agenda and the Digital Single Market. The option for an Internet It also forms and motivates the Wifi for Europe initiative for which I am the rapporteur. This initiative affirms the democratic and participatory model of facilitating Internet access by various communities and territories, and can and should have a seminal effect, with principles of action that must be encouraged throughout the world and included in the Union's external cooperation directives.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Ladies! The internet is a tool with a global reach — that's clear. The final of the process of passing the ordering function of the system of domains and IP addresses by the American government to the international community is a confirmation of this fact from the administrative side. The intentions of this process are, of course, as right as possible, but can we be sure that global control will be more efficient than it has been before? In the long run, is it possible to develop universal standards on the basic principles of the functioning of the internet, when even on the issue of human rights we could not agree? It is hard to believe that non-democratic regimes and private corporations will not use their influence to, with this change, strengthen their control over the network. Such a scenario would, of course, be extremely threatening to all of us. That is why we need to talk to our partners in international gremias and seek agreement on common principles for internet governance.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the recent internet governance transition to the global internet community is a symbolic step, but symbolic steps are quite necessary in these turbulent times, especially after the recent elections in the USA. Most people involved in the work of ICANN will say that it will not change much, as the US Commerce Department was only validating that decisions follow protocols, but this is how it was, and with new leadership things can change. So for non-Americans there is definitely a sense of relief that the transition has been done, not only because of the US political landscape, but because internet governance just cannot be under oversight of one specific country.  Trust and openness are at the heart of the internet, so people expect the internet to function and to be able to trust it; but maintaining that trust does involve a lot of technical work behind the scenes that most of us do not really see. The work of ICANN on domain names is a good example. Domain names are like phone numbers: if some of us have the same number, then it’s a problem. So people need to trust that there is an inclusive and transparent process in place on how domain names are distributed and how name collisions are dealt with. The internet was created with the dream of free flow of information, but since then interests around controlling the internet from both the private sector as well as the public sector have been growing. Therefore this is an important time for multi-stakeholder internet governance to be successful. It is crucial to show even in a rather technical area that the process is independent and transparent.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner. The theme of the Internet Governance Forum 2016 is “Enabling inclusive and sustainable growth.” Increasing connectivity is one of the priority objectives, and connectivity means that another billion people are expected to go online by 2020. This year's forum has three main priorities, which are cyber security, cyber economy and human rights, which are very well chosen! Cyber security — the meaning is not particularly noteworthy. Everyone in Germany — around 300,000 people were affected by the failure at Deutsche Telekom — knows that cyber security today can affect not only companies, but also any private household. The digital economy in general is the key factor for growth and employment. Digital innovation, as we see on blockchain today, for example, is the driver for hundreds of thousands of new jobs. The EU must be strongly represented here. The decisions taken by the Internet Governance Forum, however, are only agreements of principle. This means that they can demonstrate the digital growth potential and the impact on a global society, but they cannot prevent fragmentation of the Internet. However, fragmentation is the biggest threat to the Internet. For this reason, the mandate of the IGF needs to be strengthened. The Internet must remain open and freely accessible.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the internet is a global common resource and a springboard to economic, scientific and social development. The EU has to contribute actively to the evolving model of internet governance. Parliament has been committed to making the governance transparent and inclusive. We welcomed the transfer of supervision over the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority to the multi-stakeholder communities. This will help us keep the internet open and safe. Moreover, the Internet Governance Forum must remain high on the agenda of the EU institutions and the Member States.  Next week the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) will once again lead the European Parliament delegation to the Forum’s meeting in Mexico. The European perspective must be communicated globally for the sake of our industry, business and citizens, especially citizens of course. Three preconditions are necessary: global efforts to improve access all over the world to the internet, joint strategies for raising the security of critical infrastructure, which is very important in times of so many hybrid threats, and ensuring internet communication for our citizens and companies, especially small and medium enterprises. That is a priority for us.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: – Madam President, next week the Internet Governance Forum (IGF) takes place just after the change of the IANA stewardship to the global internet community in October 2016 – an important milestone that has been supported by Parliament and the Commission for years.  The new arrangement is the outcome of political awareness and pressure. We have strengthened the position of the global internet community, internet governance. The principles of openness, security, reliability and independence from national states have been applied. In times of strong tendencies toward national solutions and attitudes, we have to make sure that the internet truly remains the free worldwide web. There can be no Balkanisation of the internet, where countries build virtual walls, fragmenting the worldwide web into national internets, limiting trade and communication, which are our principles.  A lot of work needs to be done, as Mr Buzek said, including in terms of involving the stakeholders from developing countries and our youth. It is important that young people take responsibility, and the Youth IGF next week in Mexico is a good start. It is a good sign that Parliament is sending a big delegation – a good high-level delegation – as is the Commission, to Guadalajara in Mexico.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Madam President, a lot has already been said on this subject, I will only underline the words of my pre-speakers. It is very good that the European Union is sending its delegation to this global internet forum. The shape of the internet is an extremely important thing. He belongs to a free society. We must do the best to ensure that internet governance, which goes effectively into private hands, into the private sector, so that it is carried out efficiently and that some key topics under discussion, such as internet access for young people, genders such as internet access in third countries, such as the issue of protection of personal data, protection of human rights and protection of free speech on the Internet, has been the subject of consistent debate. I am in favour of absolute freedom of speech on the internet, on the other hand, we must draw attention to the fact that this freedom is occasionally abused, for example in the case of the Czech Republic by Russia, that spread false information on the internet. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by lifting the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: blue card issue. — It is important that Europe is represented. We also had the opportunity to consult experts on how they see the situation evolving overall in terms of the internet, whether transparency has increased or decreased. Taking these self-evident opinions of Europeans forward is important. That's why it's important for the European delegation to be there. Unfortunately, experts told us that in a good direction we are not evolving, but in a bad direction.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by picking up the blue card. — I do not know whether there was a bad translation, but I did not directly record the question. So I will respond to what my colleague said. I absolutely agree. Our goal is to do everything possible to keep the internet open, that there is freedom of speech, that there is no fragmentation of it, and that more or less the internet is accessible to citizens in third countries. This is a burning problem, where the European Union should clearly support that maximum people on this planet have free access to the internet.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Madam President, DNS is one of the most important pillars of the Internet, combining IP addresses with providers. The United States has always had final control over DNS control, and the transfer of the management of IANA from the US government to the non-profit organization ICANN is the end of the control and management of the Internet by the United States. This US action is an open, stable step and combines multilateral control of the Internet. It limits Washington's power to govern the Internet and puts control under the spectrum of an international umbrella. The parties involved must ensure that the Internet is and remains a single, open, neutral, free and unbroken network during the transitional period.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, let me first thank you for your support and engagement in this file. We are at a turning point for the evolution of the internet, an amazing technology that for good and for bad is a mirror of our societies. Now it is time to deliver what is needed to keep the internet open, unfragmented and reliable. Going forward, it will be important to continue to work together and make sure the EU acts as a coherent and positive partner in internet governance discussion at the global level. This will include working on how to improve the multi-stakeholder model and make it more inclusive, accountable, and transparent. In this context, stronger links with internet governance dialogue taking place at local and national level are also very important.  The internet governance forum has grown to become an important platform for these discussions, and I am confident with our input it will continue to improve and grow over the next coming years. I therefore wish the European Parliament delegation going to Guadalajara a fruitful meeting. The Commission will also be present there with a delegation from DG CONNECT. I am confident that you will be able to bring forward the discussion in many areas, and I am looking forward to hearing about the result of your discussions.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — In a few days will be held the Internet Governance Forum 2016, an important appointment to discuss and further codify the necessary improvements in the ICT sector. These discussions guide actions by national governments, regional and global agencies and operators. It is therefore important to point out that the IGF will also discuss relevant public policy issues with the internet, such as cybersecurity and data privacy, topics on which I am most sometimes pronounced. I must say that the issue of internet governance will be essential in a global context, with some important features: there is a growing economic competition in the digital field; the axis of global cyberspace is not the usual one, but it is around the US and China; after the European Court of Justice's decisions on Safe Harbor and the right to be forgotten, privacy and cybersecurity are no longer alone a human rights issue. Now they are also an economic problem, indeed, of cybereconomy, it is in this perspective that must be solved, with the activation of inclusive and sustainable growth for developing countries.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: in writing. — The upcoming Internet Management Forum is not only a major global event, but also an important part of cooperation between the European Union and Mexico. I would like to draw your attention as a member of the Delegation for Relations with Mexico and as a member of the STOA delegation of the European Parliament for this event. Mexico, because of its scientific and technological potential, is an attractive partner for us. From the beginning, our cooperation has been intense and events such as the Internet Governance Forum further deepen it. It is worth noting joint European-Mexican projects such as the LEADERSHIP project, which supported dialogue between the Union and Latin American countries in the field of cooperation for teleinformation techniques (ICT). Through the implementation of the project, a special expert group was established, which is a sustainable mechanism to promote dialogue. I hope events like the Internet Forum will result in similar useful initiatives. In addition, the forthcoming forum is a great opportunity to talk about the impact of digitisation on the job market. The exchange of good practices on new forms of work through digital platforms may be particularly interesting. In Europe, we still haven't found the perfect solution for how to combine flexibility with worker safety. Therefore, this forum can prove to be an excellent source of information.
