name: Salvatore Cicu
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, after the tragic flood events in 2002, the European Union established the Solidarity Fund, in order to express in a tangible way, a centrality with respect to these issues, towards countries affected by severe natural disasters. Italy has been in recent years, unfortunately, facing very important dramas: the flood in Sardinia, in Liguria, in Piedmont. This is from a few days ago, but the earthquake in Aquila, in Central Italy it is definitely impossible to predict all emergency situations, all disasters, but it is always possible to improve management of their consequences. Preliminarily I would also like to say that in these cases the European institutions must be sensitive, they must understand that their credibility, their authoritativeness, also depends on the ability to be present in these moments and to transfer a message, precisely ability, management. We know that, however positive were the amendments made by Regulation 2014, i.e. those referring to prepayments up to 10% of the amount, the eligibility of costs related to preparation and attention to disaster and restoration operations, but also the extension of the time limits for the submission of the application by Member States, the introduction of the period of six weeks for the Commission's response, new provisions on prevention, natural disasters and improvements in their procedures. I firmly believe, however, that many steps forward can and should be able to improve the effectiveness of the fund and show our citizens, affected by disasters, that Europe is really close to their necessity, therefore it is important that the presence of the European Commission today is important to ask the Commissioner that the Solidarity Fund is still improved, in order to overcome some issues that still remain remain. So I ask Commission to assess the possibility, to increase the threshold of prepayments, from 10 to 15%, because it is important the immediacy of availability, which the territories can achieve in comparison with emergential situations, as well as still in Italy, compared to the dramas he lives, I just mentioned, as well as the possibility of shortening the terms for the treatment of six questions from six to four weeks. I also call on the Commission to examine the possibility of establishing an eligibility threshold which, from 1.5%, is achieved instead, with the limit of 1% of regional GDP, and to consider in the assessment of questions the level of socio-economic development of the affected regions. However, I would also ask the Member States to act with responsibility, in improving their means of communication and cooperation with local and regional authorities, both during the initial evaluation process of Permissible damages, for which financial support is required, because too many times the delay and little administrative capacity, caused additional obstacles. I would also ask this Commission that in the specific case of the earthquake, be given the opportunity to revise the rules on flexibility and the stability pact, especially with regard to investment anti-seismic and sustainable reconstruction, because in this specific case they should be excluded from the calculation of the national deficit under the Stability Pact, because in this case it cannot be asked a derogation from the rule for electoral reasons, but to safeguard the lives, the suffering of hundreds of people who, in the context of natural disasters, have lost their lives.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij
text: author. –  Mr President, Mr Cicu has made a lot of very concrete proposals. It is now two years ago that we first spoke in this House about the Solidarity Fund, and it is indeed possible to be quicker, to be more effective and to have a reconsideration of the exact territory and figures. So my question to the Commissioner more generally is whether the Commission is able to take over these proposals and what kind of planning does it have to deliver these ameliorations. And it doesn’t have to cost more. In fact, since the Solidarity Fund started we have spent EUR 3.8 billion, and it has been mobilised in 70 natural disasters in 24 countries of the Union. So as Mr Chico said in his report, it is very close to people and it can be used to act immediately. At this time of naturalistic, populist debates, this really is being close to the people when with floods, hurricanes and earthquakes things go totally wrong. I support Mr Cicu strongly on this. The second question, harking back to the previous period and the proposal from Mr Kallas in 2007 on earthquakes, is that it is so important to have a good preventive alarm system, and also with our funds – combining the Solidarity Fund with the regional development funds – to put prevention in the forefront. I think we are having the right debate, especially as the situation in Italy makes this a timely debate, and I am very glad that the government recently brought the proposal to the European Commission. I hope we will have good follow-up to the proposal.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: Author. — Mr. President, the consequences of the earthquake that befell Italy this summer have not yet been removed. The consequences are 290 people killed, over 400 seriously injured. We reckon about 100,000 people have been displaced or will have to be displaced. These are really terrible consequences. That is why I want to point out on this occasion that it is very important that we adopt the resolution we proposed tomorrow, because we need to point out the problems we face when we talk about the EU Solidarity Fund. We need to react faster and even involve the EIB when we talk about some things that need to be pre-financed or financed in terms of these disasters that hit the areas we come from. As a rapporteur for the Adriatic and Ionian macroregion, we talked about the specifics of this area. Unfortunately, earthquakes are one of the specifics of the area. All of Italy and the Balkans are very rotten areas. We know about historical earthquakes in Dubrovnik, Zagreb, Skopje, Greece, Montenegro. We know about these problems and we need to do everything we can to prevent because human lives, world cultural heritage have no price. We must pursue a long-term policy to protect against earthquakes that world heritage in the Adriatic and Ionian area. Not to talk about infrastructure and everything that matters to people's lives. Finally, I wish to all those who died in the earthquake in Italy once again express my maximum condolences and regret.

name: Mercedes Bresso
text: author. — (IT) Mr President, I would like to thank my fellow Members who show that solidarity exists in Europe, including on behalf of my country, where, as you know, seismic events have been of exceptional gravity and in some months have upset a very large area of Central Italy. I believe that in addition to the memory of the victims we must recall that extensive damage to housing has been produced, much of the infrastructure has been destroyed, businesses have been hard hit, public buildings, schools, hospitals, facilities are in many cases not accessible. It is therefore still a very serious emergency that is being faced with rapid but effective measures, which are already taking action, both for reconstruction and prevention, and colleagues have very appropriately called back. In the resolution, which we are co-authors, a group of representatives of the different political groups, we welcome the willingness — which we hope the Commissioner will confirm — and the granting of a greater flexibility for emergency expenditure, but also for securing costs, which are (I believe) a very important element for the whole seismic area, which, as my colleague recalled is Italian but also of the Balkans. And also the speed and commitment to speed in the provision of resources, the solidarity fund, here too, the speed and the ability to show that the European Union moves when it is necessary, with due speed. Thank you, so if these commitments will be maintained and I would also like to remember, all the volunteers, who have made their enormous contribution, saving lives and limiting damage, many of them also foreign. We hope that in the future the strengthening of the bodies of solidarity at European level will allow many young people to experience a similar experience.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Author. — The word solidarity plays a very important role in this report. And all these last earthquakes that hit central Italy, from August to the end of October, show of course that Mother Nature is completely unpredictable and that is why this solidarity fund, established back in 2002, is so important. But it is also important that this financial support to tackle the consequences and mitigate the consequences comes in time, to the right headlines. But often in this area there are also administrative barriers, which in principle should also prevent abuse, corruption and, of course, things that are sometimes exploited for bad purposes. And that is why I think that the Commission could also take a step forward in this area and prepare in some way some “guideline” and instructions to the Member States — recommendations on how to make the most effective use and of course ensure the distribution of that aid. On the one hand, those from the Solidarity Fund and, on the other hand, of course also within the Member States. In this place, I would also focus on another problem, namely sometimes we forget about those who risk their lives when rescuing people and property in the face of natural disasters, earthquakes, floods. I'm also talking about firefighters, civil protection and those volunteers who are putting themselves in protection — like I said — people and, of course, property as well. And I think that some of the Commission's attention needs to be paid to that in the future. In particular, because many volunteers who are in employment do not, of course, receive adequate compensation from employers for their absence, even though it is a work of sacrifice and solidarity. And I think that's another challenge that we have to pay special attention to, and of course thank you to all those who have sacrificed themselves in this help.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: author. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent earthquakes in central Italy have caused nearly 300 victims and forced one hundred thousand people to leave their homes, their businesses, and procured billions of euros in material damage. Solidarity and closeness is not enough, citizens want answers from the Union and governments, to get a hard-hit territory back on its feet. Italy is at high seismic risk and is often lashed by climate events causing landslides, floods, landslides, landslides, like just days ago in the north west of the country. Citizens await resources and want them to be properly employed, for the prevention of disasters, to combat hydrogeological dissest, for securing homes, schools, hospitals and companies. It has been talking about it for decades, but the facts belie the promises made by all the governments that have come together. Complicating the picture, there are then the chains and constraints imposed by this Europe, which takes the breath away already in ordinary administration and which in cases of calamity, risks strangling the population and the people productive activities. The 5 Star Movement since the beginning of the legislature, insists on the discourage of the structural funds from the calculation of the deficit, one of the parameters of the Stability and Growth Pact. And today, coherently, calls for the exclusion of sustainable reconstruction, earthquake prevention and actions co-financed by structural funds according to the thematic objective, five. I appeal to all my fellow Members to support and vote on this position, expressed in the resolution in Compromise No 11. The Commission evaluates the Italian Government's application for the Solidarity Fund, but quickly and vigilantly so that the resources are used appropriately. Austerity is not fought by alternating current, at emergencies or electoral deadlines, but consistently and continuously and not instrumental.

name: Curzio Maltese
text: author. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, timeliness, effectiveness and prevention. I believe that my colleagues, many colleagues, beyond the different positions, agree, on pursuing these objectives. And the relationship is a step forward, but more remains to be done. Experience tells us that this Solidarity Fund, although it is limited, has not been fully used so far, although natural disasters are increasing in Europe, also due to changes climate. In 2014, for example, only 126 million were spent out of the 500 available. Also because the access thresholds are too high. We need to change that mechanism. Make it more functional. In what way? The simplest would be to lower the thresholds, which was proposed and the states rejected it. We propose as an amendment, also another solution, complementary to lowering thresholds, perhaps fairer, which is to calculate thresholds not only on the basis of a single event, but also by adding up damage suffered by the same region over one year, as a result of natural and repeated disasters. We brought here, all of us, the tragic experience of the people of Central Italy who had just begun to rebuild their cities, destroyed by the earthquake in August, when three more devastating shocks have annihilated the work done. But there is also the experience of regions, especially in Southern Europe, Italy, Portugal, Spain, Greece and Cyprus, where climate change, the bad policies of the territory, produce catastrophes that have now been happening they follow in series, leading populations to despair. So I wonder and ask you, what is the point of evaluating one by one events that are now connected, denying our solidarity to those who really need it most, based on a frosty bureaucratic algorithm?

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start with Mr Cicu’s report on the Solidarity Fund, and I would like to thank Mr Cicu and the Committee on Regional Development for this own—initiative report on the EU Solidarity Fund. Solidarity, as has been said here, is one of the fundamental values of the European Union. However, this value takes on even more importance when one of our Member States, regions or accession countries is hit by natural disasters.  The EU Solidarity Fund was created exactly for this purpose. As a speaker rightly said, two years ago we introduced a reform to make support from this fund better and simpler. We are currently assessing the impact of this reform, but we can already note some positive consequences.  First: clarity. Criteria for support from the Solidarity Fund are now much clearer. This means more transparency, but also greater ease for beneficiaries to prepare successful applications. Second: rapidity. Assessment and decisions on support are now speedier, not least thanks to Commission-streamlined procedures. Third: advance payments. Now we can ensure that shelter, clothes and food can be delivered while we are deciding on applications. Thanks to this possibility, Italy will be receiving EUR 30 million in advance payments already in December to help alleviate the consequences of recent earthquakes. But beyond these changes, the ongoing simplification of cohesion policy regulations should also help facilitate swift decisions on solidarity fund applications.  Sulla situazione in Italia dopo il terremoto quattro domande orali. Sono lieta di annunciare che le autorità italiane hanno recentemente introdotto la domanda per attivare il Fondo di solidarietà dell'Unione europea. Questa domanda riguarda i terremoti di agosto e di ottobre. Stiamo ancora lavorando con le autorità italiane per completare la valutazione dei danni causati dal terremoto in ottobre, poi saremo in grado di attivare concretamente il Fondo di solidarietà. Nel frattempo abbiamo già lanciato la procedura per assegnare un anticipo di 30 milioni di euro, che è il massimo consentito dal regolamento. Questo anticipo sarà già disponibile la settimana prossima e consentirà di sostenere gli interventi più urgenti. Ma, cari colleghi, e la solidarietà dell'Unione europea non si limita soltanto al Fondo di solidarietà. Anche la politica di coesione può e deve essere attivata. In questo contesto, la Commissione sta esaminando come i programmi della regione colpita dal terremoto possano essere adattati per sostenere la prevenzione delle catastrofi e il rilancio sociale ed economico nelle zone colpite da terremoti. Infine, ho proposto che i lavori di ricostruzione in caso di calamità naturali possono essere interamente coperti dai fondi strutturali, per esempio per la basilica di San Benedetto di Norcia.

name: Marco Valli
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Committee on Budgetary Control has drafted a very clear text, where we believe it is essential that the Solidarity Fund shall start towards a simplification of the procedures and evaluation criteria for the request for activation. This is to be as timely as possible in emergency situations, in the case of unpleasant disasters. At the same time, we believe that it is not possible to carry out a good check without total transparency, because it should not be allowed to speculate on emergency situations in the least. That is why in the report we call on the Member States and the Commission to make public and fully accessible all information on the use of the Solidarity Fund, something which has not been done to date and allowed in some cases, misuse of money, including the last earthquake that had happened to the Eagle. I would like to add personally, on behalf of the 5 Star Movement, that it is not acceptable, to hear about European spending constraints, at a time of demand crisis like this and like what we are in, and for long time less when catastrophes are in the way. For this reason, prevention and reconstruction measures should immediately be excluded from constraints for Italy and for all countries. This isn't populism, it's not demagoguery, it's simply common sense.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, 2016 has been a devastating year for the Italian people: Norcia, Amatrice, Preci. Hundreds of neighbors from whom the earth, in its virulence, took away life. Thousands of neighbors forced to seek refuge elsewhere after seeing their houses consumed. To allocate the necessary funds to rebuild homes, schools, health centers, churches, infrastructures is simply rebuilding lives. And this is where the principle of solidarity must be applied with greater intensity. I lived a similar experience when the land opened in my region, the region of Murcia, which then presided, ravaging a historic city, that of Lorca, and, worse, taking many human lives ahead. That is why I also show my solidarity with Italy, in general, and with the affected areas, in particular. I am aware of the economic and human implications caused by earthquakes. I know that this is when citizens most need the response of political institutions, especially the proximity of the institutions of the European Union. That is why, Commissioner, I call on the Commission greater flexibility in the budget with which to deal with such tragedies and unforeseen events. You, Mrs Crețu, are a sensitive person who is committed to these situations, and that is what we trust.

name: Tonino Picula
text: on behalf of the S&D Club. - Mr. President, the EU Solidarity Fund exists to provide financial support to Member States and accession countries after major natural disasters. From its founding until the end of July last year, a total of €4 billion was approved and paid out based on 72 requests from 24 countries. After several attempts in 2014, the Commission's proposals on amendments to speed up payment procedures were finally accepted. Advances are introduced and gives more time to use grants. The scope of application is clarified and promotes the prevention of damage from natural disasters. However, the Fund's biggest problem is certainly the slow payment of approved funds. Regardless of the reforms mentioned, it must take a minimum of up to 10 weeks until payment because permission must be given by both the Council and Parliament. In practice, the term is also longer. For example, money for floods that hit Croatia and other countries in the region in May 2014 The Commission approved it in October, but it was only confirmed by Parliament in December of the same year after a full 7 months. In the people there is the following saying: “Who helps immediately, helps double”. I believe that a stronger financial instrument is missing so that a larger share of the total cost of damages could be covered. At present, only 2 -5% of total damage is concerned. The advance payment rate should be increased from the current 10%. So we will really show solidarity and guarantee quick assistance to people affected by major natural disasters. It is worth avoiding situations when victims feel abandoned in a long period from disaster to payment of funds of the fund. This report and resolution on the consequences of catastrophic earthquakes in Italy are a good set of proposals to help the affected citizens as they improve the Commission's solutions. This relates to the duration of aid payments, prevention, implementation of ex ante conditions in cohesion policy, synchronisation of existing EU instruments, transparency in spending of allocated funds and cooperation of different levels of decision-making. I thank my colleague Cic for good cooperation and I invite you to adopt the report tomorrow.

name: Remo Sernagiotto
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I also wanted to thank the Commissioner for his speech, which I greatly appreciated. But I wanted to start with Mr Cicu's report, which pointedly indicates that we are very quick at these times. You see, in these such beautiful, but so difficult lands of Central Italy, lands that we know very well, the economy is all based on agriculture above all and its transformation, and agriculture — yesterday I was talking with the mayor of Amatrice — who explained to me that for 2 000 people, 1 100, there is winter, there is already snow, it's very cold. But those businesses cannot be left, those businesses are linked to animals, therefore to the people who live there and who care. But the importance of staying there, because the weather could be dramatic for those lands. We must not abandon them, neither people, nor that territory. It is a strategic territory, because abandoned it could become a territory, difficult for everyone, not just those who live there. So we need to speed up and give immediate answers. Meanwhile, that extraordinary trust, that those citizens, but not only those, those who see these acts, capable of giving answers, could be acts that would also help our Europe, if I have to be sincere, because today maybe it is no longer seen with great sympathy, instead, we believe that we must work a lot and in these moments, more, in order to make this Europe become sympathetic once again to all European citizens.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, I would like to begin by expressing my condolences to all the victims of recent natural disasters. As a Dutch MEP, I know what natural violence can bring about. The flooding disaster in the Netherlands of 1953 is still alive in my country and the need for prevention, the need for good water management is also passed on from generation to generation. It is therefore very good that Europe has a Solidarity Fund and in this way can show real solidarity with regions, countries and victims affected by natural disasters. I would like to thank Mr Cicu most sincerely for his work on his report, but I am critical of the efforts made by a number of political groups which have tried to bring about all sorts of new adjustments to the current regulation in the report. And the current regulation underlying the Solidarity Fund has been amended very recently, in 2014. The effects of this adjustment are hardly measurable. So again, I am critical of calls for the Commission to be reinstated and to come up with new proposals for readapting the current Solidarity Fund. And I am also critical, Mr President, when it comes to the resolution which says in paragraph 7 that investments in sustainable recovery, in earthquake-resistant investments should be excluded from the calculation of national deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact. That is unacceptable to my group, the ALDE. Above all, let us avoid investing where natural disasters are concerned, which may lead to minor financial disasters. So far.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, in general, I am in favour of the report submitted because changes and operational improvements are proposed in relation to simplification, speed in allocation of funds, reduction in processing times, and increasing the amount of advances and reducing the number of payments thresholds. However, I believe that an important opportunity to propose real improvement for disaster-affected populations is also missing. It would also have been time to extend the objectives of the Solidarity Fund to include humanitarian disasters and not just natural disasters; an excellent opportunity to use Community funds to alleviate, for example, the effects of the migration crisis, which is causing so many deaths on our borders. And, with regard to the threshold system, although it is true that the minimum threshold has been lowered, it is proposed equally for all regions. It would be fairer for poorer countries and regions to have easier access to funds, using a progressive threshold system, in which richer countries and regions would have higher thresholds than the poorest countries and regions. With regard to the amount allocated to the Fund — it has already been mentioned here: EUR 500 million a year — it should be noted that it has not changed since its inception in 2002 and that the consequences of climate change show a steady increase in natural disasters and that the forecast is even worse. Therefore, the financial amount of the Fund should be increased. And, last and certainly not least, I believe that the introduction of gender equality policies should have been considered as a criterion for the choice of proposals, since women are one of the groups that suffer most virulently the consequences of natural disasters, as reflected in many reports of the organizations such as the UN or the World Bank.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Thank you, President. Commissioner, honourable colleagues, today we are discussing a policy on insurance against natural disasters by the Member States of the European Union, the European Solidarity Fund. It ensures the Union's ability to help in the event of natural disasters. No less important is that the proposal also includes measures to increase efficiency, and I do not believe that the proposal to reserve the amount allocated annually to this fund in the budget of the European Union next year will result in considerable resistance. At the same time, I want to draw the attention of colleagues to the harmful trends that have begun to emerge after the recent natural disasters. As you know, the draft resolution is currently being debated in Parliament, calling for the costs of increasing resilience from one type of natural disaster — earthquakes — and only in a geographically restricted area. And why, in this case, other types of natural disasters, such as floods, landslides and other regions, are ignored? I think this is dangerous. The danger is that, in addition to the assistance that the European Solidarity Fund can provide, Member States will be able to pursue unsustainable financial policies. It is easy to guess what a precedent would mean for public finance management and the Stability and Growth Pact, especially when the concept of increasing seismic resilience is rather undefined. I would like to emphasise that the European Solidarity Fund is an effective aid instrument, but the aid instrument must have a defined budget and specific objectives and, most importantly, it cannot be allowed that some Member States justify a good economy by using the pretext of natural disasters violations of management rules.

name: Laura Agea
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am Umbrian, on 30 October I was at home with my daughter and I had to explain to her what was going on. And the same thing happened in the Marche and happened in Lazio. It's not easy to tell fear. It's not easy to tell it for me that I lived anyway and I live 100 kilometres from the epicenter of the quake. Imagine what they mean, seconds erasing centuries of history and destroying the prospects, the future, of thousands of families. This is the reality. Today, here we tell, we propose actions, but today in Norcia the temperatures are below zero and there are people who no longer have a home, people who have lost everything in a few moments. Then this Europe, if it still makes sense, if it exists, if it has a reason for being, beyond words, must demonstrate with concrete facts, immediate actions, its essence. Solidarity is a value and it is a principle only if we add the concrete factor to solidarity, only if our words become facts, only if people who have nothing today, because they have lost everything, they are put in the condition that they can continue to believe that there is a future. There are children who are trying to return to normal, but are there schools that are inaccessible and we talk about the difficulty of being able to release certain investments from the Stability Pact? We are talking about the future of our children and are you talking about budgetary constraints? Then you have to come and tell the children of Norcia, to the children of Tolentino, the children of Amatrice, that in the face of the disaster, the fear in which they have lived for months, there is a Europe that says that stability is a supreme good. Because to bail out the banks there is no stability he holds. And then, I claim, on behalf of the 5 Star Movement, on behalf of the citizens of Umbria, Tuscany, Marche, Abruzzo, to have a Europe that takes care of its citizens. I claim it, because that is due to the good of our children. The chatter is up to nothing. Solidarity is made of concreteness.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our Commissioner has reassured us on some points, but she does not tell us whether she considers the proposal coming from the people acceptable — and taken up by us populists that we are the worst in the world — who is insistently demanding, that justice be done towards that blood that is shed by the people, not by the lords of the banks or those who say we they talk every day about budget constraints. That is to extrapolate from the budgetary constraints, the sums sacrosanctly destined to the prevention and reconstruction and the productive, social relaunch of areas whose population has immediately returned to work, is attached to the territory. There are the shepherds, who are still there, have not abandoned the territory. Two things: the first, we want to know whether the Italian government participates in this popular motorcycle that calls for the release of the sums for reconstruction from the budget and secondly, if at least, we decide to present, the Italian government, the request strongly supported by the mayor of Amatrice on behalf of the 600 mayors of the earthquake zones, to implement the no tax area. It is necessary for this reason a procedure that comes from the Italian government, but from what you have told us, it seems to me that it has not even been put into place. Thank you very much for what you can do, these people deserve it. You don't look at those who are asking, you look at the faces through televisions, the faces of this extraordinary people of our country, who do not deserve to be represented by those who consider the constraints budget, like the Tables of Moses. They are not the Tables of Moses, they are the tables of banks and high finance. They are not the tables of peoples law. They are the tables of the financial international he commands in Europe.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). — (EL) Mr President, what is the importance to the European Union of the victims of laboratories in West Athens, or the devastating fire on Thassos, which has burned thousands of acres of forest and livestock crops? What is the significance for the European Union of the great fire in Chios, which burned down forest, mastic trees, crops, or in Northern Evia 25,000 acres of pine forest and with the redtino-producers now unemployed? What significance do earthquake workers and self-employed families in Lefkada after the earthquakes there mean to the European Union? Small things to deal with them, much more and to compensate them, while the Greek Government in many cases does not even bother to claim compensation from the European Union from funds paid for by the Greek people. In persistent questions from the Communist Party of Greece, the European Commission admits that, even if the European Union were to compensate the affected, it would be crumbs. It makes it clear that it does not compensate working grassroots households and self-employed people, who are objectively affected most by natural disasters, being unfortified and vulnerable to them. At the same time, funds relating to infrastructure prioritized by the large business groups, to which the large packet of Solidarity Fund money and other Eurofunds are directed, are provocatively considered eligible. The Communist Party of Greece demands immediate and full compensation for all those affected by natural disasters, immediate coverage of the chronic tragic deficiencies in infrastructure and modern means of protection against them.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Mr President! Commissioner, colleagues. The EU is a community of solidarity, and to ensure that this is not just a catchword, this Solidarity Fund has, among other things, been set up to help regions affected by natural disasters in particular to overcome the damage caused, while at the same time reducing human suffering as far as possible. The fund has certainly proved its worth since it was launched. However, as Mr Cicu's report shows, there are still many proposals on how to improve its application, particularly in terms of accelerating aid and providing financial resources. Another special report by the Court of Auditors would now be desirable to show us whether the funds have really all been used for the purposes for which they were intended. We should not forget, however, that the best protection against disasters is still preventive measures and this requires transnational cooperation, including exchanges of experience within the EU. After all, we do not even have civil protection plans in place in many countries. For me, however, civil protection and disaster assistance has nothing to do with the Stability and Growth Pact. This is a connection that, I think, is not allowed here.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too, like my colleague Angea was there, on the 24th night and 30 morning at 7.40 am, I experienced this terrible earthquake together with the community. An earthquake that does not stop, Mr President, Commissioner. I have heard from my colleagues, I thank them, all the Italian colleagues who spoke and also the other colleagues, who have obviously given full solidarity and support, but it is a particular earthquake, a calamity, particular. The shocks are continuing, they are widening to the old faults. Yesterday the earthquake at L'Aquila, this morning the quake near Reggio Emilia. The situation is particularly serious, and therefore, I gather the appeal of my colleagues, whom I thank the Committee on Regional Affairs, who have prepared this resolution, which is also important in Article 7, My colleague in the ALDE, I thank Mr Cicu, who, through his report, asks the Commission for more timely action, because this Europe must be done soon, with less constraints and more support. This Europe must stand next to sufferers, if it is not next to sufferers, those who have lost their homes, those who died, who should be next to? How our citizens could understand us, if we are not on these, at least on these occasions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: — Mr. President, the payment of the advance on the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund was introduced shortly after I became an MP in this House and then I truly wholeheartedly supported her. Unfortunately, the mobilization of the Fund is still not fast enough and effective, and the payment of the advance as a firefighting measure is devalued by administrative screams and slowness of bureaucracy. Just before the 2014 European elections Croatia was hit by terrible floods and a lot of people left without their homes and crops. Their existence was directly threatened, and the state reacted as quickly as it could. But in my opinion, not fast enough and not overly effective. The Croatian example best demonstrates the space for upgrading this mechanism, which is direct financial, but above all logistical assistance to members while humanitarian catastrophe takes place on their territory. All the rest of the help is welcome, of course, but it will always be perceived as overdue and insufficient.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to renew my solidarity with the affected populations, those who have lost their homes, to those who are victims of an earthquake that does not mention an end, well three seismic events concentrated in a very short space of time. I think it is important in this Chamber to also emphasize my thanks for those who are self-managed the emergency, for all those realities, such as the Brigades of Active Solidarity, which they carry every day, assistance and comfort to affected women and men. I believe that Europe should decide whether it matters more about the stability of banks or the stability of its citizens and its citizens. And it is clear that discourage from the Stability Pact and activation of the fund is a necessary measure, but it is not a sufficient measure. To date, for example, there are not enough technicians to carry out the inspections and there are those waiting for them from the first quake on August 24. I believe that it is necessary to counter the depopulation of mountain areas and prevent them from being built in that area, as paradoxically, is going to make the Renzi government, mega incinerators and even a Snam oil pipeline. Projects that would have been crazy regardless and that right now are even grotesque.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF).
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while we express uncompromised criticism of the policies of the European Union, we are nevertheless in favour of solidarity among European nations, especially in the face of natural disasters. Yes, the Europe of the nations we call for, is a Europe that protects the weakest of our compatriots. And it is in the face of the drama that she can best express herself. So yes, the Union Solidarity Fund must be made more accessible and efficient, especially to help our Italian friends in the face of the terrible earthquakes that struck the city of Amatrice. But if we really want to help Italy, it is now necessary that, in the Stability Pact, every euro spent on reconstruction should be excluded from the calculation of the deficit and that all European funds allocated to that region be reprogrammed for the reconstruction of the affected regions. Finally, the Commission must ensure that the Solidarity Fund will be devoted exclusively to Europeans confronted with natural disasters, and not to policies to welcome migrants, as some seem to want. I say yes to European solidarity with Italians, not to waste on migrants.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since its establishment to date, the Solidarity Fund has proved very useful for helping people in 24 different countries in difficulty for some seventy natural disasters, making available 3.8 billion euros. It is one of the symbols of the European Union in terms of solidarity, to meet those who have sometimes lost everything they possessed. Tomorrow morning we will vote on an instrument that is perfect. The report by Mr Cico, which I thank, goes in this direction: it serves to improve the instrument, because the improvement profiles are certainly there. We will also vote tomorrow on a budget transfer, to make available immediately 50 million euros to the fund, to meet the realisation of advances and not wait — as sometimes unfortunately happens — that there is a process to get to the disbursement of the sums. I have listened in this House to stand up against the possibility of taking earthquake or reconstruction investments from the Stability Pact calculations. As an Italian and European, I believe that every euro that is spent on avoiding deaths and disasters, helping people in distress, should be spent and taken away from the strict rules of austerity.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Italy is experiencing a very difficult time, shock has not yet passed and, among other things, earthquakes continue, one a day, even more, every day. After the time of demonstrations of proximity, the affected regions are now calling on Europe to apply and act according to two principles: flexibility and simplification. The procedures and the time of application of the Solidarity Fund are long and the advance will serve to begin to act, but flexibility and simplification serve above all to intervene with the Structural Funds. Reconstruction expenditure must be absolutely excluded from budgetary constraints, as well as expenditure on prevention. Because while it is true that unfortunately earthquakes are not predictable, the inadequacy of public structures and houses in the major Italian seismic areas and the need to make them safe now is demonstrated . What has collapsed in Italy is a piece of Europe and we are not asking Europe to replace our local government, we instead strongly ask Europe to put our government and ours regions under the conditions of making investments, rebuilding and modernizing, because otherwise those constraints, more than constraints, would be insurmountable obstacles.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I want to thank all the non-Italian Members who have expressed their solidarity with such a vast territory in our country that continues to be subjected to constant earthquake shocks. Saying it is easy. Living every day and every night, with the fear that the earth will still open, means living in conditions of total precariousness and unfortunately in our country almost every year there are devastating earthquakes. After L'Aquila, there was Emilia Romagna, there was Veneto, there was Lombardy and this summer, two continuous shocks. We were all there, us, in an earthquake zone. Near Rome the land continued to shake and you live continuously in the situation of instability. The impression because there being continuous aftershocks, perhaps 2.2 and 2.3, that do not produce damage, but they always give the impression of living on a soil that is not solid and that is not firm. So, therefore, for this reason, I think it is important to realize the difficulties that are there, the damage that continues to cause earthquakes. I am very pleased that the President of the Commission has decided to commit himself, not least so that we can rebuild the church of San Benedetto in Norcia. We also heard the Commissioner's words. The advance of 30 million euros is well, tourism must be supported and perhaps even, using the Horizon 2020 package, try to use funds for research in the seismological sector. Because the situation is much more serious than you can imagine and have died — and I conclude — Mr President, so are your fellow citizens. Not only Italian citizens died, Romanian citizens died, so European citizens, who worked, lived in our country. So, I repeat, the appeal is to realize what is the exceptional situation, including with regard to prevention. I don't know if it's right or not to touch the deal of stability. I do not think we should touch the Stability Pact in general, however, for this particular situation, I believe that a very careful look needs to be taken. It is right to have the public accounts in order, but here we are in such an emergency situation, that only those who have seen it, those who lived it and knew it can realize how serious it is, how much damage is there can be and how much fear there may be in the future. It is not easy to live 365 days a year with the pressure of constant fear of having to die, of seeing one collapse on the house.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as the previous colleagues said, the earth still continues to tremble in the heart of Italy, Italy which represents stories of civilization in Europe and of great beauty: places, artistic, architectural, cultural testimonies, expressions also of the deep religious feeling, the ability of enterprise that have made Italy unique in a Europe that cannot fail take charge of the fate of a territory and a community that belongs to it. Overcoming the constraints that make reconstruction difficult today is not in the interests of a single government, but must fall within the objectives of a Europe guarding its territorial realities, which in this case represent Italy, which does not resign itself to the ineluctability of its destiny. Today in the face of a politically relevant commitment of the Italian government, which declares that it wants to deal with determination the passage of the reconstruction of the housing fabric, but also of the enterprise of that territory and beyond, in an intervention never carried out in our country, that of securing public and private heritage, Europe cannot remain indifferent.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Crețu, I appreciated your truth, including linguistic. Yesterday we received some students and teachers here in Parliament from the prefabricated school which was set up in Amatrice, one of the most affected municipalities, along with Norcia and many others. I explained that Europe would be close to them. The priorities for the Italian government, you know, were the protection of citizens, the reopening of schools immediately, the provision of prefabricated housing, which are finally beginning to be, after the containers, the continuation of economic activities, such as livestock, agriculture and small businesses of commerce, the securing of houses and the great cultural heritage of the seismic areas. But, Europe must play its part, recognising a greater level of flexibility in calculating the deficit, excluding from the Stability Pact, as has been said, investment in reconstruction and reconstruction Prevention, while we appreciate, and I tell Commissioner Crețu, the availability and advance of the 30 million of the Solidarity Fund. It is necessary, however, and I hope that there will be a great openness on this, to change the operational plans of the Structural Funds as well, to invest in the prevention and quality of earthquake reconstruction which concerns in Italy the area, the whole Apennine belt. Thank you also for the availability of President Juncker, also reiterated here, for the reconstruction of the Basilica of Saint Benedict of Norcia, which we remember is the patron saint of Europe.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for your contributions to this rich debate, which of course highlights the importance of EU solidarity and of cohesion policy support, in particular in the dramatic situation that people are experiencing in central Italy.  As I said, and I repeat today, the Commission adopted a proposal to amend the Common Provision Regulation (CPR) to allow for 100% co-financing – so it’s not co-financing any more – regarding the construction costs in areas hit by natural disasters. This is not only available for earthquakes, it is not only available for Italy – because I had this question by Mr Ropé: ‘why only earthquakes?’ – it is everything related to natural disasters, and we did this not only for earthquakes but this year we just paid for Madeira for fires, for Cyprus for drought and fires, for Greece as well, so now with this amendment for the CPR all the reconstruction will be done by EU money without any need for co-financing. This is news today.  On this report by Mr Cicu, which is very important, on the Solidarity Fund, this own-initiative report presented by the Committee on Regional Affairs (REGI) and drafted by Mr Cicu emphasised also the main challenges we are facing. As I said two years ago, the reform of the EU Solidarity Fund allowed support to be made clearer and swifter, but also fairer, thanks to the advance payments. So, as I said, EUR 30 million will go next week to Italy as advance payments, and I would like to remind you that we have received the application from Italy just at the end of October, so of course we will assess the final sum, but we are coming as quickly as possible with the advance payment. The ongoing evaluation of this reform we adopted two years ago will provide further light on these improvements and allow for a possible further revision in the context of the future MFF post-2020.  For the Commission, flexibility and responsiveness of the Solidarity Fund is only one objective. Another one is respect for sound financial management, as well as assurances on the legality and the regularity of spending – as Parliament, especially the Committee on Budgetary Control regularly and rightly recalls. The Commission has to strike this balance between these two objectives which can obviously have an impact on the speediness of closure procedures. On the situation in Italy after the earthquake, in any case, as I say the Commission is supportive, is currently working with the Italian authorities to ensure that the EU Solidarity Fund is mobilised as soon as possible following the payment of the advance. Unfortunately Italy has been the leading beneficiary of the Solidarity Fund since 2002 with an amount of EUR 1.3 billion, so we are very much aware that there is a big problem, and it is the frequency of the earthquakes which is really very dramatic. Don’t forget that I am also coming from a country who lost many people in Amatrice, and I will be there in several days to speak with the Italian authorities in Rome, I will visit Amatrice and also Norcia, so we will see on the ground whatever it takes to help – and to help the citizens first of all, this is our first objective. We also stand ready to work with Italy on possible revisions of the programmes of the European Structural and Investment Funds. We have offered this opportunity and we are very open to rapidly change some operational programmes if needed and if the Italian authorities require. We expect these solidarity instruments to be supplemented by support from the European Solidarity Corps once it is established as announced by President Juncker.  Finally, we are exploring possibilities to help Member States and regions better handle the period between the disaster and the payment of EU support. In this context, one possibility could be setting up a bridging loan facility with the European Investment Bank which would help bridge this gap.  I would like to take this opportunity to reiterate the Commission’s full commitment to strengthen the various solidarity instruments of the European Union. I saw that there have been recurrent inquiries about the Stability and Growth Pact. I am not responsible for this, it is my colleague Mr Moscovici, but as you know short-term emergency and reconstruction costs related to major natural catastrophes are excluded from the Member States’ final effort. Regarding investments related to seismic risks, the Commission’s assessment will require ex-ante and ex-post data to be provided by the Italian authorities.

name: President. –
text: I have received eight motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 1 December 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — In the light of the serious situation in the areas affected by the earthquake, it is necessary to exclude, from the calculation of national government deficits under the Stability and Growth Pact, investments in sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention and also to consider extending the existing calculation of the Solidarity Fund, which is currently based on the effects of damage caused by a single catastrophic event, to a cumulative calculation of damage caused by several natural disasters in the same region in one year. I would also like to stress the importance of meeting the requirements relating to the construction of earthquake-proof infrastructure and buildings. Taking note of the application for intervention under the European Union Solidarity Fund submitted by the Italian Government, I call on the Commission to take all necessary measures to examine promptly requests for assistance under the Fund in order to ensure its rapid mobilization.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The earthquakes in central Italy in 2016 have affected homes, culture, people and loved ones. It is necessary to intervene in a timely and effective manner, not only to ensure a decent living but also, and most importantly, to secure these areas and the whole country. These are absolutely necessary and urgent measures and, thanks to our contribution, the adopted resolution calls on the Commission to allow investment for reconstruction to be removed from the statement of debt to comply with the stability pact. This is a very important result for our country, which we hope will follow a decision by the Commission in this regard.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. — Created in 2002, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) is a necessary non-refundable financial instrument for emergency and rescue actions carried out by the authorities following natural disasters which have a direct impact on people's lives, the natural environment or economy in a particular affected region. Over time, the EUSF has undergone several revisions with a view to its development, at least in the light of the process, procedures, time period, content, notions with which it operates, aid effectiveness assessment indicators, scope/scope. This is because the evidence shows that, as a result of climate change, natural disasters within the EU are constantly growing in terms of their number, severity and intensity. The impact and importance of the EUSF in promoting sustainable solutions shall increase if, in this context, other European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) are used appropriately and synergistically by national, local and regional authorities, in particular for the purpose of prevention natural disasters, based on specific effective strategies. Obviously, the authorities should disseminate by modern means to the general public information on both EUSF aid (including monitoring of its progress) and on the results of aid already granted since 2002.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Written. — I regret the fact that Italy has been shaken by as many as three strong earthquakes this year. The last one, which was in October this year, has left huge consequences. A huge number of people were injured, and as many as 290 died, material damage was thunderous. On this occasion, I express my deep and sincere condolences to our neighbours. What happened in Italy can happen right to all of us, so I think it is essential that we as the European Union are in this situation solidarity and to Italy, which needs our help, also help. I believe that the Commission should take measures as soon as possible to address requests for assistance to affected areas under the European Union Solidarity Fund immediately. This would allow buildings to be restored in the affected areas as soon as possible and thus eliminate the effects of the earthquake more quickly. It is also essential that competent authorities at all levels simplify administrative procedures in order to make access to funds as easy and quick as they are necessary for residents of affected areas.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Union Solidarity Fund, although financed outside the EU budget, is an important instrument for joint response by Member States in the event of dangerous disasters or natural disasters. The fund has so far launched €3.8bn as a response to more than 70 disasters, almost all European Union countries. It is therefore a clear symbol of EU solidarity in difficult times. I am positively assessing the recent reform of the principles of the operation of the fund, which simplified the procedures for applying for aid and the possibility of payment of advances. However, in view of rapid response considerations, the Commission should consider increasing the threshold for prepayments paid and reducing the time limits for processing applications. Effective assistance to victims of natural disasters also requires better coordination at Member State level and improved procedures in emergency states. In the course of future discussions on the EU Solidarity Fund, it is also necessary to consider using its resources as widely as possible to assist Member States affected by terrorist attacks and to prevent these threats. In that case, the Treaty solidarity clause requires the Union and its Member States to act together using all instruments at their disposal.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Pascal Durand, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on Commissioners’ declarations of interests – guidelines (2016/2080(INI)) (A8—0315/2016).

name: Pascal Durand
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, we are here in a debate which is absolutely major. It may seem technical, since we will talk about the possible modification of a code of conduct and conflicts of interest. In fact, this debate is, as you know, in a very particular context for Europe, at a time when European citizens, sometimes rightly doubt, that Europe is defending the general interest, the common good, and not necessarily private interests or particular interests. We must therefore be very attentive to this issue. The question of transparency, control and functioning of our institutions is, as the European question stands, of major importance. Transparency is one of the pillars of democracy and, more than ever, we need to be exemplary in this regard. The situation has worsened in recent times. A number of debates, not to use too loud words, took place, including the passage of former Commission President Barroso in a private bank, Goldman-Sachs, which had a very direct connection with the 2008 financial crisis. Of course, these elements must be taken into account. Sometimes I wonder whether the Commission is fully aware of this reality. When we asked Commissioner Moscovici, who was in your place recently, he explained to us that there was no problem, and that the code of conduct of the Commission and the Commissioners was perhaps among the best — I do not know if he did not even say “the best” — in the world! For me, it's just a denial of reality; it's the Coué method which consists of saying that everything is fine. No, everything is not fine! In order for things to change, so that we can move towards more transparency and more control, two committees in this European Parliament have unanimously approved, and I stress, both reports — the Committee on Budgetary Control and then the Committee on Legal Affairs. This unanimity must also call upon the Commission, as it shows how united the European Parliament is, I would say, in this effort to amend rules which are currently dysfunctional. So, what is malfunctioning? I will deal very quickly with two elements, namely conflict of interest and the code of conduct. Let's talk first of all about conflicts of interest. At the time when Commissioners take up their posts, at this stage, they must declare only what they consider themselves to be likely to create a conflict of interest. However, this concept is not defined anywhere. The first thing to do is to define what a conflict of interest is. We do so in this report, and we ask that the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament be able to check the financial statements and assets in order to determine whether or not there is a conflict of interest. This will simply be a matter of applying the separation of powers. This is a significant advance, and it must be implemented. We ask for the same thing during the term of office, when there is a change in assets, financial interests or portfolio. That is for the issue of conflict of interest and, of course, this requirement must be extended to family interests, since this is the case during the term of office. The second question is the Code of Ethics and the Code of Conduct. At this stage, Commissioner, you and all your colleagues have a duty of honesty and delicacy. This is not defined anywhere. Define what is meant by honesty and delicacy. Ensure that the ethics committee, currently in charge of monitoring, is composed of independent experts and is completely protected from pressures from private interests or the Commission. I'll add a third element. We you let us ask to ensure that, for the three years following your term of office, you do not have the opportunity to go to work in the private sector in areas that you have had to know in the performance of your duties as commissioner. Commissioners are paid for that; it is not outrageous. You see, the changes we ask for are not exaggerated. What we want is simply an alignment of the Commission's operating rules with what is happening in all democracies around the world.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, the Commission welcomes the contribution to the debate from Mr. Durand's report on envisaged guidelines for Commissioners’ declarations of interests. This shows Parliament's interest in this subject, which is of course an important part of the democratic scrutiny exercised by this House of the Commission and its Members. Let me therefore respond to a few issues.  I would first thank Mr Durand for the report and the other Members and committees for their work. The President of the European Commission, whom I am replacing here today, considers the highest ethical behaviour to be of paramount importance for the credibility of the EU institutions. I would also recall that the rules of the Treaties and the Code of Conduct of our Commissioners are clear; they represent standards that go well beyond those applied in the majority of Member States and in the other European Union institutions.  With its Code of Conduct, the Commission is subject to the highest ethical standards. Let me underline that some of the matters covered by the report already correspond to the current ethical framework and procedures. For instance, it is already the case that any situation entailing a possible conflict of interest which might impair the independence of a Member of the Commission during his or her mandate has to be notified to the President of the Commission. The President will then take appropriate measures, including reallocation of the file to another Member of the Commission, if necessary. The President will also inform in due time the President of the European Parliament of his decision to reallocate any file to another Commissioner. Regarding membership of what the report describes as secret societies which could interfere with the exercise of the function of public bodies, I should stress that the Treaties themselves and the Code of Conduct already provide that Commissioners must discharge their duties in the general interest of the Union without seeking or taking instructions from any other body.  In addition, other recommendations are already being implemented. For example, the report mentions the three-year transitional allowances for former Commissioners. Let me point out that these rules were recently, in February this year, amended by the Council. The new rules will apply to all Commissioners and other EU public office holders who took up office after 4 March 2016. The transitional allowances will in the future be paid for a maximum of two years. The report proposes the extension of former Commissioners’ cooling-off periods to two years. President Juncker wrote to President Schulz on 23 November 2016 informing him of his intention to modify the Code of Conduct in order to extend this period from 18 months to three years, as regards the President of the Commission, and to two years, as regards the other Members of the Commission.  I would like to underline that the Ad Hoc Ethical Committee is composed of personalities who are not Members of the Commission or Commission staff.  Their qualifications and independence are beyond any doubt and they gave a very independent opinion to the Commission. Allow me to note that the European Parliament's Advisory Committee on the Conduct of Members, which gives guidance on the interpretation and implementation of the Code of Conduct for Members, is composed of Members of the same Parliament.  Finally, I would like to recall that, in line with the Framework Agreement between the European Parliament and the Commission, the Commission has the right to be consulted before any changes in Parliament's Rules of Procedure directly affecting the Commission are decided. The possible need to amend the Framework Agreement also needs to be examined. The Commission will pursue its dialog with Parliament and will come forward with further remarks and comments as and when needed. Thank you very much.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. — (DE) Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen. Glad we can talk about this. Mr Vice-President, I would have liked a little more of what you are prepared to take on board our proposals, both from Mr Durand's report and from my opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control, which has been dealing with the Code of Conduct for a very long time. We want it to be revised to include financial interests and assets, liabilities over EUR 10 000. We want to disclose all interests — shares, board memberships, advisory services, memberships in affiliated foundations and all the companies to which future Commissioners have consulted. We also want to extend this to dependent dependants. Why? Because we have to take the conflict of interest very seriously, because we want to prevent future scandals. We also want to redraw up the Ethics Committee. It's not like this one is independent. It consists of former employees or former consultants. He's not transparent. We want its decisions to be published. We want you to understand how he works and what he did. There is no annual report on his activities so far, there is nothing at all. That is why I can only say: do not go on like the Barroso Commission. There are almost completely free things that improve the Commission's reputation. And it would be our urgent wish for you to respond to this while there is still time.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President! Commissioner! The most important thing is that we are convinced today about one thing: that the European Parliament and the European Commission on this issue are on one side. We are not against the Commission — the Commission is not against Parliament. We must ensure that the good name of the European institutions, those working in them, does not undermine the trust of citizens in the European Union. And then we will surely come to the target, which Gräßle's colleague mentioned, and which Durand was talking about. Why does the Law Commission care so much about these changes? Well, we are responsible for conducting, at the outset, when creating the College of Commissioners, such a small investigation — even though we are neither the prosecution nor the court — whether all that is in the financial statements is actually in line with reality and is not there is conflict of interest. However, we do not have, as a Law Commission, the appropriate instruments to be truly satisfied that we have checked what has been checked. So these requests are moving towards streamlining the verification process so that we can achieve success together. Members of the College of Commissioners are the highest officials in the European Union. If there are any uncertainties, if there are any issues that may lead to a scandal, it is not only the responsibility of the individual commissioner or the college of commissioners — it is a stone cast in the calm water of the whole European Union. And we do not want to ruffle this lake, we want it to be peaceful, so that we can work together for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. The declarations of the financial interests of the Commissioners-designate of the Commissioners-designate are intended to ensure the highest level of transparency, honesty, altruism and responsibility — that is the top priority for us Socialists. The European institutions have an exemplary role here. Cases like Neelie Kroes are not allowed to occur in the future. Activities such as those of Miguel Arias Cañete must be excluded from the outset. We in the Committee on Legal Affairs are examining not only whether the statement has been properly completed, but also whether there is a potential conflict of interest. The absence of a conflict of interest is a mandatory condition for hearing the Commissioners-designate, and we did not have this broader right of scrutiny with the Commission. It is particularly important to me that not only spouses or partners are specified in the financial declaration of interest, but also details of any contractual relationship that may give rise to a conflict of interest for the Commissioners-designate while pursuing their obligations as Commissioners.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, I attach great importance to changing the rules of Commissioners to promote transparency in decision-making. Clear sanctions should be imposed on the hiding of tie-ups in order to actually announce tie-ups. For example, former commissioner Neelie Kroes's affiliation with offshore companies went undisclosed in the original tie-up review. At that time, he was elected by a meager majority as commissioner. As a result of the posthumous links, Kroes can no longer be subject to sanctions, so punishments for breaches of the rules are clearly inadequate. Definitions of bondage must also be clarified so that the obligation to notify is not subject to interpretation. This is necessary for the credibility of decision-making.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, the report on the declarations of financial interests of Members of the European Commission, which we are debating today, has the central idea that the scrutiny of these statements should be made more thorough and rigorous. This is absolutely necessary to protect the credibility of the European Union itself, especially at a time when a series of events such as the placing of former President Barroso in a key position in a private bank shortly after his departure from the The Commission concludes that there are inconspicuous links with private interests. Moreover, when examining the declarations of financial interests of the members of the Juncker Committee in 2014, it became apparent that the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament needs to be given more powers and more comfortable time to enable it to establish the any mistruths or omissions of such statements. There have been cases of Commissioners, such as Mr Cañete's, where the content of the statement or other elements raised open questions but these were not adequately investigated. Commissioners are not enough to look honest. They have to be honest. The European Left will therefore support this report in tomorrow's vote, and we hope that the necessary amendments to the relevant rules will follow.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, the code of conduct for Commissioners adopted in 2011 is not sufficiently demanding in terms of controlling the financial interests of Commissioners. This laxity has led to several scandals, the most famous of which concerns Neelie Kroes, the former Commissioner for Competition, who has just been discovered to run an offshore company during her tenure. I therefore endorse the Durand report, which is trying to improve this control. However, I doubt that any effectiveness will be achieved. Basically, the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament do not want too deep investigation into the financial interests of Eurocrats. As proof of this is the decision to appoint and retain Mr Miguel Arias Cañete as Energy Commissioner, despite the conflicts of interest that have been discovered and denounced on several occasions. The European Union has denied European values in favour of the cult of the golden calf. It is entirely dominated by lobbies, financial powers and thirst for profit. That is why it covers the actions of its leaders, who are the worthy representatives of it. The fight against conflicts of interest requires the first disappearance of the European Union.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, I support the proposal, but I would like to stop on one particular topic. It is certainly good news when we hear that the majority understands that a conflict of interest is dangerous for democracy and wants to ensure that they take on decision-making in specific areas within governance not directly involved those who are in conflicts of interest. That's good news, because the voters demand it of us. But the second question is how do we want to implement this goal. And here I must say, unfortunately, that I am not convinced that all the procedures proposed in the report will ensure the effective implementation of these objectives. Through minimizing conflicts of interest in the public sphere, we primarily want to ensure that our citizens have greater confidence in their institutions. Each institution has its place in the system and is supposed to have competencies corresponding to that position in the system. The European Parliament is not, in my view, the institution that should act as an investigating institution. I think she is not gifted to do this in principle, her success in these activities is not so guaranteed, and as a result it can hurt our reputation. I hope that my concerns will not be fulfilled, I hope that increasing transparency and limiting conflicts of interest through this proposal will be achieved.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: — As a member of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs, I welcome the initiative of our colleagues to change the legal framework on the regime of incompatibilities of Commissioners and the declaration of interests. The changes made by this new document represent a step forward in combating abuse, supporting transparency and - why not? - increasing confidence in the European institutions. I therefore take the opportunity to mention an example of the press, but also in the debates that took place on this issue in the European Parliament. I am referring here to the former Commissioner for Agriculture, Dacian Ciolos, who currently has two incomes. He receives a daily allowance as a former commissioner worth about 8 300 euros per month, while he receives the salary of Romanian taxpayers from the Romanian taxpayers. I do not know whether we can refer to this as incompatibility, but we have certainly taken advantage of the absence of clear legal provisions. I am sad that such possible abuses can be committed by an experienced politician, but I am glad that we managed in this final draft on the regime of incompatibilities and the declaration of interests to combat such immoral solutions by introducing precise measures on such situations. Thank you.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Madam President, what we already knew has recently been confirmed, namely that top officials of the European Commission, even its President, Mr Barroso, are exposed to conflicts of interest. This makes it imperative and absolutely necessary that stricter frameworks of control of conflicts of interest which prevails at many levels in the European Union should be set up at last. This is also what my report, which was adopted last Thursday in Strasbourg, on the action of the European Ombudsman, points out. This is where the European Ombudsman is instructed to check the legality of Mr Barroso's appointment to Goldman Sachs. This also forced Mr Juncker to change course and propose, on the day my report was debated in Strasbourg, that the Commissioners' own code of conduct should be changed. So it turns out that measures and action are needed for full transparency in the European Union, so that there is no conflict of interest at all levels.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: Madam President, indeed, the principle of integrity and the principle of independence imposed on the members of the Commission are at the very heart of the Treaties.
