That is why it is important for the Commission to be at the forefront of ethical standards and standards of democracy. It must truly be a policy in the service of integrity. I just said something. I heard allusions to Miguel Arias Cañete. He scrupulously complied with the entire Code of Conduct, even went beyond the Code. Also with his statement of interest, his wife and his family. In no case was there any conflict of interest. And you tell a lie when the truth is missing. The truth is lacking when one thing is constantly repeated which is not true and therefore I would remind you that, if we preach seriousness, please also preach it in speeches and not attribute something that has not happened to Miguel Arias Cañete's person.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, you are telling us in essence: 'Move around, there is nothing to do; there is no problem! '. But, once again, our debates have to do precisely with the conflicts of interest of the European Commissioners. It almost becomes a habit. Last October we were talking about the case of Mrs Kroes and the Bahamas Leaks, previously it was Mr Barroso and Goldman Sachs, and now it is Mr Oettinger and his flights with a lobbyist close to Moscow. It is a new conflict of interest that President Juncker would like to “sanction” through promotion, in defiance of Parliament's opinion. This is simply unacceptable! What we are asking for is that Parliament should have a vote, and even more strongly, not only at the time of the inauguration of Commissioners, but also at repeated intervals during the term of office and, in particular, if there is a change in portfolio. We want to be able to verify that there is no conflict of interest, and we also want to be able to ensure that, in the code of conduct as revised, conflicts of interest are avoided after the commissioners' term ends. There is an urgent need to review our rules because it is transparency and exemplarity that will give meaning to the European project.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President! We should almost thank Commissioner Oettinger for having just come forward as a veterinary horse in the conflict of interest problem in support of our proposal for a resolution we are currently debating. In particular, I am talking about the fact that, contrary to the interests and common policies of the European Union, the Government of Hungary is endowing Hungary to an external power — specifically Russia — through the contract of the Paks II nuclear power plant. He would promote the push through of this, which is questionable in all respects, through the European Commission with the interference of a Russian pro-lobbyist, relying on the help, influence and advice of the in-office Commissioner Oettinger, who, by the way, Mr Oettinger, travels to Hungary on a private jet. If, after the Barroso case, such an evident offence remains without consequences, this is in itself an urgent reason for a thorough review of the European Commission's rules on conflicts of interest. But it is now up to the European Parliament and its responsibility to put an end to the Commission's opaque, unethical, self-exonerating practice.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the rapporteur Durand is completely right when he says that after events such as those which have affected the former Commissioner Barroso we need to act and act quickly, the credibility of the European institutions goes away. It is clear that if a new code of conduct comes in for Commissioners, this new code must be written by an independent committee. I also think that the independent committee should have the possibility of autonomous intervention, not conditioned by balances and internal policy to the institutions. Heavier penalties are needed. The heaviness of penalties must be the consideration of the offence identified and must also have a deterrence effect, which is always important in these cases. Still the suspension time between the end of activity and the new professional cycle must be longer, but I would add that for some activities I believe that it will be necessary to even foresee the foreclosure of a possible placement in the future by the Commissioners.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the control of statements of financial interests and more generally of potential conflicts of interests concerning the members of the Commission cannot be limited to the appointment procedure alone. Any substantial change in the financial interests of a Commissioner in the course of office or any allocation of responsibilities between members of the Commission must be the subject of a procedure of consideration by Parliament. The statement of financial interest must include interest or assets present or past over the past two years of an asset, professional and personal nature, including extended to the family. The Commission must review and tighten the Code of Conduct in order to adhere to high ethical standards and ensure that the declaration of financial interests provides to Parliament and citizens accurate information. It is crucial to extend the incompatibility period from the current 18 months to at least five years for the Commissioners and the President of the Commission. Stricter rules are certainly not sufficient to ensure ethically correct behaviour, but they are undoubtedly an indispensable starting point towards a more transparent relationship.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, to conclude, let me emphasise that the Commission welcomes Parliament’s input into the reflection on how the code of contact for Commissioners can be improved, and will inform Parliament about the follow—up it will give to the present reports. I, myself, I agree with all the speakers who have practically said that that the behaviour of politicians not only has to be impeccable, but also has to be perceived as impeccable.

name: Pascal Durand
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, I will go right to the point: since you have heard us, make sure to report to the Commission and its President that Parliament is unanimous in calling for rules to be put in place which would simply make us grow together. The Europe to which we are committed and we hold is a democratic Europe, under construction; it is evolving. It would grow, all of us would grow and we would have a much stronger weight in civil society if we were to show that transparency and the absence of conflicts of interest are at the heart of the Commission's and the European Parliament's concerns. So let us make this Europe grow, let us do it together, naturally, and not against each other. Let us ensure, as France has done, for example, to establish an independent high authority. Everyone wins and, little by little, confidence is recovering. It's simple, it's democratic, and we all have to gain.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 1 December 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The rules regarding Commissioners’ declarations of interests are woefully vague. So much so that it is almost completely at the subject’s discretion, what financial details are put forward for consideration. Commissioners decide, completely on their own, what financial interests or activities might be ‘likely to constitute a conflict of interest’ and there is no regular reporting when these interests are updated. This report, which I will be supporting is a move in the right direction however it must be followed up by the European Commission. I will further be supporting an amendment which will extend Commissioners’ post-office employment restrictions to three years.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Since 2014 scandals have been highlighting the problems related to the Commissioner’s declaration of interest. Commissioner Canete’s scandal, President Barroso’s case has proven that we need a Code of Conduct, which improves the restrictions of the post-office employment and strengthens the competence of the ad-hoc Ethical Committee responsible for the assessment of conflict of interests. Unfortunately the proposal President Juncker presented recently, which would increase the lobby ban from 1.5 to 3 years for the President of the Commission and to extend the cooling-off period for Commissioners from 1.5 to 2 years is an insufficient one. Former commissioners are entitled to a transitional allowance for three years, precisely prevent conflicts of interest, but in the meanwhile they can start working as a lobbyist after only two years? That is unacceptable and imbalanced. Such measures are exactly the reasons for extremists and Euro-sceptics to criticizing the EU institutions. Besides the 3 years ban former Commissioners should be required to make publicly available all information on their meetings and telephone calls with officials of the European Institutions or officials of the governments of the Member States up to 10 years after they have ceased to hold office.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — If the European Commission and the European Union as a whole wish to remain credible in the eyes of the voters, the former Commission President cannot be allowed to pass the evidence to Goldman Sachs, which played the lion's role in triggering the global economic crisis, a year and a half after the end of his mandate. Nor should the former Energy Commissioner be allowed to fly to Budapest on a private jet of a pro-Russian businessman to advise the Hungarian government on the expansion of Paks. That needs to be changed. That won't happen again. There is a need to tighten the Code of Conduct for Commissioners still in office and already departed. Therefore, I fully support the proposal that EU commissioners should only be authorised by the College for three years after the end of their mandate. They can only take a job that does not give rise to a suspicion of conflict of interest. You cannot be an oil lobbyist if you have previously been an EU Commissioner responsible for environmental protection. This is the basis for a functioning, credible and democratic European Union. Enforcement of the Code of Conduct is the political responsibility of the European Parliament. As elected MEPs, we will always continue to act in the future when we see that the activities of a Commissioner raise ethical issues.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — This is not a matter to be taken lightly. Barroso, Kroes, this week's case of endocrine disruptors, the multiple scandals centred on the Commission maintain a disastrous image of the European institutions and a failing ethics! Both internal procedures in the European Parliament, when the new Commission is appointed and during its term of office, and the transparency obligations of the members of the Commission must be addressed. The verification of the absence of a conflict of interest cannot be put to the same level as the assessment of the candidate's competencies. It must therefore be an indispensable prerequisite for the hearing. The control of declarations of financial interests and, more broadly, of potential conflicts of interest concerning the members of the Commission must extend beyond the Commission's appointment procedure alone. I also expect from the Commission a series of amendments to its code of conduct and declarations of interest to ensure that these include sufficient information to assess the Commissioners' financial interests and that Parliament is informed of any changes.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Increasing the level of scrutiny regarding the Commissioner-candidates’ declarations of financial interests is absolutely necessary and does not come a moment too soon. We should do our utmost to verify the truthfulness of the declarations by actually investigating, instead of accepting them prima facie. We really do not need more scandals like those that arose out of Cañete and Kroes’ omissions. This report rightfully calls for a revision of the Commissioners’ code of conduct; however, I am disappointed by the fact that the proposal to put some of the Commission’s budgetary resources in reserve, until this revision actually happens, was not adopted. This would have motivated the Commission to implement substantial, not merely cosmetical, changes. Right now, they seem to be so out of touch with reality that they didn’t even blink an eye when Oettinger made controversial remarks and accepted a flight on a lobbyist’s private jet. Instead of appropriate repercussions, Oettinger received a promotion to the post of vice-president. Even his hearing in the Parliament was replaced with a simple exchange of views. These sorts of practices play right into the hands of pro-Kremlin eurosceptics.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the short presentation of the report by Kostas Chrysogonos, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on liability, compensation and financial collateral for offshore oil and gas operations (A8-0308/2016) [2015/2352 (INI)]

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, the report on liability for offshore oil and gas exploitation is the result of a long attempt to make changes for the benefit of Europe and its citizens. The proposals in this report not only affect economic activities but also aim to support the environmental needs of the European region. Work related to oil and gas production has a significant economic impact but also high environmental hazard. Most of the oil and natural gas activities take place either in the North Sea or in the Mediterranean. In view of the nature of this work, it is extremely important to ensure the protection of undertakings which are directly linked to the environment. The commercial fisheries sector and the people involved in the aquaculture sector can suffer significant economic losses from accidents or incorrect use of chemicals. Businesses in the tourism sector could also suffer financial losses from the reduction of customers due to possible related accidents. It is therefore obvious that we need to lay down rules to protect all these economic activities located close to offshore activities, the exploitation of oil and gas fields, especially given that over 90% of oil and 60% of the oil. gas produced in Europe comes from such offshore activities. It is also of the utmost importance that there are compensation mechanisms for damage caused by offshore activities and similar mechanisms aimed at restoring ecosystems. The current European Directive makes holders of offshore licences responsible for preventing and restoring all environmental loss resulting from their activities. It also requires Member States to establish procedures for handling claims for damages. However, the directive does not deal with liability for damage to natural or legal persons in respect of injury or financial damage, nor with criminal liability for offshore accidents. It is therefore necessary to assess the importance of further harmonised rules and a compensation mechanism for offshore accidents in order to facilitate victims' access to justice. In order to promote this harmonisation, the possibility of creating a fund on the basis of fees paid by offshore industries could also be considered. We also need a European Union action plan to prevent and combat the consequences of oil and gas accidents. Their impact has serious and long-term implications for the marine environment and this should be taken into account in the directive. The Commission should cooperate with the Member States in order to speed up the relevant procedures. Risk analysis and environmental impact assessment for offshore activities could also be published regularly, according to parameters such as biodiversity, climate change, sustainable soil use, protection of the marine environment and appropriate training of personnel before any licensing business. It is my personal belief that prevention is better than treatment, and institutionalisation of criminal responsibilities at a pan-European level could be a further deterrent, in addition to existing civil sanctions, thus leading to better protection of the environment and the citizens.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President! I very much agree with the report, all activities that damage the environment and human life must be linked to collective redress, and serious sanctions must be applied. Yet the relevant 2013 directive has not been transposed in all Member States, so I call on the Commission to encourage Member States by all possible means to remedy it. However, I consider the 'polluter pays' principle to be an important tool for preventing damage, which we have already underlined in other areas, for example in the resolution on the red sludge disaster in Hungary. For my part, I would completely remove the use of fossil oil and gas, of course, while ensuring gradual gradation, as this is an endless risky operation. In this area, too, the Commission should encourage Member States to put more emphasis on renewable energy sources.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Madam President, oil and gas are half the energy mix of the European Union and will continue to be the main sources of energy for several years to come. At the same time, an increasing proportion of these sources come from offshore activities. It is therefore of major importance to ensure a high level of safety and the prevention of natural disasters from these offshore activities. The Deepwater Horizon accident in the Gulf of Mexico cost billions of dollars to the American economy. We therefore understand that a similar accident in an enclosed sea such as the Mediterranean would be disastrous, and that is why stricter rules and standards should be laid down on the liability of the oil companies and, because these disasters do not stop at the borders of the states, this high security in offshore oil operations must apply everywhere. In particular, in view of the work in the Ionian and Adriatic, Albania should comply with these rules and finally cease to claim the Greek EEZ.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank this House, and in particular the rapporteur Mr Chrysogonos, for your support and work on this complex legal fight. I would also like to thank you for your thoughts and comments on our report on liability, financial security and compensation in the offshore oil and gas sector.  Let me address some of the vital issues that came up in your report and today’s debate. You have asked the Commission to take new initiatives which may have a large impact on citizens and the offshore oil and car gas industry. After an initial analysis, the Commission will examine in detail your proposals and consider how best to carry out the assessment and the collection of more information, as suggested. Your report provides valuable policy lines for the offshore oil and gas sector, which will guide our work. It underlined certain weaknesses of the current legal framework with regards to many questions surrounding liability when offshore accidents happen. We are very grateful for this constructive and substantive contribution, which provides a structure of issues to be dealt with in the near future.  Furthermore, before deciding on new legal initiatives, we need to know what progress has been made on these subjects in Member States when implementing the directive. The deadline for implementation of the Offshore Safety Directive was 19 July 2015. At the latest in 2019, when the Commission will assess the implementation of the directive, taking into account the efforts of Member States, specifically their competent authorities, the report will include as appropriate its proposals for amending the directive and, if necessary, for additional initiatives. It is clear that the issues examined in the 2019 report, also in line with your proposals, should include an in-depth analysis of questions regarding liability, compensation and financial security for offshore and gas operators, with the objective of addressing potential shortcomings.  In the meantime, the Commission will exchange and discuss with the Member States respective experiences of practical implementation on a permanent basis, and specifically in the framework of the existing European Offshore Authorities Group. When carrying out the dialogue with Member States on these sensitive issues, we will take the utmost account of the contribution from the European Parliament, upon which we can build. We will bring your issues forward in the European Offshore Authorities Group, and in any other available forum. Both in expert groups and high—level groups, the Commission will refer to your report, which establishes clear guidance and potential target lines of where we should get to, for the benefit of EU citizens.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. — In April 2010, after an accident, the Deepwater Horizon oil rig sank, resulting in nearly 5 million barrels of crude oil spilled into seawater. The trouble was caused only by a device — the breakout detector — but yet it entered history as one of the greatest natural disasters ever. Of course, it is a legitimate expectation that, learning from the American example, Europe should not only try to prevent a similar disaster, but also be prepared to deal with it both technologically and legally. However, we must be very careful that this kind of effort does not suffocate the industry we want to regulate. Oil and gas extraction in the North Sea and the Mediterranean is essential for Europe's energy supply. It is important that companies extracting these regions do not feel that we are striving to make them impossible, but to see a helping hand in the Union, which settles legal relations and helps to minimise risks. In addition to protecting existing extraction, it is at least as important not to discourage potential future investments. The mineral resources of the Black Sea, the eastern Mediterranean or the Barents Sea could be a long-term solution for Europe's energy supply, which would greatly help reduce dependence on external suppliers. We must endeavour to ensure that all regulations we introduce stabilize the business environment and create predictability.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work on this report, which is essential to minimise the damage of a possible accident in offshore oil and gas operations: even more so when the Union is promoting its development without taking into account its risks and its environmental, social and economic impact. In particular, I share the need to establish a compensation mechanism to protect potentially affected sectors, such as fishing and tourism, to enable victims to have recourse to justice and to ensure, through specific contributions, that the offshore oil and gas industry actually pays. Measures which, as the report emphasizes, should be extended to the overall framework. I hope that the Commission will take good note of these recommendations in order to ensure that it is the companies profiting from offshore oil and gas activities that actually pay the cost of any accident.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: — Thank you, Madam President. Today's farmers' concerns are mainly related to the exploitation of products at acceptable prices, allowing them to survive on the market. Large chains of grocery stores, especially in Western Europe, have a close partnership with local farmers, which is a very good thing. Romania has implemented this concept by law 150/2016, so that traders are going to purchase certain products from the short supply chain. This involves a limited number of economic operators engaged in economic development activity, as well as close relationships between producers, processors and consumers. However, the European Commission has shown overzeal in this case by starting preliminary proceedings to the infringement procedure, which I consider at the limit of the legality of the Treaties. I note that the adopted law does not limit the presence of European agri-food products on the shelf of Romanian traders, thus it is not an obstacle to intra-Community trade, and this law must be applied in Romania. Thank you.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control reports that from 2012 to 2015 the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance has grown enormously. The United Nations judges antibiotic resistance as a health emergency equal to that of Ebola and Aids, of which tomorrow is on World Day. The abuse of antibiotics is therefore another major European and Italian challenge, amplified by the immoded use of antibiotics on farms. Italy is Europe's third largest user of antibiotics on farms, with critical concerns in intensive. 71% of those sold in Italy go to farmed animals and 94% of treatments are mass. This mode of use makes the birth of super bacteria more and more likely, such as the risk of propagation from farms to humans, raising the number of deaths due to their resistance, about 7 000 only in Italy. There is therefore no other means to counter antibiotic resistance other than their significant reduction. I call on the Commission to adopt guidelines on the correct use of antibiotics in humans and animals and to do more in implementing and implementing measures and coordinating policies Sanitary and agricultural, to increase the effectiveness of European action against antibiotic resistance.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President! The French Council of State upheld a decision by the High Audiovisual Council denying social advertising rights to a spot where children with Down syndrome laugh, talk about themselves, show how they live. Both institutions recognized that unceremoniously telling these children about their right to life, the joy of life, could alienate women who made, I will quote, another legal choice, in short, who did not allow other similar children to be born. This decision recognising the impropriety, due to the aroused reactions, of the presence of children with Down syndrome in a public space, is an abhorrent act of discrimination making these 21st-century lepers. I look forward to the position of all the representatives of the European Union authorities who speak from office on non-discrimination matters.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: — Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Croatia today feels like a kind of garbage can. Because products come to Croatia that want to be sold, and they are 40 years old. I'm talking specifically about the meat industry case. Citizens in Croatia are very concerned about their health and I want to warn you that it is obvious that the system established in Europe in many countries is not working properly. There is no quality control. So-called Rapid alert system for food and feed obviously in some countries does not work properly. We citizens are concerned, we are concerned about our health and we want to make it clear that those who want to poison us, those who poison EU citizens, must bear large penalties or, after all, close their own production.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, just a few hours ago, we met in this Parliament the group of twelve MEPs who are going to deal with Brexit. I am pleased to be the first to have the opportunity to report this in this House. This was a very informal meeting, chaired by the President of Parliament, attended as special guest Michel Barnier, appointed by the Commission as the main negotiator with the United Kingdom. He's a person who gives me confidence for negotiation. I am pleased to be a member of this small group as chairman of the European Free Alliance. For my Scottish and Welsh colleagues, it is important that your group be present in this process, and it is for Catalonia, my country, because the withdrawal from the United Kingdom also means that we must redefine the Europe of the future in which nations like Catalonia or Scotland want to take their place.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to draw attention to the ex ante conditionalities imposed on Member States. These requirements are an instrument used as a means of forced implementation of the European Commission's policy and another case of overcoming the powers conferred by the Treaties. Under the pretext of setting conditions for effective implementation of the funds, the European Commission is in fact obliging States to implement certain structural reforms and strategies at national level. The need for them is unilaterally determined by the European Commission, without further discussion or modification in the light of specific national particularities. For example, Romania was imposed on 36 conditionalities by the end of this year, including for areas that fall within the exclusive competence of Member States, such as health and education. Member States have noticed the high complexity and unclarity of these conditionalities. If we add to them the danger of suspending funds, then national institutions will be inclined to adopt formal measures just to avoid sanctions. In the current context, when more and more voices call for simplicity and clarity in regulations, I believe that it is absolutely necessary for these conditionalities to be reviewed and the allocation of funds not to be affected by the stage of their implementation. Thank you.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). — (EL) Madam President, in the name of debt, evaluation, on the altar of the recovery of capital profitability, SYRIZA-ANEL government, the European Union, the International Monetary Fund are blackmailing and calling for new popular sacrifices, the enforcement and by law of those nightmarish about workers that are promoted. today in practice in the workplaces with operational and individual contracts. Your European acquis is that an acquired labour right should not be left standing. The best practices of the European Union served by the government on demand by employers in Greece are the liberalisation of slave trade offices, galley conditions and hunger salaries, zero-hour contracts, collective redundancies. You know where to guard, so you're targeting the right to strike. You know that a danger to you and a real way out for the workers lies in the reorganization of their movement, in their organized struggle against unpopular measures to recover losses and satisfy modern needs. On December 8, the working class with a massive nationwide strike responds for everything.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I want to take advantage of this space to address from here the representatives of the Commission and the representatives of the Council and comment on the point discussed by the IMCO Committee yesterday, and this is the trialogue over the directive control and acquisition of weapons. Yesterday we learned that it will be a political effort to end this negotiation under the Slovak Presidency by the end of this year. I wanted to call on representatives of the authorities participating in the trialogue not to really take as a political task at all costs to quickly end negotiations over a directive that (at least in the Czech Republic) provokes extraordinary emotions, is extraordinarily negatively perceived by all legal gun holders. And for the really relevant authorities of the trialogue to discuss the whole thing in detail and address things that make problems in practice. And that's the issue of deactivating weapons and the question of converting weapons. So, please, Commissioner, see this subject as extremely politically sensitive and let us not stop the negotiations at all costs as a political task, but address what results this negotiation will bring.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: — December 1 is the National Day of Romania and of all Romanians, marking a moment of great historical significance, 98 years since the Great Union in Alba Iulia. It is the moment that honors the sacrifices made by hundreds of thousands of Romanians over the centuries to achieve national unity. More than 300,000 Romanian soldiers died in World War I for this goal. Of these, more than 22,000 died and were buried abroad. Because this day belongs to all Romanians, wherever they are, I decided to rejoin myself at the graves of the eight Romanian soldiers killed in the First World War here, in Belgium, at Mons. And the most important place for my soul and of the Romanians remains Alba Iulia, the locality where modern Romania was reborn. Therefore, I wish that in 2018, when the Centennial of Romania will be fulfilled, Alba Iulia will benefit from an added recognition from the Romanian state and become a benchmark for everything that Romania's future means. I invite all European partners to join us in supporting this country project. Happy Birthday, Romania, Happy Birthday, Alba Iulia, Happy Birthday to all Romanians!

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: — Following the adoption at the last session in Strasbourg of the resolution on the accession of the Union to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women, I have a proposal and even an appeal to the European Institute for Gender Equality to examine the problem of women immigrants in refugee camps in Europe where, according to humanitarian institutions, violence against women, especially Christians, occurs. But also Muslim women are treated as objects when husbands give them back to other men in exchange for proper payment. UN figures, which cover last year, showed 75% of immigrants were young men and the rest were families with children, as if women in families were not there. Or they're not noticeable even by research organizations. Unfortunately, I have not found any report on this matter on the institute's website.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: — Madam President, the President of the Brussels Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, has just shocked much of humanity by paying tribute to Fidel Castro. In particular, he said the following sentence: “The world has lost a man who was a hero for many.” This tribute is shameful! It is an insult to the thousands of dead and to the two million exiles who are the victims of Castro. Jean-Claude Juncker shames Europe by chairing the Commission for two years in reward for his role as a great architect of tax evasion. Now he makes him ashamed by his cruelty! Castro was not a liberator, but a dictator. This is what Jean-Claude Juncker should have said in tribute to his victims. That such a leader can lead the European Union speaks a lot about what the European Union is: a Europe of money and contempt, cut off from the aspirations of the peoples, and a hundred leagues from the Europe of the nations I call for.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Europe faces many challenges. I would like to address the challenge facing the regions today. And that's eliminating differences between regions. This is part of the cohesion policy — reducing and eliminating differences, that is what the EU does in its cohesion policy, but there are still a number of backward regions that are precisely this disadvantage they are removing very slowly and actually catching up with the average of the European Union at a very slow pace. The demographic ageing of a number of regions and the eviction of residents is also a challenge. We should, in my court, create new instruments to complement those existing instruments to support the regions. Kind of like an incentive system for big firms to invest in those regions, to set up businesses and projects there. I believe that existing tools are no longer sufficient, and I would not want to live to see the collapse of a number of regions in two decades.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the main result of the presidential election in the United States is that the American political elite has been punished for its arrogance and ignorance of the interests of a large part of the population. A few months ago, a similar signal was sent by the people of Great Britain during the referendum on the country's exit from the European Union. People did not vote for Donald Trump or for Brexit, they voted against inequalities, injustices and continued disregard for their opinions. The current political system is lagging behind reality and has become ineffective. Not only can he not solve current problems, but he often creates others. People do not want to accept the fact that the current system does not bring stability and well-being to their families. Society cannot be divided between a small and wealthy minority and a large majority living in poverty, fear of unemployment and homelessness.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: (ECR). — (EL) Madam President, the great countries of the West that have sparked the Middle East and created refugee caravans are now whistling indifferently and allowing the European South to become a storehouse of souls, even shouting so-called humanitarian arguments. But it is not humanism to stack refugees in rough camps and then serve the social dumping imposed by multinationals. Refugee and migration flows must be dealt with decisively by the European Union. The Middle East peace effort must therefore be stepped up, hit the traffickers and put pressure on Erdogan to implement the EU-Turkey agreement. The Valletta Agreement must also be implemented, the relocations of refugees from Greece and Italy to other countries of the Union should be completed and the ineffective and unfair rules of Dublin III urgently changed. The Greek people must not pay for the confrontation and the short-sighted policy of the European Union. Lesvos, Chios, Samos and the other Aegean islands cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. Greece is not a storehouse of souls.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to draw attention to one of the aspects of the Roma issue that is not being addressed at the moment. And it's a matter of addressing anti-Roma rhetoric on the internet. The European Commission is mostly concerned with tackling the problem by giving money to various non-profits and government agencies. To me, this fight against anti-Roma rhetoric is not effective. Personally, I would suggest engaging Roma in solving this problem in particular, who can best explain their attitudes, their actions and are able to bring positive examples on their own. Unfortunately, anti-Roma rhetoric has not changed almost at all in the countries of the European Union over the last ten years, and it was on the basis that the European Commission did not adequately understand the issue, and tried to fix the problem with the amount of money given to various agencies and nonprofits.
